milestone_evidence:
The
 key synthesis included: 
  
 Info
 Note: “Scaling climate-smart agriculture: Towards co-creating business models
 in the input supply chains and finance chains,” presents an exploration of
 CSA scaling options in the Nyando Basin area of Kisumu and Kericho Counties
 in Kenya, through partnerships in the value chain. 
 
 Journal
 article: “Inclusive agribusiness under climate change” is a brief review of
 the role of finance as an inherent as well as synergetic component of
 inclusive agribusiness models. 
  
 Book
 chapter: “One Size Does Not Fit All: Private-Sector Perspectives on Climate
 Change, Agriculture and Adaptation” assesses how private-sector actors across
 the supply chain manage CSA. Drawing on dialogue with 42 private firms
 working in coffee, cocoa and other commodity crops. 
  
 Poster:
 Presented at the 5th Global Science Conference on Climate-Smart
 Agriculture: literature review of business models and CSA and qualitative
 fieldwork with four business models in Southern Africa to investigate the
 extent and way business models work to support CSA. 
  
 Paper
 (forthcoming): Seeks to operationalize and to assess the inclusiveness of
 business model partnerships in terms of its organizational structures. 
 
 New
 business model been piloted to upscale CSA by bundling village savings/loans
 associations with farmer field business schools that deliver knowledge to
 groups of small-scale women farmers.
gender_justification: Inclusive business models
capdev_justification: PhD and master students involved in research (WUR collaboration)
climate_justification: All on climate

outcome_sumary:
At least 64 CSA practices tested and/or evaluated across the CSV
network: 20 with gender dimensions assessed and 14 with mitigation potential. A
CSA Monitoring Framework scaled to 11 countries, which includes gender specific
indicators and provides gender disaggregated information on adoption, access to
climate information services and perceived impacts of CSA implementation on
productivity, income, access and diversity of food and climate vulnerability.
milestone_evidence:
This
 milestone includes participatory ex-ante assessments as well as monitoring
 frame works for projected trajectories. 
  
 Brief:
 “Climate-smart cocoa in Central America and the Caribbean” summarizes the
 results of participatory workshops and research for the implementation of climate-smart
 cocoa, including projections for climate change impacts on cocoa production
 and recommended climate-smart cocoa practices identified and prioritized with
 experts from Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, and El
 Salvador. 
  
 Brief:
 “Achieving climate-smart coffee in Central America” employed a similar
 approach as for cocoa to guide adaptation at scale recommendation domains to
 scale climate smart coffee practices. 
  
 Participatory
 Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) bundled with prioritized
 CSA options will be implemented and tested in the four Latin America CSVs,
 including a special focus on gender. 
  
 Gender
 consideration incorporated into the CSA Investment Plans developed for Mali
 and Cote d’Ivoire. 
 
 Monitoring:
 Evidence from Cauca, Olopa and Santa Rita CSVs shows adoption of CSA
 practices and perception of farmers being more prepared to tackle with
 climate variability. Analysis includes benefits from CSA adoption by gender.
gender_justification: PICSA incorporates gender aspects
capdev_justification: PICSA
climate_justification: All climate

milestone_evidence:
West Africa:
In Ghana, a study identified different farmer typologies across three climate
impact zones, to assess how this affects the adoption of climate-smart cocoa
practices and related recommendations. Gender-differentiated
social learning methods applied in Burkina Faso, Senegal and Ghana CSVs.
Training of 1200 women across the northern region of Ghana. In Mali, results of
CSV survey identified education, number of workers in the household, access to
subsidies and training as positive factors affecting adoption of most of the
promoted CSA technologies and practices. 
East Africa:
A study explored Gendered Trends in Commercializing and Diversifying
Smallholder Farming Systems  across different gender-respondent-household
typologies in Ethiopia, Kenya, and Tanzania. India:
A methodological framework using the positive deviance approach to inform farm
redesign for smallholder systems of Bihar. A compendium of potential CSA technologies,
practices, services and policies suitable for different agro-ecological zones,
farm typologies, and investment requirements published in Odisha (India). 

















Publications:
A journal-paper using CSV data globally on the “Impacts of smallholder agricultural
adaptation on food security: evidence from Africa, Asia, and Central America.” "The
LCA4CSA framework: Using life cycle assessment to strengthen environmental
sustainability analysis of climate smart agriculture options at farm and crop
system level" based on a typology of farming-systems.
gender_justification: Will be targetted in 2020
capdev_justification: Social learning W-Africa
climate_justification: Across the board

milestone_evidence:
Partnership
 launched in Bangladesh, Nepal and India to use digital collection tools to
 retrieve yield and crop management information from more than 50,000 farmers
 and point to opportunities to support CSA nutrient management. In India, Rice
 Crop Manager integrated with ICT-based tool for scaling out CSA providing
 recommendations to 75,000 farmers. The SeedCast digital tool used to support
 knowledge dissemination and selection of climate resilient rice
 varieties. Launch of Ethiopian Digital
 Agro-climate Advisory Platform (EDACaP). Innovative App Climate Smart Cocoa
 Implementer developed in Ghana while multifunctional community seedbanks enhanced
 access to a diversity of climate resilient seeds to 7,000 and 100,000
 smallholder farmers in Uganda and Kenya respectively. Digital Agriculture
 Profiles developed for Argentina and Grenada. Digital climate service
 “Agrotutor” mobile application developed in Mexico reaching up to 35,000 farmers.
 In Peru, Nicaragua, Mexico, and Argentina 14 CSA options identified by the
 use of novel analytical tools, mostly machine learning techniques based on
 random forest. 
 
 In Latin
 America a Methodological Framework for Achieving Large-Scale Change was
 co-designed with local stakeholders. In Laos, a systematic approach was
 introduced for multi-criteria ranking system for CSA for rainfed rice and in
 Philippines CSV a roving workshop and School-on-the-air on Climate-Smart
 Agriculture (SOA-CSA) were implemented.
gender_justification: Included in CSA scaling framework, citizen science, and seed banks
youth_justification: Included in citizen science, digital CSA
capdev_justification: Included in citizen science, digital CSA and seed banks
climate_justification: Across the board

outcome_sumary:
706,000 farmers received incentives for adopting CSA related practices
underpinned by CCAFS science. In Kenya and Uganda the establishment of
community seed-banks for storage and multiplication of diverse resilient high-quality seeds adapted to local climatic conditions reached
189,000 farmers (at least 30% women farmers), of which 82,000 potato growers
use web-based SMS platform for disseminating information on resilient seeds.
milestone_evidence:
New business model for upscaling the adoption of CSA piloted in Tanzania
bundling village savings/loans associations with farmer field business schools
that deliver knowledge to groups of small-scale women farmers.





Literature
review of business models and CSA, qualitative fieldwork with four business
models in Southern Africa to investigate the extent and way they work to
support CSA.





Peer-reviewed
article and research outputs on: the role of finance for inclusive agribusiness
under climate change; supporting farmers and SMEs to invest and adopt CSA and
on co-designing CSA business models in the supply chain. PhD thesis is underway
in Honduras on adaptation and business models by coffee value chain actors to
incentivize CSA uptake.





ERA
database gathered thousands of African CSA studies and informed two CSAIP that
if implemented, will reach hundreds of thousands smallholders.





Scalable
scheme to implement data-driven agricultural program for small-scale farmers
implemented with the Colombian Ministry of Agriculture and a national farmers’
organization. Study published on machine learning and big data techniques for
monitoring rice phenology using optical satellite data.





Innovative
App Climate Smart Cocoa Implementer developed in Ghana to support extension
services. Further developments and applications of the GeoFarmer App for data collection,
knowledge exchange and M&E.

aquaculture in Vietnam; Gender responsive technologies in India; Hostspots for gender-targeted climate change adaptation, CSA effects on rural
households and effects on-farm performance in Guatemala.

cost-Benefit analysis of CSA options published in Malawi,

Publications
on empirical relationship between credit use, effective incentives and CSA

Development
of the climate-smart cocoa implementer. Application combining two approaches: A

Scaling
framework for the dissemination of Smart-Valleys and AWD technologies developed
in Burkina Faso. Publication addressing CSA scaling through certification in

Certificated
program and materials for the implementation and scaling of CSV developed in

Compendiums
of Technologies, Practices, Services and Policies for Scaling Climate Smart

outcome_sumary: Implementation in focal countries and regions progressed significantly, although still falls short of CGIAR's GHG reduction targets. Vietnamoutscaled alternate wetting and drying (AWD) on 180,000ha, reducing 1 million+ tCO2-eq/y, as a result of IRRI's research on technical options, suitability and investment needs. In East Africa, 37,000 farmers participated in a carbon-credit scheme, sequestering ~1 MtCO2e (3rd-party verified) with 70% women, based on CCAFS partnerships with Vi-Agroforestry, ECOTRUST and EcoAgriculture.At least three CCAFS scientists and partners contributed to IPCC reports in 2019 on methods guidance and the land sector.Countries are strengthening national plans, advisory services and capacities. Colombia improved their Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action for livestock and Colombia's livestock federation implemented a livestock strategy targeting 50,000ha of degraded pasture. Women’s unions in nine provinces in Vietnam promoted coffee agroforestry, with potential impact of ~1 MtC sequestration. Vietnamrefined their Nationally Determined Contribution based on CCAFS outputs on Alternate Wetting and Drying and agroforestry and developed a LED investment plan for rice. In Tanzania, ~1,000 smallholder farmers received field-specific, nutrient advice, enabling efficient fertiliser use. In Indonesia,the private sector established a revolving fund for investments in manure management and a high quality compound concentrate feed was formulated with participation from CCAFS.

outcome_sumary:
This
 work focused on women in dairy in East Africa and agroforestry in Vietnam,
 due to the numbers of women involved. We've also supported women PhD
 fellowships for estimating emissions and supported youth initiatives in East
 Africa, Colombia and Vietnam. There has been no demand for gender-based LED
 indicators, so this milestone has been changed to support for institutional
 change and capacity building for women's participation in LED. In East
 Africa, ILRI worked with the World Bank to design gender and socially
 inclusive (including youth) livestock projects. The Kenya Dairy Board, with
 technical support from UNIQUE developed a gender mainstreaming strategy 2020–23.
 In Vietnam, 10+ organizations are using ICRAF and CARE innovations to empower
 women in coffee-based agroforestry. In Colombia, CIAT worked with extension
 groups to train youth in low-emission livestock development. An outcome study
 of the CLIFF-GRADS PhD student fellowship, which targeted 50% of fellowships
 for women, demonstrated that CCAFS investment in 54 graduate students (2011–2018,
 48% women and 52% men) led to participants' having significantly enhanced
 skills, and career options, and generated 31 publications. 80% of respondents
 applied skills and knowledge from the CLIFF-GRADS program in their work. 71%
 could initiate new ideas and innovation at their work.
milestone_evidence:
ILRI has advanced analysis of intersectionality for gender and youth and
worked with the World Bank to develop improved project designs; monitoring
indicators will come at a later phase. The Kenya Dairy Development Board
developed a gender strategy. Monitoring indicators have not yet been a priority
explicitly for LED at national levels.



Another
change is the increased attention to youth. Partnerships for youth training in
Colombia was established
gender_justification: Focus has been on institutional change and capacity building for women's participation in LED.
youth_justification: Capacity building for youth participation in LED.
capdev_justification: institutional change and capacity building for women's participation in LED.
climate_justification: Focus of program is on low-emission development

outcome_sumary:
We continue to aim to support countries' Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to the Paris Agreement and
their capacity to improve accounting for mitigation. We have also supported the
preparation of country NAMAs and investment plans in Colombia, Kenya and
Vietnam. Methods for estimating GHGs advanced with 121 new emission factors,
five countries developing improved inventories, a new Measurement, Reporting, and Verification (MRV) resource website
developed with the GRA, PhD student training and a calculator for emissions
from food loss and waste. A major global database on N2O emissions
was completed (published online in 2020).
milestone_evidence:
Methods for estimating GHGs advanced with 121 new emission factors, five
countries developing improved inventories, MRV recommendations for
agroforestry, a new Measurement, Reporting and Verification  (MRV) resource website developed with the GRA, PhD student
training and a calculator for emissions from food loss and waste. Global
database on N2O emissions completed. Students (CLIFF-GRADS) were guided in
estimating GHG emissions of food and effects of food loss and waste through the
Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas Emission (ACGE)-calculator. Scenarios generated for maize intensification in sub-Saharan
Africa.





Support
for MRV advanced in 5 countries:




-
Kenya Dairy NAMA developed improved MRV for livestock
- Colombia uses ruminant model to improve NAMA and MRV




-
China improved Tier 2 Livestock inventories at the provincial level




-
Cuba livestock emissions inventory support




-
Following IRRI’s advice, the Central Project Management Unit of the Vietnam
Sustainable Agricultural Transformation (VnSAT) project conducted additional
GHG measurements within the VnSAT program, which will be part of the M&E of
the VnSAT program but also create new data to update the development of
regional emission factors.
gender_justification: Kenya Dairy Development Board action to mainstream gender will affect Kenya's dairy NAMA. The Kenya DDB is developing a strong gender strategy; they are one of the NAMA design and implementation partners
capdev_justification: Support for country NDCs, NAMAS and MRV
climate_justification: Focus of program is low-emission development

donor

outcome_sumary:
CCAFS
 produced a range of global analyses to inform project design and finance. We
 produced the agriculture-sector blueprint for World Bank's TCAF, contributed
 technical expertise and wrote background papers and criteria for the
 agriculture standard of the Climate Bonds Initiative and produced a report
 with IFAD on the GHG footprint of their portfolio to better understand
 sources of major GHG emissions and the net effect of the portfolio on
 emissions. The food loss and waste work is still in a preliminary phase. In a
 hotspot analysis of food loss and waste, WUR quantified hotspots for FLW and
 associated GHG emissions and analyzed causes, possible interventions and
 analyzed trade-offs with GHG emissions (using the Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas
 Emissions calculator). In addition, IRRI supported development of Vietnam's
 World Bank VnSAT project and an investment plan for AWD in paddy rice. In
 East Africa, ILRI worked with the World Bank to improve MRV and design gender
 and socially inclusive (including youth) livestock projects. In Tanzania, WUR
 initiated a pilot project with c. 1,000 smallholder farmers, who received
 field-specific, nutrient advice, enabling efficient fertilizer use and
 reduced GHGs. WUR's food loss and waste analysis is behind schedule but
 started producing outputs in 2019.
milestone_evidence:
- While analysis of priority FLW value chains was conducted, a causal
analysis was not completed. This project
has had setbacks due to staff changes and prior poor performance, so is behind
schedule.





The
milestone for 2019 is instead changed to focus on analysis of priorities for
low emission finance initiatives. 
- Led design of agriculture sector blueprint for
World Bank's Transformative Carbon Asset Facility (TCAF) 






- Produced
report with IFAD on the GHG footprint of their portfolio to better understand
sources of major GHG emissions and the net effect of the portfolio on emissions







- IRRI
supported development of Vietnam's World Bank VnSAT project and an investment
plan for AWD in paddy rice.
gender_justification: Not an emphasis
capdev_justification: Supported institutional capacities of World Bank, Climate Bonds Initiative
climate_justification: This is a low-emission program

outcome_sumary:
CCAFS
 produced a range of global analyses to inform project design and finance. We
 produced the agriculture-sector blueprint for World Bank's TCAF, contributed
 technical expertise and wrote background papers and criteria for the
 agriculture standard of the Climate Bonds Initiative and produced a report
 with IFAD on the GHG footprint of their portfolio to better understand
 sources of major GHG emissions and the net effect of the portfolio on
 emissions. The food loss and waste work is still in a preliminary phase. In a
 hotspot analysis of food loss and waste, WUR quantified hotspots for FLW and
 associated GHG emissions and analyzed causes, possible interventions and
 analyzed trade-offs with GHG emissions (using the Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas
 Emissions calculator). In addition, IRRI supported development of Vietnam's
 World Bank VnSAT project and an investment plan for AWD in paddy rice. In
 East Africa, ILRI worked with the World Bank to improve MRV and design gender
 and socially inclusive (including youth) livestock projects. In Tanzania, WUR
 initiated a pilot project with c. 1,000 smallholder farmers, who received
 field-specific, nutrient advice, enabling efficient fertilizer use and
 reduced GHGs. WUR's food loss and waste analysis is behind schedule but
 started producing outputs in 2019.
milestone_evidence:
In Colombia, CIAT engaged on initiatives towards best-fit mitigation
options. A consortium was formed with Fedegan-CIPAV-The Nature Conservancy to
implement a co-designed livestock NAMA. Collaboration with IFC-World Bank resulted
in GANSO in Colombia, and forage improvement in Nicaragua with Nitaplan and
LALA. Engagement with GICON to reduce environmental problems in the vicinity of
sanitary landfills due to GHG emission, contamination of soils and water. A
biogas plant is at CIAT as platform for valorization of food an agricultural
waste. Reviewed conditions for business development and adoption of
low-emission livestock. 





Actual
and potential nutrient input requirements for maize were assessed for Sub-Saharan
Africa (published in two peer-reviewed articles and a policy brief on Fertiliser use and soil carbon
sequestration: Key messages for climate change mitigation strategies).
Findings show potential nutrient efficiencies and reductions in GHG emissions
and were widely used by industry partners. Farm-level economic assessment done
using lime with fertilizer in Kenya, showing possible economic benefits. Consequently,
a decision support tool was piloted among more than 1000 farmers in the
Southern highlands of Tanzania. The latter is an early stage outcome on which
we will build the coming years. Investment
website created as a resource to summarize low-emissions economic and finance
data.
gender_justification: Need to improve in 2020
capdev_justification: Activities utilize a strong network of collaborating partners and focus on institutionalisation (scaling up). Partners include national and regional institutes that co-developed decision tools.
climate_justification: Focus on low-emission development

CCAFS
 produced a range of global analyses to inform project design and finance. We
 produced the agriculture-sector blueprint for World Bank's TCAF, contributed
 technical expertise and wrote background papers and criteria for the
 agriculture standard of the Climate Bonds Initiative and produced a report
 with IFAD on the GHG footprint of their portfolio to better understand
 sources of major GHG emissions and the net effect of the portfolio on
 emissions. The food loss and waste work is still in a preliminary phase. In a
 hotspot analysis of food loss and waste, WUR quantified hotspots for FLW and
 associated GHG emissions and analyzed causes, possible interventions and
 analyzed trade-offs with GHG emissions (using the Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas
 Emissions calculator). In addition, IRRI supported development of Vietnam's
 World Bank VnSAT project and an investment plan for AWD in paddy rice. In
 East Africa, ILRI worked with the World Bank to improve MRV and design gender
 and socially inclusive (including youth) livestock projects. In Tanzania, WUR

milestone_evidence:
Methods for estimating GHGs advanced with 121 new emission factors,
countries developing improved inventories, and a new MRV resource website
developed with the GRA and PhD student training. Produced report on the GHG
footprint of IFAD's agricultural portfolio. WUR contributed preparations for
the Abuja 2 Summit on Fertilizers and Soil Health. World Bank’s IFC Water
Group, Coca Cola Foundation, and Bangladesh Water Partnership funding have
successfully scaled up AWD through grassroots capacity building and
IRRI-developed training manuals. IRRI provided input to Vietnam's World Bank
VnSAT project. Following IRRI’s advice, the VnSAT project conducted additional
GHG measurements, which will be part of the M&E, but also create new data to update the
development of regional emission factors.









Industry
partners have widely used analysis of nutrient input requirements for maize for
Sub-Saharan Africa, potential nutrient efficiencies and related GHG emission
reductions. Farm-level economic assessment done using lime with fertilizer in
Kenya, showing possible economic benefits. Consequently, a decision support
tool was piloted among more than 1000 farmers in the southern highlands of
Tanzania. The latter is an early stage outcome on which we will build the
coming years.
gender_justification: Not targeted
capdev_justification: Almost all of our work is focused on supporting use of improved tools and data for LED, which includes capacity building through partnerships.
climate_justification: Focus of activities was on low emission development

outcome_sumary: Both member CGIAR and NARS breeding programs have been introduced (via workshop trainings)  to the process of accurately developing market informed product profiles. All member breeding programs now have, and have submitted provisional product profiles into the Module 1 Product Profile tool. A total in excess of 200 product profiles are in the tool from various member programs across the globe on a wide range of crops.
milestone_evidence: Best practice manual published which is aligned to the product profile tool.Over 200 provisional product profiles submitted to the Product profile tool.
gender_justification: Preferences for men and women in preferred traits in varieties is a significant driver for adoption. Gender is being targeted in product profile development.
youth_justification: Member breeding programs have a mixed age group of participants.
capdev_justification: Developing the capacity of member breeding programs to be able to understand market/value chain/gender analysis needs for their breeding programs in product profiles is being hugely targeted.
climate_justification: Developing varieties through product profiles, that are resistant to effects of climate change is being specifically targeted.

outcome_sumary: Implementation guidelines for MAS, GS and QC have been modified in light of CtEH development. The newer approach is to support MAS, GS and QC pipelines within the context of modernized and unified breeding network which involves cross modular engagement within EiB with breeding teams to redesign MAS, GS and QC strategies. Generic sampling workflow and data analysis procedures are made available via EiB Toolbox.
milestone_evidence:
Partially delivered. Part i) has not yet happened. Guidelines for MAS (Markers assisted selection), QC (quality control), GS (genomic selection) are deferred due to "Crops to End Hunger" (CETH). Part (i) and (ii) are now directly related to milestones 3 (Outcome 1) and
will be achieved in 2021. The crop specific SOPs which we are developing
with the centers/ crops under CtEH should allow for deliverables here as well.

outcome_sumary: In light of CtEH reviews, the new direction was to support development of QC, MAS and GS protocols within the context of a modernized breeding approach. I.e. with strong prioritization based on centralization of trait activities within network, leveraging shared genotyping services and implementation of trait stage gates for markers currently available as well as those under development. Marker datasheets for all available trait markers currently available under low density platform was compile and will be made available via EiB Toolbox.
milestone_evidence:
Due
to Crops to End Hunger (CtEH) being prioritized over the initial plan, the use
case or documents produced will be quite different than what we’ve initially
planned (more generic). The outcome for this will look more like SOPs on how
marker tools are being used in an optimized breeding workflow and will be
developed/ custom fitted to target crops. The exact timeline will be
challenging to estimate as we are currently working with other modules within
EiB to help redesign the breeding workflow under the scope of CtEH which needs
to happen first before marker SOPs can be meaningfully developed. This will
likely take us into 2021 or early 2022 before we can have all the SOPs
documented either on EiB toolbox or by respective crop/ center. Timelines are
estimated based on CtEH proposals administered by EiB for centers to carry out
their modernization tasks. For some crops, the EiB team has recommended to
further delay on the use of molecular tools due to more fundamental issues
which need to be addressed first. Regardless, we should have one or two of
these SOPs nearing completion by this year.
gender_justification: Technical output, unable to incorporate gender component
youth_justification: Technical output, unable to incorporate youth component
capdev_justification: The strategy will support AFS breeding programs to better unitize genotyping resources
climate_justification: Technical output, unable to incorporate climate change component

outcome_sumary: A total of 6 logistic training workshops were held in South Asia and Africa targeting primarily new genotyping users and follow-ups with existing users. Over 3.5 million data points were delivered to AFS network via shared genotyping services with an estimated value of $1.0 million USD.
milestone_evidence:
The objective of this milestone
is to ultimately increase the use of genotyping tools via aggregation of demand
across all centers and crops. There are three service labs providing services
at the moment (Sweden, India and Australia). As for expenditure and investment
from users, they are divided into 2 categories:

1. 
Investment in marker
verification (setup cost). Investment in this area counts towards the overall
business volume needed to maintain the pricing. 

2. 
Routine analysis

a. 
Samples submitted
with direct connection to the project

b. 
Samples submitted
via extension of the service to other crop projects/ entities (you may notice
some charge accounts listed, example: Nextgen Cassava). All third party usages
count towards the overall business volume needed to maintain pricing as well.

In summary, from all the
combined investments, either directly or via third parties, we were able to
maintain the pricing and increase the adoption year on year.

capdev_justification: Logistics training for AFS users
climate_justification: Technical output, unable to incorporate climate change component

improvement workshop for Bioscience labs in CIMMYT, Mexico;

It needs to go to module 2. In GXE analysis, E refers to
environment. In this case how to best define the environment on where the
breeding programs will plant their trials. And how to design the breeding
schemes to approach not only the environment but also the G component and their
inter-relations, which is in the area of expertise of module 2 team. We

outcome_sumary:
BrAPI continued to develop specifications including significant work to
better accommodate use cases using markers. Currently multiple systems
including BMS, GOBii, and Breedbase are BrAPI compliant and applications
continue to utilize BrAPI (i.e. Flapjack, field book, and DArT LIMS).

In initial use cases around
 sample tracking and field data collection are moving forward with the
 development of sample orchestrator and the BrAPI compliant PhenoApps. In a
 big step towards improved coordination and sustainability the GOBii
 development team will begin working as part of the EBS project in 2020.
gender_justification: Goal is to develop an API for software development to be used by anyone.
youth_justification: Goal is to develop an API for software development to be used by anyone.
capdev_justification: Scientist are funded to attend hackathons to implement the API in tools developed by the CGIAR
climate_justification: Software could be developed dealing with climate change but the API itself does not target climate change.

outcome_sumary:
All projects have made significant
progress in the last year. BMS and EBS have developed and submitted 5-year road
maps and GOBii and EBS have restructure dev teams to ensure more alignment. Currently
BMS and Breedbase are available to all AFS breeding networks. GOBii is
available to ICRISAT, IRRI and CIMMYT networks. EBS will be available to IRRI
and CIMMYT in 2020.
milestone_evidence: All systems developed are open-source with the code available online(with the exception of EBS which is still in early stages of development).
gender_justification: Gender and youth considerations are a part of forming the software teams but the software is intended for all breeders.
youth_justification: Gender and youth considerations are a part of forming the software teams but the software is intended for all breeders.
capdev_justification: Breeding software will increase breeding capabilities across the breeding network.
climate_justification: The software is intended for all breeding programs, some may be addressing climate change issues.

outcome_sumary:
Development efforts are focused on
core systems with integration of peripheral tools accomplished through BrAPI. A
current catalog of available tools can be found in the EiB Toolbox. Peripheral
tools such as PhenoApps and ASREML are examined and provided based on defined
use cases and adoption efforts.
milestone_evidence: Several BrAPI compliant applications have been developed and are available for free download.
gender_justification: Gender and youth are not explicitly considered when evaluating software- not possible, too technical
youth_justification: Gender and youth are not explicitly considered when evaluating software- not possible, too technical
capdev_justification: Breeding database and tools are designed specifically to increase breeding capabilities across the breeding network, and to fill existing gaps in needs of member breeding programs
climate_justification: climate change is not a factor is selecting software.

outcome_sumary:
Development efforts are focused on
core systems with integration of peripheral tools accomplished through BrAPI. A
current catalog of available tools can be found in the EiB Toolbox. Peripheral
tools such as PhenoApps and ASREML are examined and provided based on defined
use cases and adoption efforts.
milestone_evidence:
With
the success of BrAPI, the focus on new databases in tools is on implementation
of BrAPI to enable various tools to connect to core breeding management
systems. As of now BMS, GOBii, and BreedBase are BrAPI compliant with EBS
committed to implanting BrAPI in the EBS service layer. A list of tools and
software available to the EiB community is found on the EiB toolbox (https://excellenceinbreeding.org/toolbox). In
addition to open-source tools, discussions have been initiated to explore
demand for ASREML and possible approaches to licensing and hosting ASREML on
servers open to CGIAR researchers.
gender_justification: not possible to target gender when prioritizing software development
youth_justification: not possible to target youth when prioritizing software development
capdev_justification: All prioritization for software development is done with the intent of increasing breeding capacity. Cap dev is the main focus
climate_justification: Climate change was not explicitly considered when prioritizing software development

outcome_sumary:
Given the BrAPI initiative and Big
Data platform investment in this space, Module 5 has reduced emphasis on this
while following the lead of the Ontology CoP. Feedback from ontology experts is
incorporated through BrAPI hackathons and oversite of the BrAPI standard with
guidance from the the ontology CoP of the Big Data platform.
milestone_evidence:
This is being addressed through
BrAPI definitions and the ontology CoP of the Big Data platform. Feedback from
ontology experts is incorporated through BrAPI hackathons and oversite of the
BrAPI standard. Given the BrAPI initiative Module 5 will follow the lead of the
Ontology CoP.
gender_justification: Not possible to explicitly address gender and youth in development of APIs
youth_justification: Not possible to explicitly address gender and youth in development of APIs
capdev_justification: Funding has been allocated for hackathons to develop APIs that are compliant with standard ontologies and meta data requirements. The primary goal of these APIs is to build capacity/support member breeding programs of EiB
climate_justification: Climate change is not explicitly targeted in development of APIs, not possible to target climate change. too technical of an output

outcome_sumary:
Several CoP meetings took place
this past year dealing polyploid crop support, biometrics and R training,
sample tracking use cases, and sabbaticals for CGIAR scientists. Reports and
notes outlining meeting outcomes are available online and through reports
included in the annual report.
milestone_evidence:
In additional to regular CoP bi-monthly meetings several
project planning, workshop and trainings meetings were held. In February of
2019 there was a module 5 developers meeting to discuss improved collaboration
and joint development across projects funded under Excellence in Breeding. A
write-up of the outcomes of the meeting can be found in Appendix 3. In May
there was a Module 5 CoP meeting to discuss the needs of plolyploid and
approaches that could be taken to address these needs. In
July a workshop training was held to provide in depth training for genomic data modeling
and R Shiny development. 

In addition to workshops and training, Module 5 sponsored
sabbaticals to enable collaboration across institution in addressing the needs
of CGIAR breeding programs.
gender_justification: Gender and youth are considered when identifying participants in CoP funded workshops and training
youth_justification: Gender and youth are considered when identifying participants in CoP funded workshops and training
capdev_justification: The CoPs fund workshops and training to increase capacity in biometrics, bioinformatics and software development.
climate_justification: Climate change is not considered or addressed in workshops or training.

outcome_sumary:
All source code is
open-source and available freely. The sustainability model is focused on a
software as a service model in which the cost of maintenance is spread across
users, rather than requiring each institute to build the infrastructure
required to host and maintain the codebase. Module 5 is working with funders to
ensure future grants include software as a service fees for running breeding
software.
milestone_evidence: All systems developed are open-source with the code available online(with the exception of EBS which is still in early stages of development). All systems are moving towards docker deployment. EBS will deploy in February of 2020.
gender_justification: Gender and youth were not explicitly considered in prioritizing programs for software deployment
youth_justification: Gender and youth were not explicitly considered in prioritizing programs for software deployment
capdev_justification: Deployment of breeding software will increase breeding capacity.
climate_justification: Climate change was not explicitly considered in prioritizing programs for software deployment

outcome_sumary:
Various publications on disease priorities and risk and disease models that
underline the need for more attention to endemic diseases at policy level have
been published. Results are being taken up by the governments in Vietnam and in
Ethiopia as part of an initiative to strengthen veterinary services that focus increasingly
on these neglected endemic diseases. Developed approaches and tools are used by
partners within and outside CGIAR.
milestone_evidence:
Risk modelling frameworks have been developed, tested, and published for
2 diseases. The control scenario evaluation framework is being applied in
Uganda in pigs. For Peste des Petits ruminants (PPR) in small ruminants, data
collection to feed into models has been initiated in 6 countries.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Various publications on disease priorities and risk and disease models that
underline the need for more attention to endemic diseases at policy level have
been published. Results are being taken up by the governments in Vietnam and in
Ethiopia as part of an initiative to strengthen veterinary services that focus increasingly
on these neglected endemic diseases. Developed approaches and tools are used by
partners within and outside CGIAR.
milestone_evidence:
A Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR)-toolbox has been developed and
pre-tested in Kenya, with data collection initiated in Kenya, Uganda, Senegal,
Mali and Burkina Faso. The toolbox includes a suite of gender sensitive survey tools to collect data on PPR
epidemiology and socio-economic impact that complement each other and can
be applied in any setting. In addition, a disease prioritization framework using
quantitative and qualitative gender sensitive methods has been tested and
rolled out.
gender_justification: The disease prioritization tool is fully gender sensitive, for the qualitative data collection with separate focus groups discsuions for men and women and separate survey tools for men and women at household level. This has allowed to fully capture views of men and women on the same topics.
capdev_justification: Specfiic trainings for research parntners were developed on particiaptory methods and gender. Similary for the ECO-PPR toolbox, training of research partners and enumerators is a key component of rolling out of the tool
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Various publications on disease priorities and risk and disease models that
underline the need for more attention to endemic diseases at policy level have
been published. Results are being taken up by the governments in Vietnam and in
Ethiopia as part of an initiative to strengthen veterinary services that focus increasingly
on these neglected endemic diseases. Developed approaches and tools are used by
partners within and outside CGIAR.
milestone_evidence: A disease transmission model for Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PPRS) in pigs in Vietnam has been developed and published.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

Various publications on disease priorities and risk and disease models that
underline the need for more attention to endemic diseases at policy level have
been published. Results are being taken up by the governments in Vietnam and in
Ethiopia as part of an initiative to strengthen veterinary services that focus increasingly
on these neglected endemic diseases. Developed approaches and tools are used by

milestone_evidence: This milestone has been extended due to issues with some probes in the lab, necessitating re-assessment of samples. A brief on this topic is in preparation and will be published on CGSPACE in 2020.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Integrated animal health interventions tested since 2017 are
 being taken up by the CRP Livestock priority country programmes and will expand
 their reach. Of the training approaches tested, the most promising are the
 community conversation training modules, which since 2018 have reached close
 to 1,600 participants, with evidence of behavior change emerging. In parallel,
 research within the herd health concept - identifying and analyzing
 underlying reasons to poor productivity - has disclosed new health and
 management shortcomings that will be included in the trainings.
milestone_evidence:
Longitudinal work in selected small scale pig herds was conducted to
obtain details on herd health/productivity challenges. This helped to devise a draft framework to conduct quick assessments of health/productivity at farm level. The extension is attributable to the need to extend the longitudinal study and the fact that the paper was submitted  for publication for the first time in early 2020.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Integrated animal health interventions tested since 2017 are
 being taken up by the CRP Livestock priority country programmes and will expand
 their reach. Of the training approaches tested, the most promising are the
 community conversation training modules, which since 2018 have reached close
 to 1,600 participants, with evidence of behavior change emerging. In parallel,
 research within the herd health concept - identifying and analyzing
 underlying reasons to poor productivity - has disclosed new health and
 management shortcomings that will be included in the trainings.
milestone_evidence: Improving pig productivity and incomes in Uganda through an environmentally sustainable and gender inclusive integrated intervention package (Uganda Priority Country Project). Some specific shortcomings in pig keeping were identified\, related to reproductive management, parasite management and feeding. This has been presented in a poster at the Agricultural Research for Development Conference, Agri4D 2019 (page 15 in the link below).
gender_justification: The herd health management means in the project and the learning about these must be gender sensitive for being efficient.
capdev_justification: This activity is about CapDev in herd health management for veterinarians and farmers
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Integrated animal health interventions tested since 2017 are
 being taken up by the CRP Livestock priority country programmes and will expand
 their reach. Of the training approaches tested, the most promising are the
 community conversation training modules, which since 2018 have reached close
 to 1,600 participants, with evidence of behavior change emerging. In parallel,
 research within the herd health concept - identifying and analyzing
 underlying reasons to poor productivity - has disclosed new health and
 management shortcomings that will be included in the trainings.
milestone_evidence:
Using community conversation, training
 modules for specific health problems were developed and rolled out and new
 modules were developed and tested  (antimicrobial use and animal
 welfare). A training of trainer module was  rolled
 out to ensure that local service providers and researchers can conduct
 community conversations without CRP involvement.
gender_justification: All training modules addressing herd health challenges in Ethiopia are developed in a fully gender sensitive way to ensure the roles of women and men in animal health management  are adequately adressed. The Community Conversation, which are a key approach in rolled out trainings, are developed based on research on division of labour in animal health management and specifically addresses topics of interest for women
capdev_justification: The materials developed have the main focus to train farmers and also include training materials for researcher and/or service providers at local and national level.
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
A training module on antimicrobial use and resistance has been developed
and tested in two communities in Ethiopia, involving 120 participants, with
early indication of change in practices. Twenty participants received training at
a training of trainer session. The trainers will roll out the module in
additional communities.
milestone_evidence: The surveys on antimicrobial use have been completed in Ethiopia (in press), Vietnam and Uganda with two more publications pending for Uganda. A summary report on gaps and interventions across countries is pending.
gender_justification: the AMUSE tool collects gender disagregated data and the community conversation appraoch provides in depth data on knowledge, attitude and practices reltaed to antimicrobial use by men and women, allowing to identify gender specific interventions
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
For east coast fever (ECF), nanoparticle p67C-I53-50A gave a 60%
 protection against an LD70 challenge with almost four times less antigen
 relative to previous antigen formulations. In African swine fever (ASF),
 construction of two CRISPR-cas9 gene deleted ASFV strains was completed.
 These vaccine candidates will be tested in pigs in 2020. Screening of the
 T-cell response in 23 pigs after ASFV immunization has been completed. Based
 on the repertoire of responses in individual pigs, the data will be used to
 prioritize genes for subunit vaccine studies. Finally, for Contagious Caprine
 Pleuropneumonia (CCPP), we have shown that inactivated Mccp ILRI181 prepared
 according to OIE guidelines confers protection and is a promising strain to
 replace existing commercial vaccine strains as it exhibits faster growth
 rates. Live wildtype Mccp strain ILRI181 inoculated subcutaneously did not
 cause disease and resulted in goats immune to CCPP. This route of
 immunization could be 
 used to develop a live vaccine.
milestone_evidence:
Improved ELISA with IDVet in France for prototype improvement and
decision on commercialization to be taken by them. Lateral flow test
development has not yet been completed by partners due to lack of funds. Market
analysis for lateral flow test in Kenya will be led by GALVmed in 2020 as part
of the Transformation of Animal Health Services and Solution in Low to Middle
Income Countries (TAHSSL) initiative.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
For east coast fever (ECF), nanoparticle p67C-I53-50A gave a 60%
 protection against an LD70 challenge with almost four times less antigen
 relative to previous antigen formulations. In African swine fever (ASF),
 construction of two CRISPR-cas9 gene deleted ASFV strains was completed.
 These vaccine candidates will be tested in pigs in 2020. Screening of the
 T-cell response in 23 pigs after ASFV immunization has been completed. Based
 on the repertoire of responses in individual pigs, the data will be used to
 prioritize genes for subunit vaccine studies. Finally, for Contagious Caprine
 Pleuropneumonia (CCPP), we have shown that inactivated Mccp ILRI181 prepared
 according to OIE guidelines confers protection and is a promising strain to
 replace existing commercial vaccine strains as it exhibits faster growth
 rates. Live wildtype Mccp strain ILRI181 inoculated subcutaneously did not
 cause disease and resulted in goats immune to CCPP. This route of
 immunization could be 
 used to develop a live vaccine.
milestone_evidence: Construction of two CRISPR-cas9 gene deleted ASFV strains has been completed. These vaccine candidates will be tested in pigs in 2020. Screening of the T-cell response in 23 pigs after ASFV immunization to a synthetic peptide library of 217 ASFV genes has been completed. Based on the repertoire of responses in individual pigs, the data will be used to prioritize genes for subunit vaccine studies. For example, there was no response to 62 genes in any pig, indicating these genes are not of vaccine interest.

capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Veterinary
 diagnostics for trade and epidemiological surveillance would play a
 significant role in improving animal health generally. Point of care
 diagnostics face major difficulties in adoption as is the case for several
 other animal health services and products. Thermostable batches of the PPR
 vaccine have been successfully produced and will be deployed next year when
 the cost-effectiveness of the vaccine will be assessed
milestone_evidence:
The effectiveness of a thermostable (stable even at moderate heat) PPR
vaccine was assessed. Market for diagnostics was taken over by the new Transformation of Animal Health Services and Solution in Low to Middle Income Countries (TAHSSL) initiative.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Veterinary
 diagnostics for trade and epidemiological surveillance would play a
 significant role in improving animal health generally. Point of care
 diagnostics face major difficulties in adoption as is the case for several
 other animal health services and products. Thermostable batches of the PPR
 vaccine have been successfully produced and will be deployed next year when
 the cost-effectiveness of the vaccine will be assessed
milestone_evidence:
We tested public-private partnership (PPP) models on vaccine delivery
and tested mobile animal health service delivery in Kenya. In Ethiopia, we designed
a community conversation approach for delivery of anthelmintics (antiparasitic
drugs) to small ruminant producers while in Mali we tested an innovation
platform (a participatory forum for stakeholders) for delivery of vaccines.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

Veterinary
 diagnostics for trade and epidemiological surveillance would play a
 significant role in improving animal health generally. Point of care
 diagnostics face major difficulties in adoption as is the case for several
 other animal health services and products. Thermostable batches of the PPR
 vaccine have been successfully produced and will be deployed next year when
 the cost-effectiveness of the vaccine will be assessed
milestone_evidence:
The
 Kenya government has adopted and issued guidelines on private sector role in
 vaccine delivery. In Mali, ILRI scientists working on domestic ruminant livestock value chains helped increase vaccination rates by improving interactions among stakeholders such as farmers, private veterinarians, local leaders and public veterinary services, facilitating collaboration in planning, implementing and evaluating the vaccination programs and fostering knowledge sharing, communication and capacity building. The delay in the start of the HEARD project in Ethiopia did not allow sufficient progress in developing the modules to the point of testing by 2019 but this is ongoing.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary:
Plans to establish an advanced dairy cattle research facility at ILRI's Kapiti research station were abandoned due to lack of funding (milestone 1.1.5). This means that some anticipated flagship work e.g. a study on the milk-yield of various breeds dairy cattle to different planes of nutrition are unable to be undertaken at this stage. However excellent data on livestock systems and animal performance is being accumulated through other flagship initiatives (e.g milestone 1.1.7) that
will eventually allow for analysis similar to that planned on the research
station data (though under a longer timeframe).
milestone_evidence:
The anticipated funding for this did not become 
available and no alternate funding sources have been identified to date or seem likely in the near future.  This milestone is thus cancelled.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Plans to establish an advanced dairy cattle research facility at ILRI's Kapiti research station were abandoned due to lack of funding (milestone 1.1.5). This means that some anticipated flagship work e.g. a study on the milk-yield of various breeds dairy cattle to different planes of nutrition are unable to be undertaken at this stage. However excellent data on livestock systems and animal performance is being accumulated through other flagship initiatives (e.g milestone 1.1.7) that
will eventually allow for analysis similar to that planned on the research
station data (though under a longer timeframe).
milestone_evidence:
Progress has been made on mobile application development, with piloting by smallholder-farmers underway in Kenya.  In Tanzania and Ethiopia, internet coverage is not as extensive hence farmer access and adoption of tools is not yet fully rolled out.
Political strife in Ethiopia has also slowed down the rate of engagement with farming communities.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: Both national partners and farmers are trained on using mobile applications to access information for decision making to enable more profitable dairy production
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: The flagship is supporting genetic improvement strategies for dairy cattle, small ruminants, pigs and chicken.  Milestones for 2019 related to the dairy cattle genetic improvement program include: the availability of a  genomic tool (for determining parentage and breed composition of animals), which is currently in development with commercial partners (milestone 1.2.4; still ongoing); and use of a customised breeding objective to ensure genetically improved cattle meet the needs and preferences of the smallholder farmers  (milestone 1.2.6; also still ongoing).
milestone_evidence: The background work in development of this tool is complete (i.e. the SNPs for breed composition and parentage determination have been identified). Two commercial companies (IGSS and Livestock Genetic Analysis) have been contacted in relation to production of the chip, and discussions with them are still ongoing.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: The flagship is supporting genetic improvement strategies for dairy cattle, small ruminants, pigs and chicken.  Milestones for 2019 related to the dairy cattle genetic improvement program include: the availability of a  genomic tool (for determining parentage and breed composition of animals), which is currently in development with commercial partners (milestone 1.2.4; still ongoing); and use of a customised breeding objective to ensure genetically improved cattle meet the needs and preferences of the smallholder farmers  (milestone 1.2.6; also still ongoing).
milestone_evidence: Data is still building-up for the identified breeding objective to be incorporated into the breeding program: it is expected that the breeding objective will be in use to identify genetically superior dairy cattle by 2021.
other_reason: Ongoing data collection
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Towards business models for multiplication and delivery of improved
livestock genetics, a network of reproductive labs supporting delivery systems
for small ruminants has been established in two countries (milestone 1.3.3) and
business models for artificial insemination of dairy cattle have been
established and tested in one country (milestone 1.3.4). Whilst not listed as a
2019 milestone, work towards establishing business models for delivery of
improved chicken and pigs is also ongoing. Genetic gains and distribution of better
chicken breeds are described in an OICR.
milestone_evidence:
Plans were revised from the 9 and 2 stated in the milestone to 7 and 1 respectively. Platforms for the certification of sires and for the delivery of
reproductive technologies to support community based breeding programs for four
sheep and three goat breeds are ongoing in Ethiopia. These were operationalised
in collaboration with national partners. 1 platform has also been established in Tanzania.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: Training of national partners and post-graduate students in use of the reproductive technology labs
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Towards business models for multiplication and delivery of improved
livestock genetics, a network of reproductive labs supporting delivery systems
for small ruminants has been established in two countries (milestone 1.3.3) and
business models for artificial insemination of dairy cattle have been
established and tested in one country (milestone 1.3.4). Whilst not listed as a
2019 milestone, work towards establishing business models for delivery of
improved chicken and pigs is also ongoing. Genetic gains and distribution of better
chicken breeds are described in an OICR.
milestone_evidence:
Two business models are being piloted in Kenya: in the first county
governments are subsidizing farmers’ access to breeding services through a digital
voucher system; in the second a private breeding service provider (Gene plus)
is charging for the service. Similar business
model options will be tested in Tanzania under the CRP priority country
initiative
other_reason: Longer than anticipated start-up time on the pilot
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Towards policy and institutional arrangements on animal genetic resource
use, smallholder poultry platforms were established in three countries with an
aim (amongst other) of identifying and establishing appropriate delivery models
for improved genetics coupled with strong private sector involvement. Moving
forward, less emphasis will be placed on this outcome due to the generally
favourable institutional and policy environment around animal genetic
improvement in the flagship target countries.
milestone_evidence:
In Nigeria, Tanzania and Ethiopia a smallholder poultry platform was
established in each to serve as the means for value chain diagnosis, challenge
identification and solution co-creation to ensure the development of
appropriate delivery models for improved chicken breeds for smallholder farmers.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: The forums create opportunities for learning from other smallhold farmers, input suppliers and subject matter specialists.
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Technology developers are now considering environmental issues when setting
priorities in three countries: Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda. One of the tools
used is the heat stress mapping originally developed for pigs but has since expanded
to dairy systems. The tools allow
technology developers to understand the likely impacts of climate change (heat
stress) on production systems (e.g. pigs) so that they can adapt (e.g. breeds)
to these new future conditions. The
CLEANED ex-ante impact assessment tool also predicts likely impacts of a
technology on GHG emissions, water use, soils and biodiversity.
milestone_evidence:
The tools are in use three countries (Tanzania, Ethiopia and Kenya), through trainings of
partners. Evidence includes a report on refinement of the CLEANED tool and a presentation
at workshop in Southern Africa.
gender_justification: At the moment the tools are all biophysical; we hope to introduce gender to CLEANED in 2020.
youth_justification: We are not able to include youth at the moment in this targeting.
capdev_justification: We conduct trainings in CLEANED with national and NGO partners.
climate_justification: The goal of supporting users to consider environmental issues is critical for adapting technologies to climate change.

outcome_sumary:
Greenhouse gas (GHG) baselines fully published in Kenya; data analysis
almost complete in Tanzania; data complete in Vietnam but not published. RHoMIS
(Rural Household Multi-Indicator Survey) assessments used across more than ten
countries for tradeoff analysis among household objectives: food security, land allocation among farm
enterprises, GHG emissions, income.
milestone_evidence:
Greenhouse gas emissions baselines published.

Rural Household Multi-Indicator Survey (RHoMIS) tool use documented
and data for 13,000 households publicly available.
gender_justification: the RHoMIS analyses are all gender disaggregated.
youth_justification: We hope to do more age disaggregated analysis with RHoMIS data in 2020.
capdev_justification: Trainings in RHoMIS are a significant part of its uptake.
climate_justification: The goal of supporting users to understand environmental impacts and tradeoffs among objectives is critical to both mitigating GHGs and adapting to climate change.

outcome_sumary:
Greenhouse gas (GHG) baselines fully published in Kenya; data analysis
almost complete in Tanzania; data complete in Vietnam but not published. RHoMIS
(Rural Household Multi-Indicator Survey) assessments used across more than ten
countries for tradeoff analysis among household objectives: food security, land allocation among farm
enterprises, GHG emissions, income.
milestone_evidence: Ongoing collection of data on greenhouse gas emissions.  Continued stream of publications in process.
gender_justification: All RHomis analysis is gender disaggregated.
youth_justification: we do not look at youth at the moment.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Greenhouse gas emissions baselines are a major impact assessed.

outcome_sumary:
Results of feeding trials are now completed in Kenya with more underway. These results are applicable across East Africa.
 Ongoing work on pasture management in Colombia continues to show that Nitrous
 Oxide emissions are reduced from well-managed pastures. Rangeland management
 and restoration techniques are in use in Kenya, Tanzania, Ethiopia and
 Tunisia.
milestone_evidence: In 2019 we published two articles on the impacts of improved feeding regimes on greenhouse gas emissions.
gender_justification: We consider the gendered implications of new interventions..e.g. labour burden for women, women's land access and market participation.
youth_justification: At the moment we do not focus on implications for youth.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Managing the environmental footprint of livestock production is critical to managing the impacts of climate change.  We also seek to reduce GHG emissions from livestock.

outcome_sumary:
Results of feeding trials are now completed in Kenya with more underway. These results are applicable across East Africa.
 Ongoing work on pasture management in Colombia continues to show that Nitrous
 Oxide emissions are reduced from well-managed pastures. Rangeland management
 and restoration techniques are in use in Kenya, Tanzania, Ethiopia and
 Tunisia.
milestone_evidence: We have produced and are disseminating guidance on rangeland management in Tunisia, Kenya and Ethiopia. Dissemination is still ongoing in Tanzania.
gender_justification: In 2019 we began to look at women's engagement in rangeland management and hope to introduce gender responsive guidance in 2020.
capdev_justification: The dissemination of the interventions requires training of local partner staff.
climate_justification: Improving rangeland management also contributes to adaptation to climate change.

outcome_sumary: We produced a synthesis report on best practice/ progress to date to better integrate gender concerns and make sustainable land management interventions more gender responsive.We continue to work on understanding the gender differences in participation in the Index Based Livestock Insurance Program.
milestone_evidence: The review of gender and sustainable land management has been published and shared.
gender_justification: The entire outcome focuses on gender.
youth_justification: We are not yet looking at youth.
capdev_justification: we have not yet started trainings.
climate_justification: The whole flagship focuses on environmental management, including climate change.

outcome_sumary: We continue to work with local and national government agencies in Tanzania, Ethiopia, Kenya and Tunisia to improve the governance and management of rangelands. This includes continued engagement on land policy in Tunisia; the success of Joint Village Land Use planning in Tanzania; the success of the Woreda Level Land Use Planning in Ethiopia; and the integration of land use planning for rangelands into the Kenya national land use planning guidelines.
milestone_evidence:
In Kenya tools developed by ILRI are included in the national Land
Commission guidelines for county spatial planning (see Innovation 1071).



In Tanzania, the Joint
Village Land Use Planning process has been developed with government (see Innovation
277).



In Ethiopia the Woreda
planning was recognised by the national government (see Innovation 279).
gender_justification: With PIM we published a review of the status of pastoral women in land use decisions. In Tunisia we also have sensitised policy makers on women's role in rangeland management.
youth_justification: No work on youth at present.
capdev_justification: The work on land governance involves training of national partners.
climate_justification: Improved rangeland governance is a tool for adaptation to climate change.

outcome_sumary: We published a policy brief outlining our experience working with national partners on improving GHG emissions factors to attract climate finance and report on their climate change commitments under the 2015 Paris Agreement.We also attended several meetings to raise awareness of the benefits of work on improving GHG emissions from African livestock systems.  This included advice to the IPCC Emission Factor Data Base in 2019.
milestone_evidence: A policy brief on engaging stakeholders on policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the livestock sector was  produced. The recognition of the data by the IPCC is an additional bonus.
gender_justification: At the moment our recommendations focus purely on improving GHG reporting and inventories.
capdev_justification: We engage national policy makers and technical staff as well as global scientific bodies. raising their awareness
climate_justification: The advice all pertains to climate change and livestock production.

outcome_sumary:
Progress in 2019 was mainly on strengthening the partnership with FAO
and CIRAD as well as raising funds to improve the modelling at various levels,
including on gender and environment aspects. While the actual modelling work is
delayed, the additional resources, including the recruitment of a full time modeller,
will allow the team to deliver a more robust, user friendly and flexible sets
of models, to guide policies and investment decisions. This is timely as four
countries have expressed interest in developing a livestock master plan, with fund
raising ongoing.
milestone_evidence: Through additional support to bilateral projects (LSIL, PIM) and the use of supplemental Livestock CRP funds, progress was made towards developing conceptual frameworks and modeling approches that integrate meso-level value chain models and macro level partial equilibrium models in the context of informing livestock master plans and other livestock policy processes
gender_justification: including gender in the LMP modelling will start in 2020
capdev_justification: the work includes capacity development of next users (e.g. government staff)
climate_justification: funds are sought to be able to include climate change considerations in this modelling

outcome_sumary:
Progress in 2019 was mainly on strengthening the partnership with FAO
and CIRAD as well as raising funds to improve the modelling at various levels,
including on gender and environment aspects. While the actual modelling work is
delayed, the additional resources, including the recruitment of a full time modeller,
will allow the team to deliver a more robust, user friendly and flexible sets
of models, to guide policies and investment decisions. This is timely as four
countries have expressed interest in developing a livestock master plan, with fund
raising ongoing.
milestone_evidence:
Reasons are twofold: one relates to modalities of working within the
FAO/ CIRAD/ ILRI partnership that took more time than expected and secondly,
time and expertise were spent fundraising for this work, with the work
accelerating in 2020 with the addition of a full time modeller.
gender_justification: new models will include gender differentiated assessment and analysis of interventions
capdev_justification: Capacity development is required for the countries to be able to use the model on their own, or at least to understand the data needs, assumptions and be able to interpret the outputs. A training on the current LSIPT was held in Bangkok with FAO and partners from Asia.
climate_justification: funds are sought to be able to include climate change considerations in this modelling

outcome_sumary:
Progress was made in integration of gender in the priority country
programs as well as in work with technical teams, in particular health,
genetics and feeds and forages. Elevating gender considerations into policies
and investment decisions is done through the livestock master plans and
associated modelling.
milestone_evidence: The work has been delayed, due to competing priorities. The work is re-starting in 2020, with the help of a librarian from Cornell University and bringing in a wider team of gender and other social scientists.
gender_justification: the work is focused on gender
youth_justification: while including youth may be interesting, the work focuses on women/men differentiation
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: not relevant at this stage

outcome_sumary:
Progress was made in integration of gender in the priority country
programs as well as in work with technical teams, in particular health,
genetics and feeds and forages. Elevating gender considerations into policies
and investment decisions is done through the livestock master plans and
associated modelling.
milestone_evidence: While the writing of the gender strategy has been delayed due to competing priorities, the team continues to support the different flagships and country teams, to integrate gender in their work, including the assessment of gender differentiated impacts.
gender_justification: the work is focused on gender
youth_justification: while including youth may be interesting, the work focuses on women/men differentiation
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: not relevant at this stage

outcome_sumary: The planned milestone has been delivered. The team is also testing, either as a lead or working with other organisations, different gender transformative approaches in Ethiopia, Tanzania and Ghana. This complements the gender work within the priority countries activities.
milestone_evidence: The paper has been published
gender_justification: the work is focused on gender
youth_justification: while including youth may be interesting, the work focuses on women/men differentiation
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: not relevant at this stage

outcome_sumary:
A number of projects are currently testing, promoting and evaluating
technologies and practices developed by Livestock CRP. For many of these more
development oriented projects, however, the evidence - using rigorous methods (e.g.
including control sites and households) is lacking.
milestone_evidence: In Ethiopia about 1000 male- and 150 female-headed households apply at least one best-bet interventions (IFAD funded small ruminant project). Monitoring data are available. In Kenya, the accelerated value chain development (AVCD) project, both dairy and livestock, is also promoting technologies and practices developed by ILRI.
gender_justification: some gender differentiation possible (but not within household)
capdev_justification: capacity building activities of farmers and other actors are being conducted
climate_justification: not included in project activities

outcome_sumary: A number of projects are currently testing, promoting and evaluating institutional arrangements developed by Livestock CRP. For many of these more development oriented projects, however the evidence - using rigorous methods (e.g. including control sites and households) is lacking.
milestone_evidence: Delays have been experienced with data collection and therefore analysis. The paper will be developed as part of a special issue in Frontiers
other_reason: project reports are available but no external evaluation planned
gender_justification: analysis is conducted for women and men separately, we are also assessing if and how the business approach should be different between women and men
capdev_justification: topic not considered
climate_justification: topic not considered

outcome_sumary: PIM-supported foresight modeling feeds into the production of reports that have been used by many stakeholders, such as multilateral organizations and donors (Asian Development Bank, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Central America Council, Food and Agriculture Organisation, Inter-American Development Bank, International Fund for Agricultural Development, Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, United Nations Environmental Program, World Bank) and national governments, including in Cambodia, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Indonesia, Philippines, South Africa, United Kingdom, the United States, Uzbekistan and Vietnam (Lowder and Regmi, 2019).
milestone_evidence: The multiple outcomes from the PIM foresight work collected by Sara Lowder and Anita Regmi in their 2019 report present a strong case for the completion of the 2019 milestone. Early or mature outcomes have been documented across multilateral organizations and donors (Asian Development Bank, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Central America Council, Food and Agriculture Organisation, Inter-American Development Bank, International Fund for Agricultural Development, Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, United Nations Environmental Program, World Bank). Analysis provided to a multi-donor group in 2018 informed donor understanding and decision making in 2019 about crop breeding in the context of climate change through the Crops to End Hunger Initiative.
gender_justification: Ongoing work to try to include gender considerations in foresight analysis
youth_justification: These two outputs address youth issues: Background report for the IFAD 2019 Rural Development Report: http://ebrary.ifpri.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15738coll5/id/7000; webinar: http://ebrary.ifpri.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15738coll16/id/1065
capdev_justification: Work to expand uptake, understanding and use of the results of foresight modeling, including through learning sessions for Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation senior leadership and ongoing dialog with USAID and other funding partners
climate_justification: The bulk of the work addresses questions that have climate change either as the main topic or as one of the scenarios under investigation

outcome_sumary: The Government of Ethiopia used evidence generated by PIM to launch the Digital Agricultural Advisory Services initiative to introduce digitalized delivery and content throughout the national extension system, with support from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and UK Department for International Development. The Government of Uganda, Uganda Forum for Agricultural Advisory Services and USAID have used PIM-supported studies and been active participants in PIM’s efforts to strengthen extension systems in Uganda. The Program on Biosafety Systems team has continued supporting countries in improving regulatory environments and capacity for managing biotechnology, including in Ethiopia, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania and Uganda.
milestone_evidence:
The Biotechnology and Biosafety Rapid Assessment and Policy Platform
team completed ex ante economic assessments of selected genetically
engineered crops in Ethiopia, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania and Uganda. As an
integral part of the project, IFPRI trained and assisted senior local
economists in the use of the DREAM model, thus contributing to building in-country
capacity in ex ante assessments.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: IFPRI trained and assisted senior local economists in the use of the DREAM model, thus contributing to building in-country capacity in ex ante assessments of genetically engineered crops
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: As noted in the 2018 external assessment of ASTI, a number of countries have used ASTI data and analyses to support budgetary discussions. More recently, Myanmar began the design of a new master plan for the modernization of the country’s research and extension system. In India ASTI has been integrated into the national science and technology information management system. In Southeast Asia and the Pacific, NARS and other national institutions are using ASTI-type data collection and analysis. Vietnam’s agriculture and rural development strategy for 2020–2030 and Laos’ Agriculture Development Strategy 2025 are using ASTI analyses.
milestone_evidence: As noted in the 2018 external assessment of the Agricultural Science and Technology Indicators (ASTI) initiative, ASTI partners in Brazil, Mauritania, Nepal and Nigeria have used ASTI data and analyses to successfully advocate for higher agricultural R&D spending.
gender_justification: ASTI data in country factsheets address differences in  male/female data. Assessment of gender gap is part of the work conducted by ASTI
youth_justification: Not a specific focus at the moment although ASTI country factsheets present data by age group
