Documentation of the value of origin specific genomic selection in exotic by elite populations conducted and draft manuscript submitted.Phenotypic evaluation of genetic gain for drought stress in two GS pre-breeding populations initiated. Other validation activities postponed due to large funding cut in the MasAgro Biodiversidad project in 2019.
milestone_evidence: 30 and 28 new lines of 7th WYCYT and 9th SATYN, respectively distributed to ~100 sites per nursery• IWYP Hub catalogue for ordering new germplasm• USAID’s FeedtheFuture website featured the article: High yielding genetically diverse wheat lines based on physiological traits delivered to public & private breeders globallyAnnouncement by IWYP and USAID websites. Seed of SATYN and WYCYT available on request through CIMMYT international nurseries.
gender_justification: Not relevant
capdev_justification: Under this milestone, seminars and field practice using phenotyping tools was conducted with four scientists from different research institutions. Four scientists did long-term PhD training at CIMMYT under this milestone.
climate_justification: Under this milestone, traits that are emphasized include Root capacity for water uptake under drought, and to maintain cooler canopies that also match evaporative demand under heat at high VPD to deal with changing temperatures, Canopy ground cover under drought, and development and maintenance of photosynthetic area under heat, Photo-protective traits/mechanisms, Spike photosynthesis for heat or drought

outcome_sumary: Adequate progress. Some delays due to technical issues (field data too late; software requirements and development) or funding constraints. Documentation of the value of origin specific genomic selection in exotic by elite populations conducted and draft manuscript submitted.Phenotypic evaluation of genetic gain for drought stress in two GS pre-breeding populations initiated. Other validation activities postponed due to large funding cut in the MasAgro Biodiversidad project in 2019.
milestone_evidence: Sparse testing in plant breeding and in genomic-enabled predictions implies modifying the original multi-environment breeding trials system (where all breeding germplasms are evaluated in all the testing environments) into a system where not all the breeding lines are sown in all environments. The question is how to establish a multi-environmental trial system that will be economically feasible, save land and water resources, without highly affecting the precision by which breeding lines or varieties performance are assessed, predicted and selected. For the reasons previously outlined, the main objective of this research was to study the genomic-enabled prediction accuracy of different field sparse testing systems for maize and wheat multienvironment trials.Analyses for wheat are also finished
gender_justification: Not targeted as only indirectly relevant at later stage in impact pathway, see FP3
capdev_justification: It was demonstrated that sparse testing can be used to save costs and time for FP3 breeders and for partner breeding teams in phenotyping
climate_justification: pertaining to climate change-relevant traits

outcome_sumary: Some delays with regard to rolling out the Enterprise Breeding System, otherwise on track.
milestone_evidence: Although we have extensive evidence of requirements and software development efforts at IRRI and CIMMYT documented in our Confluence and Azure sites, these are not available to the public. The only public evidence is this CIMMYT article. Software development ongoing in 2020.
gender_justification: Possibly relevant in terms of gendered access to actionable information, but not in scope here
capdev_justification: As the development of the Enterprise Breeding System continued during the year, four staff members working as Requirements Analysts learned how to use the B4R component of the EBS and also developed skills in capturing user requirements and documenting workflows using BPMN diagrams. The skills developed are a key internal capacity required to effectively and efficiently drive the design, implementation and roll out of EBS in the coming years.
climate_justification: Wheat scientists at CIMMYT are involved in pre-breeding and breeding efforts related to climate-related traits including drought and heat tolerance.  They conduct trials at CIMMYT to select stress-tolerant varieties and also send out sets of germplasm for evaluation globally. Those trials are registered in the centralized IWIS2 database, and subsets of phenotypic data are loaded into two internal databases where they are available to support analysis and decision-making. The Semi-Arid Wheat Screening Nursery (SAWSN) is just one example of a stress-tolerance related trial with data registered in CIMMYT’s centralized systems. Access to this data is critical to the development of climate adapted germplasm.

outcome_sumary: Some delays with regard to rolling out the Enterprise Breeding System, otherwise on track.
milestone_evidence: The GOBii project will be integrated into the EBS project and the user interfaces will change so the standalone GOBii system will not be widely released to breeding team members even though data loading to the system will continue
gender_justification: Not relevant
capdev_justification: Three scientists at CIMMYT were introduced to the GOBii data extractor to enable them to download selected genotypic data stored in the database. They also received demonstrations of additional tools under development through the GOBii project including Flapjack and DArTview. In addition, two curators learned how to use new versions of the GOBii software that were released during the year. The skills developed are a key internal capacity required to effectively and efficiently drive the implementation and roll out of GOBII as part of the broader EBS in the coming years.
climate_justification: Wheat scientists at CIMMYT are involved in pre-breeding and breeding efforts related to climate-related traits including drought and heat tolerance. Data concerning the genetic composition of CIMMYT’s materials can be useful in identifying the genomic basis of climate-trait related phenotypes and for selecting potentially stress-tolerant materials through other analyses, like genomic selection. The genotypic data loaded to CIMMYT’s centralized GOBii database in 2019 contribute to these analyses.

outcome_sumary: Some delays with regard to rolling out the Enterprise Breeding System, otherwise on track.
milestone_evidence: To our knowledge, no studies have addressed the potential interaction between pedigree and genomic information, and between pedigree, genomic, and environmental information for a large number of lines evaluated for several years where lines are tested for only one year. If genome-enabled prediction is more effective when individuals are genetically (pedigree) related than when they are nominally unrelated, the interaction between pedigree and markers and between marker, pedigree and environmental information could result in better prediction accuracy. When the interaction with environments is studied, the number of environments plays an important role because the number of correlations that needs to be estimated grows exponentially, and the complexity of the model increases significantly.
gender_justification: Not relevant
capdev_justification: addressing the challenge involved the data driven interaction of breeders, statisticians and molecular breeders from academia, national and international research areas. This interaction enhanced understanding of the complexities of the challenge faced, broadened capacities of the individuals involved allowing the exploration and development of informed approaches for future application.
climate_justification: Not relevant

outcome_sumary:
In 2019, we finalized methods and
 tools that can be used for: benchmarks and guidelines for healthy diets at
 individual and household level in our four focus countries; characterizing
 diet-food system linkages; assessing and visualizing food system
 sustainability; understanding food system drivers; and measuring the current state
 of food systems and their direction through a common set of indicators. All
 focus country food system papers were finalized and being used by several
 organizations to develop future strategies, through dietary gap and
 determinants analysis; characterize sub-national food systems; and further
 analyze the food environment. The A4NH-CGIAR consultations leveraged food
 systems thinking.
milestone_evidence:
Food-based dietary guidelines in Ethiopia disseminated (e.g. at ag2nut
webinar, in voices from the field) and adopted as a flagship project by
Government. Common set of indicators have started to be used by other
organizations, such as the World Bank. Food systems papers (Bangladesh,Vietnam,Vietnam subnational ) were disseminated.
gender_justification: The metrics and tools mentioned in this milestone do not include specific tools for assessing gender although sex-disaggregation analysis is possible.
youth_justification: The metrics and tools mentioned in this milestone do not include specific tools for assessing youth although age-disaggregation analysis is possible.
capdev_justification: The metrics and tools mentioned in this milestone were incorporated into several trainings, MSc and PhD projects. Building awareness of food systems metrics and tools as well as capacity to use them is a key activity in FP1.
climate_justification: The metrics and tools mentioned in this milestone includes sustainability, especially as a food system outcome, or related to diets.

Foresight
analysis ready for use in Nigeria;
participatory scenario analysis planned in Nigeria but postponed. Overall
foresight paper drafted but not yet published.
other_reason: This work is ongoing but not yet completed as FP1 will provide more output on leverage points uptill the end of the programme in 2021
gender_justification: Gender forms a central part in identification of leverage points
youth_justification: A first conceptual paper on youth and food systems is being developed based upon which youth sentive leverage points will be identified.

outcome_sumary:
We developed a multidisciplinary framework to identify and analyze food
system innovations and possible entry points for the design of potential
innovations. These innovations should attempt to influence food system dynamics,
especially in the area of consumer behavior, food environment and value chains.
With partners, we designed consumer-oriented interventions to increase
accessibility, affordability and acceptability of nutritious foods such as
fruits and vegetables, poultry, and fish in the four focus countries. Once
evaluated, they will provide empirical evidence on how food system innovations
could transform existing food systems to lever important outcomes related to
diet, sustainability and equity.
milestone_evidence: The multidisciplinary framework on food system innovations. Example of use of food system lens in value chain work. Partners included in the various food systems innovations: in Ethiopia (NEEP); in Bangladesh (Partex); in Nigeria: (University of Ibadan); in Vietnam (Ministry of Education Dong Anh District, Hanoi Medical University, Rikolto).
gender_justification: gender issues have not been addressed  specifically in the innovations framework
youth_justification: youth issues have not been addressed  specifically in the innovations framework
capdev_justification: Framework is introduced in several training s and shared in fora; and also preliminary evidence is introduced and shared.
climate_justification: ed by CIAT, methodology to assess sustainability (which is related to CC) of food systems in country is developed and published: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305750X18303115

outcome_sumary:
The first strategic step - an
 internal discussion paper prepared by the Global Alliance for Improved
 Nutrition (GAIN) included a SWOT analysis and recommendations for systematic
 approaches to engaging the private sector as a flagship and within focus
 countries. Consequently, A4NH adjusted its collaboration with GAIN to work
 with country teams, like GAIN-Bangladesh alongside the Scaling up Nutrition Business
 Network Platform. 
 
 Public-private partnerships in other
 countries are ongoing on a smaller scale with: UNILEVER on sustainable
 nutrition (Vietnam); Friesland Campina on fortification of milk products; a
 local broadcasting company (Ethiopia); and informal fruit and vegetable
 market retailers (Vietnam, Nigeria).
milestone_evidence: The Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN) completed an internal strategic planning paper, which included recommendations for systematic approaches to engaging the private sector. In response, we decided that it was inappropriate to implement a full strategic road map or systematic approach for the flagship or in the focus countries.
gender_justification: gender was not specigically targeted in identifying bottlenecks for public-private collaboration
youth_justification: youthwas not specigically targeted in identifying bottlenecks for public-private collaboration
capdev_justification: experience on public-private patnerships was disseminated and included in training
climate_justification: Project with CCAFS was specifically focussed on sustainability

outcome_sumary:
Information on dietary gaps and trends were widely disseminated through
(inter)national seminars and conferences and in-country stakeholder workshops.
Information on dietary gaps will be included in the country briefs. The food
systems narratives paper was highly appreciated by partners. This paper did not
include the view of the private sector; a first attempt to address this was
done in Vietnam. Policy baselines studies contributed to understanding around
food systems and sustainability. Key platforms were identified; collaborative
activities started in Vietnam and in Bangladesh via membership in key technical
working groups and the Scaling Up Nutrition Civil and Business Networks.
milestone_evidence:
Data
on dietary gaps and dietary trends were presented and discussed with partners relevant
for policy development: in Ethiopia (Ethiopian
Public Health Institute, Alive & Thrive, Addis Ababa University), in
Vietnam (National Institute for Nutrition, UNICEF, World Bank, Scaling Up
Nutrition, civil society alliances, NGOs,government in
Vietnam; in
Nigeria (University of Ibadan); and in Bangladesh (ICDDR'B)
gender_justification: data were presented disaggegrated by gender
youth_justification: data were presented disaggrgated by youth
capdev_justification: dietary gap analysis has been disseminated and used in training
climate_justification: sustainability of current and future diets have been addressed

Analysis of current narratives on food systems and sustainability was published. Further research on private sector narratives in Vietnam is ongoing. Progress was made on the national food system policy baseline assessments: Vietnam (completed and Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development added it to their library); Nigeria (completed); Bangladesh (validated); Ethiopia (ongoing).Update: This is
 ready for Vietnam and Bangladesh, but not yet for Nigeria (report is being
 finalised now) and Ethiopia (study is delayed due to Covid-19).
gender_justification: No specific gender analysis was done
youth_justification: No specific youth analysis was done
capdev_justification: Methodology for the food system policy baseline assessments was shared in the focus countries as part of the ongoing engagement.

milestone_evidence:
A4NH researchers developed a methodology for participatory scenario analysis related to food systems. The methodology was tested during a 3-week training course on food systems. Training sessions for Bangladesh and Nigeria on how to use the methodology were not scheduled in 2019, but will be conducted in 2020.Update: Change
 of positions delayed the finalisation of the food system analysis paper
 (necessary to continue participatory scenario analysis); new partner (IFPRI)
 was introduced and developed a proposal for the participatory scenario
 session, but circumstances beyond control did prevent the session to take
 place at the end of 2019. Was postponed to early 2020 but got delayed again
 due to COVID-19.

youth_justification: Youth is not an explicit focus of the scenario analysis.
capdev_justification: Training users in Bangladesh and Nigeria on how to use the methodology will be the major focus of this activity in 2020.
climate_justification: Sustainability is an important topic in the scenario analysis.

Findings provided basis for another 2019 milestone.

outcome_sumary:
1. In
sub-Saharan Africa, a total of 87,378 metric tons of certified
seed of CIMMYT- and IITA-derived stress tolerant maize varieties produced
and marketed by seed companies to farmers.2. CIMMYT executed improved maize variety licensing agreements with 41 different
partners (37 private/parastatal, 4 public) granting licenses to
register/commercialize 47 unique maize hybrids across 34 different countries in
sub-Saharan Africa.3. Five new CIMMYT-derived elite
maize hybrids (three lowland tropical, one highland and one subtropical) were licensed
for commercialization by seven seed companies.4. Two lowland tropical maize
hybrids were licensed for
commercialization in Colombia and Guatemala.5. 15 elite drought-tolerant maize hybrids, derived by CIMMYT-Asia, licensed
to 14 seed company partners in Asia.6. Eight new
multiple stress tolerant and nutritious CIMMYT hybrids for eastern
and southern Africa formally announced through CIMMYT and MAIZE CRP websites
for licensing to partners across sub-Saharan Africa.7. Six new CIMMYT-derived
heat-tolerant maize hybrids formally
announced through CIMMYT/MAIZE websites for licensing to partners in South
Asia. Nine commercialization licenses signed with various seed
company partners.8. 16 new CIMMYT maize hybrids released in Asia in 2019, including 10 in Pakistan,
1 in India, 2 in Bangladesh, and 3 in Sri Lanka.
milestone_evidence:
MAIZE varietal release map in 2019 MAIZE Annual Report

Certified seed production information of CIMMYT-/IITA-derived
maize varieties received from MAIZE partners in SSA, Asia and LatAm 

Licensing agreements with seed company partners in SSA, Asia
and Latin America

Agro-dealer Survey in target countries, such as Tanzania & Uganda
gender_justification: Not specifically targeted
capdev_justification: Capacity of SME seed companies enhanced, for commercializing improved maize varieties in Africa, Asia and LatAm.
climate_justification: Most of the CGIAR-derived maize varieties deployed through partnerships were climate-resilient.

outcome_sumary:
1. Based on certified seed production data in 2019,MAIZE estimates that in SSA, CIMMYT-/IITA-derived new maize
varieties were planted on a total of 3.93
million hectares, benefiting 6.73
million households which translates to 40
million people. See Table 1A.

2. Mexico, 2019: CIMMYT-derived improved maize varieties
were estimated to be adopted by at least 290,000
households and grown on 1.11 million
hectares.

3. Pilot marketing in India of over 60 tons of a drought-tolerant maize hybrids (AAA
Project).4. 177 tons of
certified seed of CIMMYT-derived heat-tolerant maize hybrids was produced
and commercialized by seed companies in Bangladesh, India and Nepal.5. In
SSA, 44 new stress tolerant and
nutritious CIMMYT/IITA-derived maize varieties were officially released for further commercialization.6. Top 5 CIMMYT-derived maize hybrids
accounted for 56% of the seed company
portfolio sales in Mexico. 7. In Nepal, local seed production of Rampur Hybrid-10, a heat tolerant CIMMYT-derived maize hybrid, was
formalized, a major step towards maize hybrid seed self-sufficiency in
the country.8. Training on “Maize
Seed Systems Research and Seed Production” was held at ICRISAT campus on 4-5 December 2019; attended by 55 participants from 27 public & private
institutions from India, Nepal, Malaysia, and Sri Lanka
gender_justification: Not specifically targeted
capdev_justification: Significant focus on CapDev of NARS and SME seed companies.
climate_justification: Improved maize germplasm with climate resilience is developed and disseminated.

youth_justification: Youth targeted for adoption of climate-resilient maize varieties, and for CapDev activities.

outcome_sumary:
The
four key milestones for this outcome focused on tools, approaches, and capacity
enhancement leading to the development of back end tools and services to
leverage data for analysis and visualization. Progress on all milestones was strong. A prototype data analytics environment, Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG
Labs) was developed, with Globus software allowing sharing of sensitive data.
CGlabs enables researcher collaboration and access via a Single Sign-On (SSO);
a search of GARDIAN data; dataset download to CG Labs; secure data upload and
sharing via Globus; and collaborative development of analytics and crop models
in Python and R. Jupyter notebook was implemented as a machine learning platform as part of CG Labs, and a collaboration with UC Davis resulted in tools for finding, cleaning, and processing data to enable machine learning applications. Three use cases were developed to design analytics
pipelines involving development of model-ready data from GARDIAN for
crop and new trait prediction models, and facilitating aggregation of datasets for
analysis. Collaborators at the University of Florida's Agricultural Model
Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) successfully tested an API to
develop DSSAT model-ready datasets from GARDIAN. Several data science workshops and webinars provided backstopping for
these efforts.
milestone_evidence: A prototype data analytics environment, Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG Labs) was developed and made available in 2019. CG Labs includes an implementation of Globus software that allows sharing and transfer of sensitive (and non-sensitive) data. CGlabs enables researcher collaboration via Slack-like functionality, and once a user is logged in via a Single Sign-On (SSO), s/he can perform a search over GARDIAN data; download datasets to CG Labs; securely upload and share data via Globus; and collaborate on writing and running analytics and crop models in Python and R. The R-WOFOST model is currently implemented and the DSSAT model will soon be available. Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG Labs) is currently being tested by researchers at CGIAR and other institutions who require several TB, large CPU, and uninterrupted long-timeframe data processing.
gender_justification: The gender dimension is not inherently applicable to this milestone.
youth_justification: The gender dimension is not inherently applicable to this milestone.
capdev_justification: Effective use of data and associated analytics is fueld by a strong focus on capacity development.
climate_justification: Improved analytics are focused on targeted technology development and improving forecasting of climate change impacts.

outcome_sumary:
The
four key milestones for this outcome focused on tools, approaches, and capacity
enhancement leading to the development of back end tools and services to
leverage data for analysis and visualization. Progress on all milestones was strong. A prototype data analytics environment, Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG
Labs) was developed, with Globus software allowing sharing of sensitive data.
CGlabs enables researcher collaboration and access via a Single Sign-On (SSO);
a search of GARDIAN data; dataset download to CG Labs; secure data upload and
sharing via Globus; and collaborative development of analytics and crop models
in Python and R. Jupyter notebook was implemented as a machine learning platform as part of CG Labs, and a collaboration with UC Davis resulted in tools for finding, cleaning, and processing data to enable machine learning applications. Three use cases were developed to design analytics
pipelines involving development of model-ready data from GARDIAN for
crop and new trait prediction models, and facilitating aggregation of datasets for
analysis. Collaborators at the University of Florida's Agricultural Model
Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) successfully tested an API to
develop DSSAT model-ready datasets from GARDIAN. Several data science workshops and webinars provided backstopping for
these efforts.
milestone_evidence:
Two use cases were
developed to design and test data interoperability and analytics pipelines. The first involves the development of model-ready data from GARDIAN for crop and
new trait prediction models, and required extension of data translation tools from
the Agriculture Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) for use
in GARDIAN so that selected datasets can be translated to AgMIP format. Development of standard unit conversion
utilities was expanded to include all units found in a subset of GARDIAN datasets used for testing.
Existing AgMIP data translation tools were extended to formats encountered in
sample GARDIAN datasets, resulting in the release of an updated data translator
to generate harmonized AgMIP-format files from GARDIAN data. A third use case
focused on developing methods to enhance the ability to derive insights from large data pools, improving our ability to derive insight from data; for example, understanding the drivers of variation in crop response to fertilizer in Sub-Saharan Africa.
gender_justification: The gender dimension is not inherently applicable to this milestone.
youth_justification: The youth dimension is not inherently applicable to this milestone.
capdev_justification: Effective use of data and associated analytics is driven by a strong focus on capacity development.
climate_justification: Improved analytics and the use cases piloted for the data analytics environment are focused on targeted technology development and  improving forecasting of climate change impacts.

outcome_sumary:
The
four key milestones for this outcome focused on tools, approaches, and capacity
enhancement leading to the development of back end tools and services to
leverage data for analysis and visualization. Progress on all milestones was strong. A prototype data analytics environment, Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG
Labs) was developed, with Globus software allowing sharing of sensitive data.
CGlabs enables researcher collaboration and access via a Single Sign-On (SSO);
a search of GARDIAN data; dataset download to CG Labs; secure data upload and
sharing via Globus; and collaborative development of analytics and crop models
in Python and R. Jupyter notebook was implemented as a machine learning platform as part of CG Labs, and a collaboration with UC Davis resulted in tools for finding, cleaning, and processing data to enable machine learning applications. Three use cases were developed to design analytics
pipelines involving development of model-ready data from GARDIAN for
crop and new trait prediction models, and facilitating aggregation of datasets for
analysis. Collaborators at the University of Florida's Agricultural Model
Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) successfully tested an API to
develop DSSAT model-ready datasets from GARDIAN. Several data science workshops and webinars provided backstopping for
these efforts.
milestone_evidence:
The
ability to apply machine learning techniques depends on the availability of
large data pools for these scripts to operate on. Thus, one of the Organize
Module's activities centered on creating workflows to download, standardize and
aggregate research data for use and new discovery of insights through machine
learning. The UC Davis collaboration resulted in R scripts that allow data
compiling, processing, and aggregation of large numbers of standardized
datasets for machines to operate on. Further, in recognition of the need for a
central environment through which to access and deploy these techniques,
Jupyter Labs was customized and implemented as a machine learning platform
seamlessly integrated with GARDIAN CG Labs. Lastly, IRRI's Farm Household
Survey Database was adapted to be fully machine readable, with over 100 surveys
annotated and further curation continuing in an Amazon Web Services S3 bucketas the Socioeconomic Ontology
matures and can be used for annotation. These will be shared for a machine
learning annotation project through the Convene Module's Socioeconomic Data
community of practice.

milestone_evidence:
Collaborators at the University of
Florida's AgMIP project developed minimum data criteria requirements for the DSSAT model, mapped the
AgMIP data dictionary (ICASA variables) to the Agronomy Ontology (AgrO), and
successfully tested an API to identify GARDIAN datasets meeting minimum data criteria and with data variables that could be mapped to AgrO.
AgMIP translation tools were further extended to read the datasets found in
GARDIAN, and allow users to download data in these formats for easy integration
into DSSAT. A collaboration with researchers at UC Davis resulted in the
articulation of a viable use case that would power the development ofand R library for processing
and cleaning data to enable aggregation of a large number of datasets from
GARDIAN.

outcome_sumary: The Organize Module launched GARDIAN (Global Agricultural Research Data Innovation and Acceleration Network) in 2019, developed on the 2018 pan-CGIAR portal (CeRES). GARDIAN facilitates the discovery of CGIAR data and publications with tools for data visualization and back-end services to accommodate data privacy, ethics, and clarity on licensing. As a global knowledge base for agriculture, it enables discovery of over 155,000 publications and 23,000 datasets, including from all CGIAR Centers and partners (USAID, UKAid, the World Bank and others). Through Organize Module support, almost 1000 datasets were curated and uploaded to Center repositories, well over the minimum 150 dataset target, and these are discoverable via GARDIAN. Although the number of uploads per Center varied, 13 Centers reported workshops to help researchers standardize data and metadata through annotation with accepted standards prior to upload. An API-key and support for harvesting GARDIAN FAIR scores was provided to MARLO, which makes about 70 API calls per month. GARDIAN is more than a data discovery portal -- it is a data ecosystem that also enables reuse of CGIAR data via interactive visualizations (e.g, crop production estimates, 7TB CMIP5 climate dataset), a collaborative analytics platform, and seamless model pipelines, all backed by secure data transfer.
milestone_evidence: GARDIAN released a containerized, easily deployable personally-identifiable information (PII) detection service for Centers as one part of a FAIRification workflow to help CGIAR and partner institutions. This is a step to minimize risks for the CGIAR System related to unintentional disclosure of PII, and was tested by the Alliance Bioversity-CIAT, ICRISAT, and IITA. Other parts of the FAIR workflow include the ability to easily annotate data with semantic standards and the CG Core metadata, and seamless upload to institutional repositories. These pieces of the workflow have been developed and tested in 2019, but required refinement and will be released in early 2020. The GARDIAN team provided technical guidance and/or APIs to make Center/CRP data assets discoverable through GARDIAN to several Centers (e.g. IRRI, ICRISAT, IWMI) and worked with others to test and refine the PII service. In 2019 GARDIAN indexed assets from 5 large repositories in 2019, including those of the World Bank, USAID, DFID, USDA, and the Government of India, and now indexes about 155,000 publications and 23,000 datasets.
gender_justification: GARDIAN's automated PII service provides alerts to the presence of personal information, allowing masking to protect at-risk female subjects.
youth_justification: GARDIAN's automated PII service provides alerts to the presence of personal information, allowing masking to protect young subjects.
capdev_justification: Effective use of the PII service and associated features is fueled by capacity development efforts.
climate_justification: Inclusion of data assets across CGIAR and its partners provides a large one-stop knowledge base for climate change research.

An API-key and support for harvesting GARDIAN FAIR scores was provided to MARLO, which makes about 70 API calls per month. GARDIAN is more than a data discovery portal -- it is a data ecosystem that also enables reuse of CGIAR data via interactive visualizations (e.g, crop production estimates, 7TB CMIP5 climate dataset), a collaborative analytics platform, and seamless model pipelines, all backed by secure data transfer.
milestone_evidence: GARDIAN took a big step towards becoming the definitive agricultural data resource in 2019, with an almost 10-fold increase in datasets and publications made discoverable between December 2018 and 2019. These assets are from CGIAR repositories and from other important agricultural data sources, recognizing that CGIAR scientists need relevant data wherever it resides, in the consistent and standardized format that GARDIAN provides. With support from the Organize Module, several Centers were able to implement the latest version of the CG Core metadata schema, and most Centers made strong progress in 2019 on enriching metadata associated with data and publications, and applying semantic standards across all assets -- making them easy to discover and interpret, and rendering them more actionable by machine-based techniques to demonstrate value.
gender_justification: Efforts were made to enhance annotation standards to reveal the gender dimension of data assets.
youth_justification: Efforts were made to enhance annotation standards to reveal the youth dimension of data assets.
capdev_justification: Effective use of the quality, annotated assets available via GARDIAN is backstopped by capacity development.
climate_justification: Increasing the number of well-annotated data assets across CGIAR and its partners provides a large one-stop knowledge base for climate change research.

GARDIAN is more than a data discovery portal -- it is a data ecosystem that also enables reuse of CGIAR data via interactive visualizations (e.g, crop production estimates, 7TB CMIP5 climate dataset), a collaborative analytics platform, and seamless model pipelines, all backed by secure data transfer.
milestone_evidence: User testing and alignment of the COPO data annotation tool with GARDIAN functionalities was coordinated by the Organize Module with Alliance Bioversity-CIAT, which also contributed substantial staff time to this effort. COPO is now fully responsive to the newest version of the CG Core Metadata Schema, having been further tested by data and information managers during the CoP annual meeting, held during the Platform Convention in October 2019, and refined by December 2019. Supported by Organize, CIP, the Alliance, and IFPRI also created a release of the Agronomy Field Information Management System (AgroFIMS) with help from CIMMYT, IITA, Rothamsted Research, UC Davis, and University of Florida researchers. AgroFIMS is another "expert tool" which automatically annotates data with semantic standards and conforms to the CG Core schema at the collection stage.
gender_justification: Improved annotation via an easy-to-use tool illuminates the gender dimension of CGIAR data assets.
youth_justification: Improved annotation via an easy-to-use tool illuminates the youth dimension of CGIAR data assets.
capdev_justification: User-responsive enhancement and wide uptake of the annotation tool is fueled by capacity development efforts.
climate_justification: Improved annotation via an easy-to-use tool creates a wider data pool and easier derivation of climate change insights.

GARDIAN facilitates the discovery of CGIAR data and publications with tools for data visualization and back-end services to accommodate data privacy, ethics, and clarity on licensing. Although the number of uploads per Center varied, 13 Centers reported workshops to help researchers standardize data and metadata through annotation with accepted standards prior to upload. GARDIAN is more than a data discovery portal -- it is a data ecosystem that also enables reuse of CGIAR data via interactive visualizations (e.g, crop production estimates, 7TB CMIP5 climate dataset), a collaborative analytics platform, and seamless model pipelines, all backed by secure data transfer.
milestone_evidence: In 2019 the Organize Module tested data mining of GARDIAN towards applying machine learning on large pools of data. The Module worked with the University of Florida's AgMIP team which first mapped and adapted their model data dictionary (ICASA variables) to relevant ontologies, harmonizing GARDIAN annotations to AgMIP format. Auto-generated harmonized datasets are made available for input to the DSSAT crop model. The UC Davis team identified and applied an approach to harmonize key data variables and apply machine learning and spatial approaches to analyze a large number of datasets from GARDIAN, with a high-value publication envisioned. IWMI is in the process of reorganizing its data warehouse and implemnting the CG Core v.2.0 for enhanced data discovery. Similarly, IRRI's Farm Household Survey Database has been adapted to be fully machine readable, with 99 surveys annotated to render them findable via GARDIAN. Other social science survey datasets from IRRI are currently awaiting curation using the Socioeconomics Ontology in development by the Socioeconomics Development Community of Practice of the Convene module. These will also be shared for a machine learning annotation project through the CoP. IWMI began improving its metadata workflows, and WorldFish began development of a Fish Ontology for improved annotation.
gender_justification: Improved metadata and data discovery enables improves the derivation of gender-related insights from CGIAR data assets via text-mining and machine learning technologies.
youth_justification: Improved metadata and data discovery enables improves the ability to derive youth-related insights from CGIAR data assets via text-mining and machine learning technologies.
capdev_justification: No capacity development dimension inherent to this milestone.
climate_justification: Improved metadata and data discovery enables improves the ability to derive insights related to climate change and technology targeting from CGIAR data assets via text-mining and machine learning technologies.

outcome_sumary:
The
Organize Module continued to support the development of tools and services to allow easy annotation of information resources across CGIAR. The Module promoted the implementation of the CG Core Metadata
Schema v. 2.0, providing support to the pan-CGIAR Metadata Working Group led by
the Alliance Bioversity-CIAT. Organize also convened several meetings and work
sessions to customize the COPO tool with the CG Core schema, to enhance its
ontology annotation capabilities, and made it available to for Centers to test
in 2019. Employing COPO will allow Centers to easily use metadata and semantic
standards to annotate data, publications and other resources. The Agronomy
Field Information Management System (AgroFIMS) was released in 2019. AgroFIMS
produces field book templates for collection of data fromagronomy trials. These field
books contain semantically enabled, standards-compliant metadata and data
variables (including standardized column headings within data sets).
milestone_evidence: The Organize Module continued to support Center adoption of the CG Core Metadata Schema v.2.0 in a variety of ways, including facilitating the Metadata Working Group's active engagement around the schema, and collaborative fine-tuning to further improve it. The schema was uploaded to GitHub for easy access with robust documentation, and an application profile to enable clarity on terms and facilitate use. The Module provided support for further development of the COPO annotation tool to fully align with the CG Core v.2.0, allowing easier and wider use of the schema to describe publications, data, and other information resources. Almost all CGIAR Centers are now implementing the newest version of the CG Core, and several are testing COPO for suitability with their data management workflows. IWMI began a data reorganization and metadata review in 2019, developing tools to map metadata from one format to another to facilitate adherence to the CG Core Metadata Schema.
gender_justification: Initial discussions inititated on how the CG Core Metadata Schema could contribute to enhancing our ability to derive gender-related insights from CGIAR data assets.
youth_justification: Initial discussions inititated on how the CG Core Metadata Schema could contribute to enhancing our ability to derive youth-related insights from CGIAR data assets.
capdev_justification: User-responsive enhancement and wide uptake of the CG Core Metadata Schema fueled by capacity development efforts.
climate_justification: Consistent use of the improved CG Core Metadata Schema enhances our ability to more effectively mine CGIAR data assets for insights on climate change.

milestone_evidence: The Agronomy Ontology is available for wide download and deployment via a GitHub agrisemantics collection, and users can also find information on it via the CGIAR Platform for Big Data in Agriculture website. The Agronomy Field Information Management System (AgroFIMS) v.1.0 based on AgrO and other ontologies was released at the end of 2019. It reliably allows the digital collection of semantically standardized data through the KDSmart app via smartphone or tablet, allowing the data to be checked for consistency in the field (via heat mapping). Data values can be validated once exported back to AgroFIMS, which also allows the user to perform statistical analyses on the collected data, generating reports that can be excerpted into reports, publications etc. A workshop was organized in 2019 with agronomists and developers from CIP, the Alliance, IFPRI, Ontocale Inc., Diversity Arrays Inc., CIMMYT, IITA, Rothamsted, and the University of Florida to test improved features of AgroFIMS and led to the design of more features. Testing sessions were held during the Big Data Convention at ICRISAT and individually with interested agronomists at IRRI and AfricaRice. A user-manual was created and published and is also available on AgroFIMS website.
gender_justification: There is no inherent gender dimension to AgroFIMS.
youth_justification: There is no inherent youth dimension to AgroFIMS.
capdev_justification: Wide uptake of AgroFIMS is driven by strong capacity development efforts.
climate_justification: Use of AgroFIMS generates standards-compliant data, enhancing our ability to more effectively mine CGIAR data assets and apply big data techniques for insights on climate change.

milestone_evidence:
In
2019 the Organize Module facilitated collaboration on an ontology tool
developed by the GEMS team, along with support for data and information
specialists via trainings, webinars, and coordinated user testing to
demonstrate the value and use of ontologies and controlled vocabularies in
annotating data assets. Almost all Centers report using AGROVOC (controlled
vocabulary) in 2019 in repository metadata fields; several also report using
terms from the Crop, Agronomy (maintained by the Alliance Bioversity-CIAT with
support from Organize) and other ontologies, among them the Alliance, IITA,
IRRI, IWMI, CIMMYT, and CIP. The use of ontology concepts to describe variables
in datasets for enhanced interpretability and interoperability remains rarer,
with progress made by the Alliance, CIP, IITA, and IRRI. IRRI continued work to
enhance the Rice Ontology in 2019, by adding/mapping terms in IRRI 
SNP-Seek, B4R (EBS) databases and in Agroportal. Additionally, IRRI's UAV controlled
vocabulary terms were shared with the Ontologies CoP, and a pilot database
management system for UAV images and metadata was developed for automated
high-throughput phenotyping. IWMI's 2019 data reorganization and metadata
review also incorporated terminology from existing ontologies, and data
managers are considering how metadata forms may eventually verify matches
between user input terms and ontologies.
gender_justification: AGROVOC includes gender terms, initial discussions inititated on how ontology improvement might contribute our ability to derive gender-related insights from CGIAR data assets.
youth_justification: AGROVOC includes youth terms; need to assess how ontologies can help researchers derive youth-related insights from CGIAR data assets.
capdev_justification: Consistent and appropriate use of ontologies requires strong capacity development efforts.
climate_justification: Consistent use of ontologies generates standards-compliant data, enhancing our ability to more effectively mine CGIAR data assets and apply big data techniques for insights on climate change.

milestone_evidence: The Organize Module provided in-kind and funding support to create the semantic web-based CGIAR Expert Finder, enabling CGIAR to showcase its research and researcher. The Module also supported the the Ontology Working Group and CoP in enhancing crop and other ontologies and in engaging with Research Data Alliance (RDA) agrisemantics efforts. CGIAR agrisemantics efforts were consolidated in one GitHub location for easy and organized access by users; the site includes links to the Agronomy Ontology and the in-development Socioeconomic Ontology. Module support also enabled a data curathon organized by IRRI to present development of the Rice Ontology and the CGCore Metadata Schema, with reference and application materials made accessible to IRRI staff working on data and/or databases. With support from Organize, a Bioversity-based team continued collaborations with the Environment Ontology, Food Ontology, SDG Interface Ontology, and Planteome Project teams, and attended the 2019 Plant and Animal Genomics Conference, interacting with the Excellence in Breeding and Integrated Breeding Platforms and the Planteome Project. CGIAR's agrisemantics efforts were represented by Bioversity-based staff at the SWAT4LS Conference organized by GODAN, and the Module continued engaging with CABI, FAO, CTA, and GODAN on issues focused on agrisemantics and capacity development around FAIR data.
gender_justification: There is no inherent gender dimension to this milestone.
youth_justification: There is no inherent youth dimension to this milestone.
capdev_justification: Consistent and appropriate use of agrisemantics and efforts to avoid unnecesary duplication require strong capacity development and outreach efforts
climate_justification: There is no inherent climate change dimension to this milestone.

outcome_sumary:
Enabling
CGIAR to move further and faster towards Open, FAIR, and ethical data
management necessitates enhanced capacity and culture change -- fueled by the
provision of services, tools, and support to ease transition. Throughout 2019
the Organize Module supported the development of tools and guides covering best
practices in managing for open, FAIR, and ethical data assets, and for data processing.
Module funds were used by Centers for data sprints to promote standards-based
data annotation and upload to repositories. Module-facilitated webinars were
organized, and an online interactive course on data management best practices
developed for deployment in 2020. To assure that capacity development solutions
meet real needs the Module organized user workshops, including to enhance the
COPO annotation tool with Alliance data and information specialists, and COPO/Earlham
Institute, GARDIAN, and University of Florida/AgMIP developers. COPO and
AgroFIMS needs were also assessed through larger user workshops. Several regional
workshops were held (at CIMMYT, CIP, ICRISAT, and IFPRI) to enhance CGIAR's
data science and machine-learning capabilities. The GARDIAN team provided
technical guidance and/or APIs to make Center/CRP data assets discoverable (e.g. to IRRI, IITA, ICRISAT, IWMI). An API-key and support for
harvesting GARDIAN FAIR scores was provided and is used by MARLO.
milestone_evidence:
The
Organize and Convene Modules organized several webinars towards open, FAIR and
ethical data assets, and facilitated Centers in supporting their research
communities in a variety of ways. A multi-module online and interactive course
was developed, and will be deployed in 2020 to provide tools and knowledge to
help researchers and data/information managers use best practices in ethically
managing data assets towards open and FAIR. Guidance  was made available via GARDIAN to help data managers improve the FAIRness of data assets, and presented during the Platform's 2019 Convention. ILRI organized presentations by
scientists and others on 'the power of open - inspiring stories and discussion'
(e.g. mobile phone-based surveillance systems, making ILRI code open, open data
for decision-making etc.). Several Centers including the Alliance, CIP, ILRI,
and IITA developed domain-specific guidance on best practices in managing data
for their researchers, often involving researcher-data champions. Through
Organize Module collaboration with UC Davis, regional workshops were held at CIMMYT, CIP, ICRISAT,
and IFPRI to enhance CGIAR's capabilities in data science-related topics
including advanced R, spatial predictive modeling, and machine learning,
and a data wrangling/processing guide produced and made available as a
"living document" that continues to be enhanced.
gender_justification: There is no inherent gender dimension to this milestone.
youth_justification: There is no inherent youth dimension to this milestone.
capdev_justification: All activities towards achieving this milestone are focused on capacity development.
climate_justification: There is no inherent climate change dimension to this milestone.

milestone_evidence: Facilitated by the Organize Module, Centers creatively and enthusiastically engaged researchers on data annotation and management efforts in 2019 - through data sprints, data clinics, hackathons, "curathons", and other training modalities. The Alliance Bioversity-CIAT held 3 trainings on data management planning across all CIAT regions to ensure that researchers use good data practices from project inception, while Bioversity-based staff participated in data sprint activities. ILRI organized help-desks and data clinics, and disseminated guidance on how to 'be open' across different knowledge products. IRRI organized4 training courses on RDM 101 (Basic Research Management), incorporating FAIR as well as OA/OD -- with seventy-six persons participants in total. Additionally, a data sprint was conducted at IRRI for about 20 key scientists involved in data and databases. IITA launched a massive campaign in 2019 across hubs on best practices for data quality in projects. CIFOR embedded data teams into projects to promote good data management planning, development and curation.CIMMYT data management staff worked with all stakeholders including key data stewards to promote good data management. Two hackathons were organized by ICRISAT (India) and one in Ethiopia for the ESA and WCA regions, with four digitization and data management trainings also conducted for breeding programs.

youth_justification: There is no inherent youth dimension to this milestone.
capdev_justification: All activities towards achieving this milestone are focused on capacity development.

milestone_evidence: The Module organized a workshop to enhance the COPO annotation tool involving Alliance data and information specialists, and COPO/Earlham Institute, GARDIAN, and University of Florida/AgMIP developers. An online and in-person training (at the Platform's 2019 Convention) was held for data managers and ontology specialists to familiarize themselves with the COPO data annotation tool. Likewise, an AgroFIMS user workshop involving Alliance ontology experts, developers from CIP and IFPRI, and researchers from multiple Centers and partners (CIMMYT, IITA, Rothamsted Research, University of Florida, Diversity Arrays Inc., and Ontocale Inc.) allowed researchers to test AgroFIMS' FAIR data workflows, and provide input to refine them. The Organize Module also facilitated researcher-focused regional workshops to enhance CGIAR's data science and machine-learning capabilities; these were held at CIMMYT, CIP, ICRISAT, and IFPRI and covered advanced R, spatial predictive modeling, and machine learning.

outcome_sumary: Gender and social inclusion is well embedded in FP4. First from an analytical point of view in CoA 4.1 (see i.e FACASI publication and reports). Form a participatory point view, proper attention is given to farmers diversity in all our on-going project (CoA4.2) and also embedded in our scaling approaches (CoA4.4)
milestone_evidence: Our farm mechanization portfolio continues to include strong gender and social inclusion components. FACASI project in ESA has provided clear evidences on the positive impact of access to mechanization on rural women and children livelihood components and those benefits are clearly imbedded in our scaling strategy. In Bangladesh similar gender and social inclusion components are documented in M&E of CSISA-MI project which has reached already a large number of beneficiaries. Our work on promoting service provision for farm mechanization also open opportunities for rural entrepreneurs and youth.
gender_justification: Mechanization is transformative in many small holder farming systems alleviating significant labor burden traditionally exectued by woman and childeren
youth_justification: Opportunities for rural youth to engage in service provision, businesses
capdev_justification: Not targeted but benefiting from that work
climate_justification: Not targeted but benefiting from that work

outcome_sumary: All W3/bilateral projects currently mapped to FP4 continued to target higher adoption of SI practices by farmers directly involved in those projects but also by additional farmers beyond the immediate reach of the projects through development stakeholder involvements and refined scaling strategy (Co4.4)
milestone_evidence: At the time of filling this, it seems there is only 1 contribution entered in MARLO by PL while there has been much more published work under CoA4.1. See links to evidence below... Some of the SI work was refocused on integrated approach to managed fall armyworm (FAW)
gender_justification: SI practices promoted are done through a gender lens
youth_justification: mechanization present new business opportunities for rural youth
capdev_justification: capacity of farmers are enhanced

outcome_sumary: Our farm mechanization portfolio continues to include strong gender and social inclusion components. FACASI project in ESA has provided clear evidences on the positive impact of access to mechanization on rural women and children livelihood components and those benefits are clearly imbedded in our scaling strategy. In Bangladesh similar gender and social inclusion components are documented in M&E of CSISA-MI project which has reached already a large number of beneficiaries. Our work on promoting service provision for farm mechanization also open opportunities for rural entrepreneurs and youth. Also refer to MasAgro portfolio in Mexico which has developed a series of private sector collaboration including responsible sourcing schemes.
milestone_evidence: 2019 work performed under Co4.4 has been reaching milestones beyond expectations, raising interest of several key stakeholders and financial partners (IFAD, BMZ, USAID, IDRC, CRS, sister CG institutes ) laying some key principles for a scaling paradigm shift
gender_justification: but gender integration benefiting from the work
capdev_justification: indirectly benefiting
climate_justification: indirectly benefiting

In Bangladesh CSISA-MI have notably expended they reach to small service providers using 2 WT. CSISA-MI was funded last year and will further focus on private sector contribution ustream of farm service provision.
milestone_evidence: Large impact of private sector engagement in mechanisation in South Asia presently documented. Responsible sourcing work is further developing in Mexico

outcome_sumary: Big Data Platform open, collaborative communities of practice grew to over 5,000 members and they curated open technical tracks at the annual Big Data in Agriculture Convention (with over 700 mostly external attendees and a media reach of several million views of print, online, and television media).   The Platform launched new collaborative research and events with Cambridge University and the Partnership on AI (a membership organization comprised of the major IT firms, researchers, startups, and civil society groups working on ethical AI) specifically on emerging topics and managing systemic risks to food security.
milestone_evidence: High-level 2019 Convention on Big Data in Agriculture, with wide participation of CGIAR and non-CGIAR actors, was held from 16-18 October in Hyderabad, India, hosted by ICRISAT. The Convention had over 700 mostly external attendees and a media reach of several million views of print, online, and television media.  The Youth in Data initiative entered its second year as an explicit strategy to engage young reporters and data scientists in digital agriculture.
gender_justification: Ratios of male and female attendance and speakers in the Convention was measured, with the aim that each year we can make these ratios more equal.
youth_justification: For the second year of our annual Youth in Data Workshop, we received over 80 applications to participate and enrolled 30 delegates to participate in the 2019 Convention. This event builds on the launch of our new BIG DATA youth initiatives, as we work to engage youth in digital agriculture, and to engage with youth already in the sector, in a meaningful way.  The 2019 Youth in Data group was composed of students from enginering and journalism universities local to Hyderabad, as well as PhD scholars from the ICRISAT campus.
capdev_justification: Convention contributes to CapDev of both CGIAR and Non-CGIAR actors, and the establishment of collaborate agreements.
climate_justification: NA

gender_justification: Key research topic of the Socio-Economic Data CoP.
capdev_justification: All CoPs distribute newsletters, organize webinars, etc.

outcome_sumary: The Platform launched new collaborative research and events with Cambridge University and the Partnership on AI (a membership organization comprised of the major IT firms, researchers, startups, and civil society groups working on ethical AI) specifically on emerging topics and managing systemic risks to food security. Big Data Platform open, collaborative communities of practice grew to over 5,000 members and they curated open technical tracks at the annual Big Data in Agriculture Convention.
milestone_evidence: 1) New set of MetGrid files and CLI files sets, 2) Interactive map for visualizing the simulations of different G x M options in all grids of rabi sorghum regions in India and 3) Aggregate dataset on crop stage and growth, created from cellphone images of over 30,000 wheat farmers. Dataset for Crop Monitoring Using Smartphone Based Near-Surface Remote Sensing: Ground Pictures of Wheat and Auxiliary Data from Northern India (This is a processed dataset of approximately 20,000 near-surface remote sensing images acquired using inexpensive smartphones within the context of a picture-based insurance (PBI) initiative of 1,685 smallholder farmers ﬁelds in northwest India). Spatial Production Allocation Model (SPAM 2015): the team processed subnational statistics data covering 28 priority countries in sub-Saharan Africa Asia, LAC, and Europe, but there are still 105 more countries to process. Currently, our tentative target date for release is December 2020. While continue working on MapSPAM 2015. Update to MapSPAM 2010, Version 1.1, on October 9, 2019.
gender_justification: Map of factors important for studying women's economic empowerment
capdev_justification: New methods for socioeconomic research.
climate_justification: The Spatial Production Allocation Model is a key dataset enabling climate adaptation research.

outcome_sumary: As a result of a pan-CGIAR assessment of the state of digital strategy in the organization, 7 Centers worked with Big Data Platform to begin or enhance their Center-level digital strategies.  The Platform Coordinator presented progress on pan-CGIAR digital strategy to the System Management Board and the Platform was tasked with developing a digital strategy in light of the 2030 plan.    The Platform conducted co-design workshops across Centers and domains to develop a more unified information vision for the organization and has begun to apply this to prioritize digital investments, such as in shared services.  This design outputs were presented to partners and CGIAR participants at the Big Data in Agriculture Convention.Big Data and Gender Platforms spearheaded a new method for leveraging mobile phone network metadata to study the spatial extent and changes in key factors related to women's economic empowerment, with plans to mainstream this method in the organization.

This design outputs were presented to partners and CGIAR participants at the Big Data in Agriculture Convention.

capdev_justification: Building unified infrastructure vision and investments builds our big data capacity as an organization.

outcome_sumary: As a result of a pan-CGIAR assessment of the state of digital strategy in the organization, 7 Centers worked with Big Data Platform to begin or enhance their Center-level digital strategies.  The Platform Coordinator presented progress on pan-CGIAR digital strategy to the System Management Board and the Platform was tasked with developing a digital strategy in light of the 2030 plan.    The Platform conducted co-design workshops across Centers and domains to develop a more unified information vision for the organization and has begun to apply this to prioritize digital investments, such as in shared services.  This design outputs were presented to partners and CGIAR participants at the Big Data in Agriculture Convention.Big Data and Gender Platforms spearheaded a new method for leveraging mobile phone network metadata to study the spatial extent and changes in key factors related to women's economic empowerment, with plans to mainstream this method in the organization.
milestone_evidence: The main platform mechanisms for monitoring and building capacity are technical communities of practice (who implement webinars throughout the year and curate technical tracks of the annual Convention).   This culminates in a final work plan for the the CoP developed late in the calendar year, in time for including in the next year's Plan of Work and Budget
gender_justification: Collaborative research with the gender platform includes knowledge exchange on data science methods
youth_justification: The Youth in Data initiative engages young data scientists across CGIAR and the wider sector.
capdev_justification: Monitoring capacity is a key part of our CapDev activities.
climate_justification: Applied data science activities are directly relevant to core research areas including climate adaptation

outcome_sumary: M3 has built a portfolio of 14 projects to date demonstrating research innovations and new pathways to data-driven impact for CGIAR. For example: a successful pilot of machine-learning enabling seed selection is being leverages for in-field seed and fertilizer recommendations in Mexico and East and Southern Africa, linking back to genetic resources in a CGIAR seedbank. A system leveraging free wifi to track informal food flows has been adopted by the Government of Vietnam to diagnose and predict COVID-19 related food security shocks (58% of users are women). A method levering mobile telephone network data has has proven more accurate than weather stations and CHIRPS in some circumstances in measuring rainfall. A farmer-to-farmer social network linked to ILRI researchers led to significant improvement in dairy practices. 33,000 wheat farmers in India found they improved risk management and had increased willingness to pay for a mobile phone-based advisory and insurance product.
milestone_evidence: The pilots were implemented in 2019.
gender_justification: Over 50 percent of users are women across these services and research innovations.
youth_justification: User bases skewed young in those instances where measured.
capdev_justification: CGIAR capacity to apply data-driven solutions has increased
climate_justification: Enhanced rainfall prediction, better than station-based and in some cases better than CHIRPS

gender_justification: Over 50% female user base in big data supported services

outcome_sumary:
Introduction
of technical innovations developed in RICE has shown yield increase in
Benin, Brazil, India, Madagascar, Nigeria, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, and Vietnam. The following are key highlights:

- Randomized
control trial in northern Nigeria showed that use of RiceAdvice had 15 % higher
yields and 20 % higher profits.

- On-farm
trial in Tanzania showed that P micro-dosing increased grain yield of
dry-seeded, dibbled rice by 26%.

- Compared
to the farmers’ own practices, yield increases of 1 to 2.7 t/ha were achieved
when following GAP in Tanzania.

- Adoption
of smart-valley increased yield by 0.9 t/ha in Benin and Togo.

- Introduction
of Good Agricultural Practices in Madagascar increased the yield from 2.2
t/ha to 3.2 t/ha in uplands, and from 4.1 t/ha to 7.5 t/ha in irrigated
lowlands. In Uganda, GAP increased the yield from 3 t/ha to 6 t/ha under
irrigated lowlands.

- In
Brazil, The Latin American Fund for Irrigated Rice (FLAR) demonstrated 19%
yield increase with introduction of improved management practices.

- In
Vietnam, introduction of labor-saving technologies together with 1 Must do and
5 Reductions increased rice yield by 10%.

- In
Indica, use of Rice Crop Manager had higher yield than farmers’ practices.
milestone_evidence: Introduction of technical innovations developed in RICE CRP has shown >10% yield increase in 8 countries including Benin, Brazil, India, Madagascar, Nigeria, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, and Vietnam.
gender_justification: In case for RiceAdvice, we tried to increase number of female service providers who can easily access to female farmers.
capdev_justification: Introduction of innovations requires training to service providers and/or farmers who participated in demonstration.
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Sustainable
Rice Platform Performance indicators (v2) were released in Jan 2019. IRRI and
AfricaRice contributed to this revision. Some of indicators related to
input use efficiencies were assessed for improved practices in sub-Saharan
Africa (as review), and 7 countries including Benin, Côte d'Ivoire, Madagascar,
Senegal, Tanzania, and Vietnam. 



- Agronomic
efficiency of Phosphorus micro-dosing was assessed in Benin and Tanzania.

- Water
productivity and nitrogen use efficiency of alternate wetting and drying with
different N fertilizer levels were assessed in Senegal.

- N
use efficiency for rice production in sub-Saharan Africa were reviewed.

- On-farm
demonstration showed that Alternate wetting and drying (AWD) increased water
productivity by 20% without yield penalty in Côte d'Ivoire.

- N
and P use efficiencies were assessed in long-term trial in Senegal.

- Introduction
of labor-saving technologies together with 1M5R in
“Small farmers, large field” in Vietnam reduced seed rate by 45 kg/ha and
pesticide use by 50%, and increased rice yield by 10%, resulting in an increase
in farmer income by 20-30%.

- In
central highlands of Madagascar, A prototype of WeRise was developed and
piloted in 80 farmers’ fields in 2019-2020 wet season to assess its impact on
yield and fertilizer use efficiency.
milestone_evidence: Performance indicators related to input use efficiencies were assessed for improved practices in sub-Saharan Africa (as review), and 7 countries including Benin, Côte d'Ivoire, Madagascar, Senegal, Tanzania, and Vietnam.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: introduction of innovations for improving input use efficiency required training to service providers and/or farmers who participated in demonstration.
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Farm
diversification studies were conducted in 6 countries. Following are major progress. 



- Water
productivity and profit of four off-season vegetable crops and their residual
effect on rice was assessed in farmers’ fields in Côte d’Ivoire.

- Environmental
sustainability (soil, weeds, pests), resilience to climate change, and
productivity of different upland cropping systems were assessed in Côte
d’Ivoire.

- Phenology
and productivity of 52 crop-variety combinations were assessed in
Senegal. 50 farmers including 31 female farmers were invited to evaluate them
in a field day.

- Phenology
and productivity of 14 rice-vegetable/legume combinations (12 vegetable and
legume spp.) and their residual effect on rice were assessed in Madagascar.

- Stylosanthes
guianensis showed superior P uptake by 10- to 26- fold relative to the other
major crops (rice, maize, and soybean) in Madagascar.

- Multiple-purpose
services in diversifying upland rice-based cropping systems, including protein
supply for human and livestock as well as market (pulses), pest control,
nutrient supply to soils, and rice productivity enhancement were assessed in
Madagascar.

- Potential
benefits of rice-fish systems were reviewed for Myanmar.

- Community water management, new rice varieties, and diversification options increased
agricultural production in the polders of the coastal zone of Bangladesh.
milestone_evidence: Farm diversification studies were conducted in 6 countries including Bangladesh, Côte d’Ivoire, Madagascar, Myanmar, and Senegal to assess impact of the farm diversification options on multidimensional benefits.
gender_justification: We especially focus on female farmers involvement in selection of new options in Madagascar and Senegal.
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
2019
milestone was changed to “Linkage of farm diversification with on-farm diet
diversity assessed, and strategies developed to enhance on-farm diet diversity
through diversification” in POBW 2019, that was not reflected in MALRO system.

- On-farm
survey for assessing linkage of farm diversification with on-farm diet
diversity was initiated in Nigeria, Rwanda, and Senegal. Preliminary analysis
in Rwanda found positive relationships between diversification and nutritional
outcomes. Thus, development and dissemination of crop diversification options
including vegetables and legumes might be an effective strategy for
diversifying farmers’ diets thereby contributing significantly to improved
nutrition.

- Adaptive
research on diversified cropping system in Bangladesh- Improvement in household
nutrition due to the introduction of biofortified zinc rice, sunflower, and
maize. Sunflower, as a dry season crop, is gaining popularity not only for its
resilience but also its high acceptance as edible oil from the farmers' own
farm. The community used maize grains and leaves as the feed for their poultry,
livestock, and fish leading to households having more access to milk, meat,
egg, and fish that can help improve the nutrition of the polder communities.
milestone_evidence: Research on linkage between farm diversification and on-farm diets were conducted in four countries in Bangladesh, Nigeria, Rwanda, and Senegal. Project reports are available in below links.
gender_justification: Gender specialist is leading this on-farm survey, and gender research areas (women status and empowerment) were incorporated into this on-farm survey.
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: Impact of crop management practices on GHG emissions assessed in three key action sites consisting of (i) Eastern India, (ii) Mekong delta, Vietnam, and (iii) northern Vietnam.- On-farm assessment of different rice crop management practices in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam showed that improved - practices including alternate wetting and drying (AWD) water management reduced GHG emissions by 39%.- IRRI and its partners assessed crop establishment methods in rice production systems of Eastern India. Direct seeded rice reduced GHG emissions by 17% in comparison with conventional transplanting.- In northern Vietnam, on-farm experiments showed early plus midseason drainage reduced GWP by 42–66% than continuous flooding.
milestone_evidence: Improved crop and water management practices reduced GHG emission by at least 17% at three action sites.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: Main focus is on reduction of GHG emissions

outcome_sumary:
2019
milestone was changed to “In collaboration with the Sustainable Rice Platform,
multidimensional sustainability indicators validated at four action sites” in
POBW 2019, that was not reflected in MALRO system.

- Data
on performance indicators for sustainable rice cultivation were collected and
analyzed from seven Asian countries Vietnam, Thailand, India, Indonesia,
Myanmar, Sri Lanka, and China.

- In
Africa, data on Sustainable Rice Platform Standard/Performance Indicators were
collected in Burkina Faso, Ghana, Nigeria, Senegal, and Tanzania, and key
intervention areas for improving sustainable rice cultivation were identified. Data
collection tool for Sustainable Rice Platform Standard/Performance Indicators
were developed using Survey Solutions, and data collection was initiated in
Côte d'Ivoire, Nigeria, and Senegal.
milestone_evidence: Data on performance indicators for sustainable rice cultivation were collected and analyzed from seven Asian countries  and five African countries.
gender_justification: SRP indicators/standard include gender issues such as women empowerment.
youth_justification: SRP indicators/standard include youth issues such as child labor, education, and hazardous work.
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: SRP indicators/standard include climate change issues such as estimation of GHG.

outcome_sumary:
2019
milestone was changed to "two action sites" only in
POBW 2019, that was not reflected in MALRO system. Following is major progress in this outcome.- Motorized
weeder and drum seeder were tested in Côte d’Ivoire.

- Prototype
fertiseeder was developed tested. The fertiseeder was modified based on the
suggestions of the farmers and tested in Madagascar.

- In
Vietnam and Cambodia, laser leveling has been extensively demonstrated and
services are provided by government institution.

- Women
entrepreneurs in agricultural mechanization was developed in Bangladesh. The
landless poor who used to harvest paddy manually were provided services on
harvesting paddy by reaper leading to improved livelihoods with higher income (USD392-503
per year) than before (USD45-114 per year).
milestone_evidence: Prototype labor-saving technologies were tested in three Asian (Bangladesh. Cambodia, and Vietnam). and two African countries (Côte d’Ivoire, and Madagascar)
gender_justification: The fertiseeder was modified based on female/male farmers’ feedback. Labor-saving technologies focus on improvement of female farmers labor productivity.
capdev_justification: More than 300 farmers received instruction on how to use  fertiseeder.
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: This outcome was removed from FP3 two years ago but still features in MARLO. We'll try to remove it again in 2020.
milestone_evidence: This milestone was removed from FP3 two years ago but still features in MARLO. We'll try to remove it again in 2020.
other_reason: This whole outcome was removed from FP3 two years ago but still feautures in MARLO. We'll try to remove it again in 2020
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: For the year 2019, progress was achieved toward this outcome by establishing 28 Antennae panel (AP) and 13 Reference panel (RP) sites with the global Rice Array phenotyping network by all contributing centers: IRRI, CIAT, CIRAD, AfricaRice, covering various sites in the 3 continents. Also, 48 datasets from 27 different sites including soil/climate data were curated and annotated (this is a 70% of the sites). Additionally, the 3000 rice genome metadata was used to identify genomic regions that affect community assembly for Phytobiomes. Some delays and funding constraints delayed trials at sites in China and grain quality analyses for trials from three Philippine and one Myanmar site were planned but could not be done. Change of staff and some adverse climatic conditions affected establishing trials in some sites. But we are actively finding new partners and trial sites for GRA.
milestone_evidence: Defined array and reference panels; first panels grown at platform sites. From this and other milestones, it can be evidenced that the panels have been trialed and data collection has been ongoing from various sites. The milestone will be completed by 2020.
gender_justification: field trials involving rice genotyes
capdev_justification: not at this stage, centers already skilled
climate_justification: rice panels in multi-environments to identify tolerant varieties to different stresses to adapt to climate change

outcome_sumary: Progress toward this outcome was through Drone-based high-throughput phenotyping (HTP) platforms in various centers and locations. It was conducted for the antennae panel in Philippines, India, Columbia, and Cote d’Ivoire. Also, image processing and HTP+manual data was collated at IRRI and CIAT. CIAT also continued work on the Pheno i platform, that integrates drone and satellite images.Plant phenotyping capacities were upgraded in Cote d’Ivoire and Senegal by rehabilitating field sites for the evaluation of Fe-toxicity and salinity. A drone-based phenotyping platform were established to monitor field trials in Cote d’Ivoire and Senegal), as well as hardware equipment for image-data storage, processing and analysis at AfricaRice.Establishing drone-based phenotyping at 2 locations in India (Titabar and Maruteru) was unsuccessful due to reduced staff and partner interest. Training workshops and visits to partner sites were not possible due to lack of funding. Delays in hardware acquisition continued to stall image processing and field surveying activities by other partners. Use of drone in Cote d’Ivoire was hampered by bird attacks.
milestone_evidence: Existence of phenotyping platforms, phenotype genotype protocols available, data available for multiple sites, reports. THe milestone was extended due to financial cuts and personnel reduction that were assigned to the task, therefore the expected time of completion is now 2021.
gender_justification: field trials involving rice genotyes
capdev_justification: training and knowledge transfer to equip partners wit the skills to collect data and run the platforms
climate_justification: not at this stage
