milestone_evidence: Phenotyping facilities and network up and running, new High Throughput Phenoptyping platforms established, efficient reporting and mechanisms/tools are in place. Innovations with links reported in this AR19 (Image controlled vocabulary, image drone database). Courses in drone use for agriculture available in IRRI Education.
gender_justification: phenotyping platform development and implementation
capdev_justification: training and knowledge transfer to equip partners wit the skills to collect data and run the platforms
climate_justification: not at this stage

outcome_sumary: Some tools were developed to be able to diagnose various pests and diseases. Additionally, research advances brought new information that will contribute to tackling others. For example, a new diagnostic multiplex PCR assay was refined using AfricaRice’s strains collection, together with partners. Pathotracer continued with the input of new data and the portal is ready for testing. Pathotracer involves a network of NAREs in-charge of sampling and monitoring the results. In 2019, 10 institutes in 7 countries began using Pathotracer and will generate feedback necessary for scaling up in the future. Another development was new data collection from trials and site testing, new allele discovery and tolerant varieties were discovered, activities that advanced research on Blast,Rice Yellow mottle virus (RYMV), Rice Stripe Necrosis Virus, Pantoea blights and  Bacterial leaf blight.PhD students and on-the-job trainees were involved in the rice array data curation and analyses and a PhD from AfricaRice visited China to develop her skills to identify blast resistance genes.The loss of AfricaRice’s pathologist in mid-2019 has affected continuation of activities.
milestone_evidence: A new diagnostic multiplex Polymerase Chain Reaction assay was refined using AfricaRice’s strains collection with private partners to potentially discriminate multiple pathogens. Pathotracer is being tested by partners to improve performance and get it ready for uptake.
gender_justification: tool development and implementation
capdev_justification: students and partners were trained in tools and techniques toward pest disease analysis and tolerance.
climate_justification: not at this stage

outcome_sumary: For this outcome, in 2019 48 datasets of phenotypic and genotypic data from the Antennae Panel and Reference Panel were curated. This data was made available from 27 sites, distributed in 3 continents. Additionally, data from various sites was corrected for spatial effects using experimental design and climate data.
milestone_evidence: Existence of data gathering, sharing and analysis tools: phenotype and genotype analysis platforms available, reports. The milestone was not completed due to financial shortcomings, involving personnel reductions, but it is expected to be completed by the end of 2021.
gender_justification: data hub development and implementation
capdev_justification: not at this stage
climate_justification: data hub development and implementation

outcome_sumary: The Rice Functional Genomics and Breeding (RFGB) database v2.0 was updated with improved functionality over the previous database. The latest version includes new features that allow the uploading of genotypic data and the linking of the genotyped line directly to seed accessions in the genebank to place a seed request. This database is used by researchers (for example breeders or molecular biologists) and other partners that work in the improvement of varieties.Also, genotype by environment (G x E) imputation was implemented and GWAS tools were deployed in Rice Galaxy.
milestone_evidence: The database is a research initiative now ready for the next user as detailed in the MARLO OICR with the same title (link below). Access by external users is already available following the links provided below, in which breeders have updated their breeding pipelines by using information contained in the database.
gender_justification: tool development
capdev_justification: students and OJTs were trained for development skills on data curation.
climate_justification: tool development

outcome_sumary:
During 2019, FP4 has implemented two major insurance products reaching
over 11,000 farmers in Bihar, India and Gaibhanda, Bangladesh, with the former
providing payouts to 45% of women beneficiaries. Through several mechanisms the
project obtained feedback from more than 40,000 farmers, on access and use of
insurance in the context of post-flood management. The flagship provided
guidance to inform the initiative on “Scaling Up Access to Insurance, Markets,
Finance, and Productive Safety Nets,” under the Global Commission on Adaptation
Action Track on Food Security and Rural Livelihoods.
milestone_evidence:
IWMI flood insurance project in South Asia expanded to two major
insurance products, including strategy to reach marginal farmers, reaching over
11,000 farmers. Flood insurance pilot in Bangladesh adopted by Green Delta
insurance company.





Contribution
to strategies for adoption through review of added value of science in
developing cost-effective agricultural insurance in global insurance project.
Collaboration by global insurance project and flagship leader project with
Dutch Research Council (NWO) on insurance in Uganda which included a gendered
risk spectrum analysis
gender_justification: Flood insurance project (P1607) intends to promote social equity (including gender) and reduce the constraints women’s access to insurance and climate information and promote overall women’s adaptive capacity. Collaboration with NWO project includes gender analysis.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Support climate change adaptation through improved access to insurance.

outcome_sumary:
FP4
 contributed to improved services by a range of climate service and insurance
 providers. In Senegal, CCAFS worked with USAID, public and private partners
 to develop business models to sustain successful dissemination of weather and
 climate information, via SMS and voice messages, to 356,000 farmers and
 fisherfolk. In Rwanda district agricultural officers used climate Maprooms to
 identify and distribute hybrid maize seed suitable to local conditions to
 87,872 farmers, and to provide supplemental irrigation water to protect
 against anticipated dry spells. Work with climate information providers
 contributed to adoption of improved objective climate forecasting and
 agricultural Maproom tools by the Intergovernmental Authority on Drought and
 Development Climate Prediction and Applications Centre (ICPAC) (East Africa),
 and meteorological services of Rwanda, Ethiopia, Bangladesh, Colombia,
 Guatemala and Ethiopia. Climate service delivery expanded in Latin America
 through 26 new Local Technical Agroclimatic Committees (LTACs); and in Rwanda
 through PICSA. Digital climate service outcomes included the launch of
 Digital Agroclimate Advisory Platform in Ethiopia; adoption of AgCelerant
 platform in Islamic Development Bank programs targeting 2 million hectares
 and 10 countries in West Africa; and Indian government request to scale up
 Intelligent Systems Advisory Tool. Insurance work contributed to adoption of
 flood insurance in five districts in Bangladesh, and strengthening of Africa
 farmer insurance programs, and African Risk Capacity sovereign insurance.
milestone_evidence:
In South Asia a flood insurance project was adopted by insurer, Monetary
Financial Institutions (MFIs), and local communities for implementation in five
districts in Hoar region in Bangladesh.





In
Cascaid 2.0 project in Ethiopia, training and support was delivered for the use
of CCAFS Regional Agricultural Forecasting Tool (CRAFT) tool.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: Capacity development though regional policy consultations in South Asia and training in Ethiopia on CRAFT tool.
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

milestone_evidence:
Through a Flagship Leader project, East Africa regional climate center
(ICPAC) shifted to flexible forecast format. ACToday/Columbia University
extended Maproom tools to National Meteorological Services (NMS) of Ethiopia,
Senegal, Colombia and Bangladesh.





In
Latin America, climate services were scaled-up through 26 LTACs in six
countries, promoting climate information in 300 institutions. Secretariat of
Food and Nutritional Security (SESAN) in Guatemala is using CCAFS tools.





National-level
Digital Agro-climate Advisory Platform launched in Ethiopia, led by Ethiopian
Institute of Agricultural Research, with Ministry of Agriculture and NMS. Climate
information developed/disseminated with Ethiopia’s National Meteorological
Agency and private sector (Jokalante and Meteo MBay in Senegal), and climate
services dissemination plan in place with regional climate center (AGRYMET),
and three national institutions in Niger. In Rwanda, expanded Maproom products
and other tools through NMS being used; climate services delivered to three new
districts; and climate services adopted by District Agronomists (Local
Government Ministry).





CCAFS
developed and deployed an agro-meteorological advisory system with three
national institutions in India.





In
Vietnam, climate services included in Ha Tinh Farmers' Union five-year plan,
and provincial hydro-met center now applies seasonal forecasting method in
Vietnam. In Southeast Asia, LTACs introduced in three countries with Regional
Integrated Multi-Hazard Early Warning
gender_justification: Gender integrated into LTAC manual
capdev_justification: Trainings provided as part of many of these projects, including for ICPAC  in previous years, LTACs in Latin America,  and Rwanda, among others.
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

outcome_sumary:
FP4
 activities across several projects provided direct or indirect guidance to
 climate service investors at national, regional, and global level. A series
 of trainings for senior officials with the India National Bank for
 Agriculture and Rural Development, and other private banks, cooperative
 banks, and other stakeholders, underpinned the development of new strategies
 that include addressing climate risk and digital innovation in their
 respective investment portfolios. Work undertaken jointly between FP4 and
 East Africa Regional Program led to new publications providing evidence of
 wide economic benefit of climate services in Ethiopia. Significant new
 investment from DFID (c. USD 3.7 million) under the Weather and Climate
 Information and Services for Africa (WISER) program, and contributing to the Climate
 Research for Development (CR4D)-Africa portfolio, draw on design and implementation
 support from FP4, together with East Africa Regional Program engagement. FP4
 engagement with the Global Commission on Adaptation has consisted of
 provision of a climate services background paper, and co-leading of the
 initiative on Climate Informed Digital Agricultural Advisory Services under
 the Action Track on Food Security and Rural Livelihoods. Major funding
 commitments to the action track were announced in 2019, but expected funding
 for the digital advisory theme is yet to be specified.
milestone_evidence:
Flagship leader project conducted significant engagement with the Global
Commission on Adaptation.







 In Vietnam, the Department of Crop Production
is utilizing Climate-Smart Mapping and Adaptation Planning (CS-MAP) and
requested CCAFS for the development of CS-MAP for the Red River Delta and South
Central Coast.







Trainings
with National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development in India, who then commissioned
trainings for officials from other private banks, cooperative banks, NGOs, etc.
took place.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: Trainings with National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) in India,
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

milestone_evidence:
CCAFS engagement influenced a substantial investment in climate services
through the CR4D-Africa program, managed by the African Climate Policy Centre (ACPC).






In
2019, DFID, through the WISER program, invested GBP 2,847k (c. USD 3,680k) in a
small research grant program under CR4D. ACPC and DFID jointly developed the
principles for the WISER-funded CR4D grant mechanism. Flagship 4 played a major
role in the initial development of CR4D, and continued to engage through the
East Africa Regional Program. Although plans to engage USAID East Africa office
on lessons and opportunities, and efforts to engage ACPC's cost-benefit work
under WISER through a joint methodology workshop were unfortunately not
successful, FP4 support for the CR4D program provided an alternative means to
influence investment in African climate services.

capdev_justification: N/A

milestone_evidence:
Journal article on economy-wide cost-benefit analysis in Ethiopia by
flagship leader and East Africa regional project.





Continued
engagement with USAID to shape investments in climate services by flagship
leader project. Nevertheless, efforts to
secure IFPRI commitment to expand its work on climate service cost-benefit
analysis, and potentially expand to other regions, were not successful.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

outcome_sumary:
FP4 projects have increased awareness and affected policy regarding
gender sensitive climate services for development organizations throughout
South and Southeast Asia, Africa, and Latin America during 2019. In Rwanda, the
PICSA training process has specifically targeted female participation,
resulting in nearly equal participation by gender. In Latin America,
gender-tailoring of climate services has been achieved, working with farmer
organizations engaged with the CCAFS supported programs. FP4 has supported a
gender and climate services postdoctoral scientist, who has contributed to
guidance and outreach supporting gender-sensitive integrated climate services
in Guatemala, Uganda, and Rwanda. Prior and current CCAFS projects in Southeast
Asia have engaged development organizations, including GIZ and the African
Development Bank, in promoting gender sensitive climate services, which has
been incorporated into their current programs in Vietnam and Myanmar.
milestone_evidence:
In Rwanda climate services project, four Caritas NGOs that supported
PICSA training for Twigire Muhenzi extension staff and volunteer Farmer
Promoters have been proactive in promoting women's participation.





In
Guatemala, at least one women-focused farmer organizations is now providing
digitally integrated and gender-sensitive climate information to its farmers.





Flagship
leader project informed gender-sensitive M&E strategy for ACToday, and
engaged project partners in Uganda through the Dutch Research Council (NWO)
project.









In
Southeast Asia, guidance materials are directly informing the GIZ
SIPA/EbA-project in Ha Tinh and the Canada/Asian Development Bank-funded
project component on agroclimate advisories for MOALI, implemented by the International
Centre for Environmental Management in Myanmar.
gender_justification: In Rwanda, Farmer Promoters have been proactive in promoting women's participation in various ways. With their facilitation, the proportion of male and female farmers who participated in PICSA was nearly equal. Latin America project had several explicit activities regarding gender, including working with women-focused farmer organization and a training manual for Guatemalan institutions to support gender-sensitive CSA interventions. In Southeast Asia, activities continuing from earlier project continued to address scaling with a diversity of end users in the climate services value chains.
youth_justification: Some of the trainings in Rwanda targeted youth through Rwanda Youth in Agribusiness Forum (RYAF).
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

outcome_sumary:
FP4 projects have influenced policy implemented during 2019 in Latin
America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. The Ministry of Food Security of Guatemala
is promoting innovations in food and nutrition security in the country,
including national funding, for work piloted in collaboration with FP4. In Rwanda,
the proposal for a National Framework for Climate Services has been endorsed,
and is under development, with FP4 project support. The Rwanda project team has
co-led planning for a policy dialogue targeting activities to sustain project
innovations. The Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources has taken action
to advance a national agricultural insurance strategy. FP4 in collaboration
with IRI ACToday has influenced two policy processes in Ethiopia—the National
Framework for Climate Services, and the National Adaptation Plan. Also, the
collaboration fostered a policy dialogue in Vietnam.
milestone_evidence:
In Guatemala, SESAN is pushing forward the political support for the
food security monitoring and information system across the government.





In
Rwanda, National Framework for Climate Services (NFCS) endorsed and under
development with project support, not yet finalized or ratified. Engaged Rwanda
Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources decision-makers around national
agricultural insurance strategy.





In
Ethiopia, NFCS drafted with CCAFS and IRI support, endorsed at a national level
by several government institutions, awaiting formal ratification.





In
Nigeria, public-private partnership to transform Nigeria’s agricultural sector
through AgCelerant, which is an advanced value chain orchestration and business
development ecosystem connecting smallholders with credit, insurance, input and
output markets. ICRISAT has formally joined the partnership.





In
Latin America, the Climate Outlook Forum of the SICA region developed a
mechanism to articulate their discussions on the agricultural sector adapting
the LTAC concept in order to be able to feed the LTACs in different countries.
gender_justification: N/A
youth_justification: Promotion of youth entrepreneurship a key tenet of Cascaid 2.0 project in Africa.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. The Ministry of Food Security of Guatemala

including national funding, for work piloted in collaboration with FP4. In Rwanda,
the proposal for a National Framework for Climate Services has been endorsed,
and is under development, with FP4 project support. The Rwanda project team has

innovations. The Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources has taken action
to advance a national agricultural insurance strategy. FP4 in collaboration
with IRI ACToday has influenced two policy processes in Ethiopia—the National

milestone_evidence:
Milestone was envisioned to be completed by 2021 so it has been
extended. In 2019, progress included: ACToday collaboration with CCAFS,
facilitated by the flagship leader, influenced two policy processes in Ethiopia,
and fostered policy dialog in Vietnam. Flagship Leader contributed indirectly
by supporting launch of portfolio of FP4 projects that aim to influence at
least 11 policy decisions in 2019–2021.
other_reason: Milestone was envisioned to be completed by 2021.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Support for climate change adaptation through climate services.

outcome_sumary:
In CoA 5.1 (Harnessing genetic diversity),
screening and validation experiments using germplasm panels and populations
resulted in the discovery of novel donors and genomic regions associated with
anaerobic germination (AG), stagnant flooding (SF), grain Zn content, sheath
blight tolerance, and drought/direct seeded rice (DSR). Several publications
are nearing submission. From a DSR trial, 50 potential donors have been
selected for gap analysis with DST elite lines and a Backcross isogennic line (BIL) (rufipogon x indica)
was selected for use in the stress breeding program.
milestone_evidence: Identified donors and genomic regions associated with anaerobic germination, stagnant flooding, grain zinc and drought/direct seeded rice for 25% of the targets. Over 50% of the donors are from sequenced panels of germplasm (3K rice genomes and Aus panel). The use of these panels is reported to the Genebank Platform. Screened 250 accessions from the 3K panel for grain Zn concentrations and identified 2 potential new donors combining above-average yield with grain Zn concentrations >35 ppm. Developed genomic prediction (GP) model to estimate accessions grain Zn concentrations among the 3K accessions. •Identified a new sets of SNP markers diagnostic in indica x aus and japonica x aus breeding populations through GBS.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: See capdev activities reported in section 1.3: both short and long term training are provided
climate_justification: Target traits include those that render enhanced adaptation to climate change effects

outcome_sumary:
Mid 2019, we organized a workshop with contributions from the Excellence in Breeding platform to adapt our objectives and workplans to emerging insights on modernization of breeding programs, and to take into account the lessons learned from developing the 'Crops to end hunger' initiative. As a result, the original milestone (60 lines nominated for release with 15% higher yield and meeting national quality requirements) was changed into: Baseline genetic gain values established for major breeding sub programs. Genomic selection initiated; 20 10 lines nominated for release with 10 5% higher yield, and meeting national quality requirements, in intensive systems.FP5.3 (Intensive
Systems)continued its march to produce high yielding breeding material and
release it across target geographies. Thousands of new breeding lines were
generated and hundreds of more advanced lines were tested and advanced towards
variety release at IRRI, CIAT, and AfricaRice. Eight types of trials were sent to 15
countries, and included types were for Irrigated,
Rainfed, Upland topographical types, abiotic stresses such as cold tolerance,
salinity and flood tolerance, pest and disease tolerances for Blast, Brown
Plant Hopper and bacterial blight. For MET trials data has been analysed for
dry season and shared with all the collaborators.
milestone_evidence: Genetic gain for IRRI irrigated program estimated to be 5-12 k/ha/year and 45-40 k/ha/cycle. gBLUPs (Breeding values based on genomic selection) generated for thousands of lines across Asia and Africa. RUDhan1 and NSICRc580 released in Bangladesh and Philippines respectively. Near isogenic lines(NILs) for true blast resistance genes, Pii, Pi3, Pik, Pik-h, Pikp, Pi1, Pi7(t), Piz, Piz-5, Pi9(t), Pi12(t), Pish, were developed, and confirmed the genetic improvement of resistant by inoculation test with international standard differential blast isolates. To develop NILs for partial resistance genes (pi21 and PB1), hybrid populations (BC5F2 and BC6F2) were generated, and homozygote plants will be selected in 2020. The effect of actpk1 (loss-of-functional type of negative regulator for nitrogen uptake) were confirmed in the indica genetic background (IR64 and Sahel108). NILs (5 each in the IR 64 and Sahel108) were selected by whole genome survey.
gender_justification: Developing the historic baseline genetic gain does not involve gender issues
youth_justification: Developing the historic baseline genetic gain does not involve youth issues
capdev_justification: See capdev activities reported in section 1.3: both short and long term training are provided
climate_justification: Assesed germplasm include those that render enhanced adaptation to climate change effects

outcome_sumary:
Mid 2019, we organized a workshop with contributions from the Excellence in Breeding platform to adapt our objectives and workplans to emerging insights on modernization of breeding programs, and to take into account the lessons learned from developing the 'Crops to end hunger' initiative. As a result, the original milestone (Genes conferring tolerance of two of the relevant stresses in the three ecosystems combined in elite backgrounds initial elite lines nominated for release) was changed into: Baseline genetic gain values established for major breeding sub programs. Breeding panel evaluated to initiate genomic selection.Multiple breeding lines
were nominated in release pipelines or released as new varieties for countries
in South and South East Asia. Some of these include IR10F365 and IR13F265 for
flood prone areas in Philippines; IR13F115 and IR12F578 for flood prone areas
in Nepal, Bahuguni dhan 1 and 2 for flood and drought prone areas in Nepal and
Inpari 46 for rainfed lowland drought and coastal saline regions in Indonesia. IR13F265 is identified for
release in the Philippines. A focused breeding program for direct seeded rice is now operational at IRRI HQ. The rainfed breeding program is steadily moving
towards the Rapid Generation Advancement breeding method.
milestone_evidence: Standardized Rapid Generation Advancement - Line Stage Testing based genomic breeding pipeline. Rainfed Core Breeding Panel (RCP) (1.0) characterized and genotyped. Frequency of major genes determined.. Direct Seeded Rice program initiated and first version of the core panel constituted. Breeding lines for lowland systems (8 lines) and upland systems (6 lines) submitted for variety registration trials in Madagascar. 30 breeding lines evaluated under low-input conditions in the hilly region of Nepal. New donors with tolerance to Fe toxicity identified in Madagascar.
gender_justification: Developing the historic baseline genetic gain does not involve gender issues
youth_justification: Developing the historic baseline genetic gain does not involve youth issues
capdev_justification: See capdev activities reported in section 1.3: both short and long term training are provided
climate_justification: Assesed germplasm include those that render enhanced adaptation to climate change effects

outcome_sumary:
Mainstreaming
Zn in irrigated breeding targets was initiated. Zn content in the grain is a critical micronutrient for human
nutrition and has been progressed by identifying several new donors (Jamir,
UCP222) from the aus types that have much higher levels of zinc and increased
iron in the grain. GWAS identified peaks on Chr5, 7 & 9. Populations have
been developed and QTL validated. Common QTL on chromosome 5 was identified
consistently across different mapping populations. Several of the high Zn rice
varieties with up to 16 ppm have been released in Bangladesh and Indonesia.Pre-breeding for lowered glycemic index with
acceptable texture was initiated. Reliably generating rice varieties with low
glycaemic index (GI) is an important nutritional intervention given the high
rates of Type II diabetes incidences in Asia where rice is staple diet. We
integrated a genome-wide association study (GWAS) with a transcriptome-wide
association study (TWAS) to determine the genetic basis of the GI in rice. GWAS utilized 305 re-sequenced diverse indica panel
comprising ~2.4 million single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) enriched in
genic regions. A novel association signal was detected at a synonymous SNP in
exon 2 of LOC_Os05g03600 for intermediate-to-high GI phenotypic variation.
milestone_evidence: qZn QTL on chromosome 5 identified to confer high zinc in milled rice samples. Using traditional method, Zn levels were enhanced in the range between 19-24 ppm and several varieties (BRRI Dhan 62, BRRI Dhan 64, BRRI Dhan 72 and BRRI Dhan 74) have been released meeting the target criteria.
gender_justification: High zinc content is especially relevant for pregnant and lactating women and small children
capdev_justification: See capdev activities reported in section 1.3: both short and long term training are provided
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary:
Mid 2019, we organized a workshop with contributions from the Excellence in Breeding platform to adapt our objectives and workplans to emerging insights on modernization of breeding programs, and to take into account the lessons learned from developing the 'Crops to end hunger' initiative. As a result, the original milestone (Research initiatives on modern rice breeding technologies with evidence of direct response to demand of rice value chain stakeholders) was changed into: Standardized design and data collection management as well as defined standard operating procedures and mechanization for field trials.In FP 5.6 (Modernizing
rice breeding), Breeding4Rice is now part of the Enterprise Breeding
System. The system enables the use of standardized experiment designs and
facilitates the usage via workflow. The use of standardized trial experiment
models in experimental design allows the development and implementation of
semi-automatic experiment data analysis. 
During the year the design of the workflow and
models was completed. The development and implementation of the analysis
workflows will be completed by the end of Q2 2020. The analysis workflow is fully aligned with the
Unified Breeding Strategy that was created during 2019 at IRRI Rice Breeding
Platform.
milestone_evidence: Standard Operation Procedures (SOP) for B4R task management and data collection was created and authorized. SOP's were implemented and the monitoring of compliance started at IRRI headquarters and in Easter Southern Africa region. SOP creation for experiment creation and harvest data management was started.
gender_justification: The development of software, tools, procedures to manage information flow does not address gender issues
youth_justification: The development of software, tools, procedures to manage information flow does not address youth issues
capdev_justification: See capdev activities reported in section 1.3: both short and long term training are provided
climate_justification: The development of software, tools, procedures to manage information flow does not address climate change

outcome_sumary:
In 2019, three major international meetings all acknowledged the
importance of food safety and we presented and helped draft policy statements
for all three. We also co-authored two major policy documents on food safety
with the World Bank and Global Food Safety Partnership, emphasising informal
markets. We produced a large number of papers, briefs, presentations, reports
and videos, making stakeholders aware of our pro-poor risk-based approaches
milestone_evidence: Policy makers and partners in Cambodia and Vietnam who are part of a taskforce on food safety received training on food safety risk assessment and discussed food safety priorities and solutions based on research project findings. Their capacity has been improved in risk based-approach in managing food safety and intervention.
gender_justification: Prohs in food safety in Cambodia and Vietnam embraced a gender sensitive when designing studies and involving participants. We organised several gender training linked to food safety and livestock.
youth_justification: youth not targeted specifically but age considered with gender
capdev_justification: Purpose was to train Cambodian food safety task force in risk-based food safety management
climate_justification: Climate change was not specifically targeted in the courses or tools

milestone_evidence: ILRI and IFRPI researchers helped organize and participate at the conference including important plenary presentations and helped draft the policy statement developed by the conference. They also attended a follow up conference with WTO in Geneva.
gender_justification: summarises the links between foodborne disease, poor nutrition and inequity
youth_justification: mention of youth but not targeted
capdev_justification: several briefs on capacity development of consumers, policy makers and value chain actors
climate_justification: Climate change and its impact on food safety was also a topic presented in a key note at the conference

milestone_evidence: A workshop was held at ILRI Kenya organized by IFPRI and it was attended by important stakeholders from Kenya and stakeholders from Ghana joined virtually. IFPRI and ILRI researchers presented evidence on aflatoxin control and discussed with stakeholders.
gender_justification: considered but not systematically
capdev_justification: Information provided to stakeholders
climate_justification: Aflatoxins are a climate sensitive hazard

outcome_sumary:
Six new food safety projects in Ethiopia (3), Kenya, Burkina Faso
and Uganda are using tools for risk assessment and management developed under
A4NH. All have potential to improve food safety at scale. ILRI leads two and is
a partner in another. This is in addition to ongoing projects in Cambodia,
Kenya and India aiming to reach consumers at scale. The projects all focus on
informal markets but use different methods for incentivising and sustaining
change, reflecting the “three-legged stool” approach. New research
collaborations for wider impact were also established in 2019.
milestone_evidence:
The index was developed by a multidisciplinary team of experts led by Partnership
for Aflatoxin Control in Africa (PACA), in consultation with ILRI scientists,
with support from A4NH, and validated by African Union (AU) country member
states. ILRI supported training and is helping validate data.
gender_justification: Foodborne disease information is gender disagregated
youth_justification: Foodborne disease information is age disagregated
capdev_justification: Building capacity of national health systems and AU-IBAR
climate_justification: Includes aflatoxins a climate sensitive hazard

milestone_evidence:
In India, manuals were developed for training pig and dairy farmers and
training of trainers started; laboratories were also assessed. In Kenya we engaged
with policymakers over an upcoming randomized controlled trial for milk
vendors. Focus group discussions were held with vendors and gender sensitive
training materials prepared.
gender_justification: All training and information is gender sensitized.
youth_justification: youth are especially vulnerable to food borne disease and will benefit from safer food
capdev_justification: building capacity of traders and policymakers
climate_justification: no systematic inclusion of climate issues

Links to evidence describe activities in (1) Burkina Faso and Ethiopia; (2) Uganda; and (3) the new One Health Centre.
gender_justification: all projects have gender dimension beyond gender-disaggregated data
youth_justification: youth are included but not considered systematically

outcome_sumary: By the end of 2019, Aflasafe was registered in 9 African countries. To date, three companies and one government partner have been licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe products. Ministers from Mozambique and Tanzania endorsed Aflasafe; the Governments of Sudan and Togo requested technical support from IITA to develop Aflasafe products for their countries. The Governments of Burkina Faso and Ghana are rolling out national initiatives to raise awareness of and build capacity to control and mitigate aflatoxin. An external evaluation of Aflasafe in Nigeria concluded that sustainability depends on raising consumer demand for Aflasafe-treated maize, enforcing existing regulations, and increasing testing capacity.
milestone_evidence: In 2019, Aflasafe TZ01 and Aflasafe TZ02 were registered in Tanzania and Aflasafe MWMZ01 and Aflasafe MZ02 were registered in Mozambique. In 2018, Aflasafe ZM01 and Aflasafe ZM02 were registered in Zambia. To date, there are 9 African countries with 12 different registered Aflasafe products.
gender_justification: production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term
youth_justification: production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term
capdev_justification: IITA conducts field efficacy trials of Aflasafe alongside national partners, building research capacity. The trials are an important part of the process to prepare Aflasafe products for registration.
climate_justification: production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term

outcome_sumary: By the end of 2019, Aflasafe was registered in 9 African countries. To date, three companies and one government partner have been licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe products. Ministers from Mozambique and Tanzania endorsed Aflasafe; the Governments of Sudan and Togo requested technical support from IITA to develop Aflasafe products for their countries. The Governments of Burkina Faso and Ghana are rolling out national initiatives to raise awareness of and build capacity to control and mitigate aflatoxin. An external evaluation of Aflasafe in Nigeria concluded that sustainability depends on raising consumer demand for Aflasafe-treated maize, enforcing existing regulations, and increasing testing capacity.
milestone_evidence: A to Z Textile Mills Ltd. signed a technology and transfer licensing agreement in May 2019 licensing them to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe TZ01 in Tanzania. By December, their new manufacturing facility was nearly complete. In Ghana, Macrofertil Ltd. was appointed to distribute Aflasafe GH02; search is ongoing for manufacturing partner.
gender_justification: product licensing agreement did not include gender analysis
youth_justification: product licensing agreement did not include youth analysis or targeting
capdev_justification: As part of the Aflasafe technology transfer, IITA is working with A to Z to transfer the know-how about the technology and provides technical assistance in implementing the business plan. IITA’s support includes training the technical and sales staff on the integrity of the technology to increase their confidence during commercial deployment of this new-to-market product; providing technical assistance for structured awareness-raising and demonstration of the economic and social value of the product to different market segments using business cases; and support in setting up of their factory, quality control and the associated specialised staff training.
climate_justification: product licensing agreement did not include explicit consideration of climate change

outcome_sumary: By the end of 2019, Aflasafe was registered in 9 African countries. To date, three companies and one government partner have been licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe products. Ministers from Mozambique and Tanzania endorsed Aflasafe; the Governments of Sudan and Togo requested technical support from IITA to develop Aflasafe products for their countries. The Governments of Burkina Faso and Ghana are rolling out national initiatives to raise awareness of and build capacity to control and mitigate aflatoxin. An external evaluation of Aflasafe in Nigeria concluded that sustainability depends on raising consumer demand for Aflasafe-treated maize, enforcing existing regulations, and increasing testing capacity.
milestone_evidence:
The pilot has successfully
created a niche for Aflasafe™ treated maize, where buyers from supermarkets,
poultry feed market and export markets paid a premium. This AgResults blog describes the promising results from the external evaluation and includes a link to the full report. The AgResults Lessons Learned Briefs describe more.
gender_justification: Results from the Evaluation Final Report: Nigeria Aflasafe Challenge Project (p. 31-32) suggested that AgResults did not appear to stimulate gender inclusiveness. Three primary reasons were cited in the report as possible explanations for the low level of inclusion.
youth_justification: Results from the Evaluation Final Report: Nigeria Aflasafe Challenge Project (p. 31) concluded that in terms of inclusiveness, AgResults has stimulated the emergence of an AT/AC maize market that is inclusive of smallholder farmers. The project’s monitoring data indicate that a total of 13,372 farmers were producing for AgResults in year 3, with on average 2 ha under Aflasafe. The smallholder survey suggests that farmers in the program owned on average 5 ha of land, implying that the project did indeed reach smallholders.
capdev_justification: Major emphasis on considering capacity of organizations involved in Aflasafe scale out and their future training needs
climate_justification: Implications of climate change were considered in the AgResults approach, but it wasn't a focus of the project's aims nor considered in the evaluation..

outcome_sumary: Flagship 1 is collaborating with African and Asian countries to test and support implementation of innovative land and water policies and practices at scale. This includes mapping of, and public-private partnerships for scaling out and assessing the impact of, solar irrigation in Africa and Asia; mainstreaming solar power as a remunerative crop (SPaRC) in India; scaling out watershed innovations; mapping irrigation suitability in the Nile Basin; and demonstrating the potential of shallow groundwater for irrigation in Africa.
milestone_evidence: Continue to bring ALWM solutions piloted through demonstration projects in more than five countries to policy makers and practitioners, including (1) work on solar irrigation including development of solar suitability mapping tools (2) expansion of work on solar irrigation from India to new countries in South Asia; (3) outreach on solar technology. In addition, work to (4) investigate climate impacts on small scale irrigation, and groundwater availability and potential for irrigation expansion, and links to food security and nutrition were conducted in Ghana and Ethiopia, including (5) in Ethiopia how the potential for irrigated vegetable production could be increased and (6) how practices such as conservation agriculture can positively reinforce small scale irrigation efforts. Institutional aspects of AWLM were also investigated, through (7) work in Myanmar on water user associations and a strategic overview (8) of what it will take to expand small scale farmer irrigation in Africa.
gender_justification: Gender equality is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.
youth_justification: Youth is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.
capdev_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing CapDev.
climate_justification: Climate change is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.

outcome_sumary: Flagship 1 is collaborating with African and Asian countries to test and support implementation of innovative land and water policies and practices at scale. This includes mapping of, and public-private partnerships for scaling out and assessing the impact of, solar irrigation in Africa and Asia; mainstreaming solar power as a remunerative crop (SPaRC) in India; scaling out watershed innovations; mapping irrigation suitability in the Nile Basin; and demonstrating the potential of shallow groundwater for irrigation in Africa.
milestone_evidence: Results of land management strategies and practices and land use mapping were published and presented, several of these were piloted in Ethiopia including (1) water spreading weirs (2) soil and water conservation measures (3) exclosures and other work (4) developed a better understanding of sustainable land management. In India, the focus was on (5) demonstrating how to deliver livelihoods equitably and sustainably through watershed management approaches and (6) introduction of game methods to help farmers identify their own rules for management of water infrastructure. Other relevant initiatives included (7) mapping of cropland extent in India and changes in Malawi using new techniques for monitoring food supply and policy; (8) land restoration in Uzbekistan.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender component in the mapping of risks and opportunities for actors in locally important value chains.
youth_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Youth as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Youth research component as part of the UNCCD COP14.
capdev_justification: CapDev is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work. The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included tertiary and vocational training (among others).
climate_justification: Climate change is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.

outcome_sumary: Demonstrating through Agriculture Innovation Platforms, smart water management tools, water users’ associations (WUA) and on-line irrigation benchmarking systems (OIBS) and asset management system (SAMS) the possibilities for revitalizing irrigation schemes at scale. These pilots are where government is engaged and convinced to invest in impactful interventions. For example, in Zimbabwe work in 13 schemes with 1698 farmers on 757 ha is being scaled to 30 more with Government involvement and continued donor support.
milestone_evidence: This milestone has been extended into 2020, to enable time for national governments in at least 3 countries to combine on-farm and scheme performance tools to improve irrigation management. Other work included delivering insights on (1) how to achieve more productive uses of water in irrigation for climate smart objectives; getting a (2) prototype Systematic Asset Management System for assessing irrigation schemes tested and online, and including gender indicators into the Online Irrigation Benchmarking System; assessing (3) canal irrigation performance in India; and(4) using smart water management tools in Zimbabwe to improve water productivity in small scale irrigation schemes.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis with regard to reducing water use within irrigation (among others).
youth_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Youth as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Youth analysis related to household dynamics and farm income (among others).
capdev_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included significant Capacity Development on the use of irrigation  monitoring tools introduced to smallholders (among others).
climate_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Climate Change as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Climate Change research component related to the sustainablity of smallholder irrigation schemes (among others).

These pilots are where government is engaged and convinced to invest in impactful interventions. For example, in Zimbabwe work in 13 schemes with 1698 farmers on 757 ha is being scaled to 30 more with Government involvement and continued donor support.
milestone_evidence: Printed issue (International Journal of Water Resources Development) planned for launch during XVII World Water Congress in Daegu, Korea, May 2020.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis in assessing scaling options for Tools + Agricultural Innovation Platforms (TAIP) (among others).
youth_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Youth as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Youth analysis related to household dynamics and farm income (among others).
capdev_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing CapDev. Capacity Development was a primary aim in this milestone, first related to teaching the use of smart water management tools to smallholder farmers and second related to the development of Agricultural Innovation Platforms (AIPs) where stakeholders developed their own solutions to irrigation scheme challenges.
climate_justification: Climate change is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.

outcome_sumary: Demonstrating through Agriculture Innovation Platforms, smart water management tools, water users’ associations (WUA) and on-line irrigation benchmarking systems (OIBS) and asset management system (SAMS) the possibilities for revitalizing irrigation schemes at scale. These pilots are where government is engaged and convinced to invest in impactful interventions. For example, in Zimbabwe work in 13 schemes with 1698 farmers on 757 ha is being scaled to 30 more with Government involvement and continued donor support.
milestone_evidence: Tools for better irrigation scheme management are being further developed, and engagement in key platforms and partnerships is continuing to support outcomes. Sessions were held (1) with Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa, Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Small Scale Irrigation, and the World Bank Group at Stockholm World Water Week, and with donors and development banks at the Water4Food conference. The irrigation benchmarking tools were discussed (2) with governments in India and Uzbekistan; and (3) the recommendations on how to set up Water User Associations for more sustainable and equitable irrigation scheme management was published as a handbook. Work in (4) Jordan looked to how to deliver behaviour changes in farmers in Jordan to facilitate more productive water use in irrigation.
gender_justification: Gender equality is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work. The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis of the relationship between women's empowerment and food security (among others).

capdev_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Capacity Development  component related to the manamgement of basin water organizations (among others).

outcome_sumary: The RUAF Global Partnership collaborates with FAO and selected cities to better understand and strengthen City Region Food Systems for urban climate resilience.In addition, with the same partners a set of gender-sensitive indicators was developed for MUFPP cities, and the Framework was field tested in three cities, to date.
milestone_evidence: The assessment methodology was field-tested in five pilot cities (1) (Quito, still ongoing) with outreach to MUFPP (>200 cities) and CityFood (>30 cities). The reports on the Dynamics and Planning of the City Region Food System of Quito were finalized and the review of existing approaches on climate resilience and city region food systems was also finalised and a two-day workshop held in Rome. Draft reports are available from the field tests in Tamale and Colombo (2) 6 draft training modules on city region food systems were developed.
gender_justification: Gender equality is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work. The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis of land ownership and control.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: CapDev is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work. The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Capacity Development resulting from the development of Training Tools for current and future diet and climate resilience / footprint assessments (among others).
climate_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing our knowledge of climate change.

outcome_sumary: The RUAF Global Partnership collaborates with FAO and selected cities to better understand and strengthen City Region Food Systems for urban climate resilience.In addition, with the same partners a set of gender-sensitive indicators was developed for MUFPP cities, and the Framework was field tested in three cities, to date.
milestone_evidence: The Gender Indicator Framework (1) for assessing city region food systems for the Milan Urban Food Policy Pact (2) was field tested in (3) Nairobi, Quito, Antananarivo. These cities adapted/proposed new indicators, as applying gender lens is not easy, and the framework provides some clear guidance. Applying these gender indicators will be pursued further with cities. (4) These challenges will be described in a paper for UA magazine. (5) Framework indicators, and gender issues were included in training materials, Wageningen (CDI FSUS course, 30 participants) and at a Milan Urban Food Policy Pact meeting. A special issue on gender and urban agriculture is now in process for publication in 2020.
gender_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing gender equality.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: CapDev is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.
climate_justification: Climate change is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.

outcome_sumary: To increase recognition of waste as a business opportunity, curricula and an online course were designed for universities and schools. Pilot training program and direct engagements with universities generated keen interest to adopt the curriculum into their programs or incorporate selected modules in courses.Advisory services for key sanitation/RRR investors (World Bank and BMGF) in South Asia helped strengthen business capacities.Our support of waste-based standards in Sri Lanka is helping establish an enabling environment for RRR.The need to establish standards was an important lesson for scaling up waste-based fertilizer recommendations, resulting in milestone change.
milestone_evidence: Seven universities and business schools using the materials including:1. Birla Institute of Technology & Science, India (M.E Sanitation Science Technology and Management program).2. IHE Delft (Module – Sanitation Financing)3. CEWAS school: in water entrepreneurship courses4. RRR entrepreneurship training, TH Köln (run by CEWAS)5. M.Sc. programs, AIT-Bangkok;6. MSc, Makerere University, Uganda;7. MSc at Ghent University.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone. outcome_sumary: We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the impacts of water variability. This includes updating of systems to maximize benefits from contemporary technologies (e.g. cloud-based systems), as well as continued focus on nature-based solutions and risk transfer mechanisms. We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the risks associated with floods and droughts, with a focus on gender equality and inclusion.
milestone_evidence: Report in layout stage. Review process slow; to be published in the first quarter of 2020.
gender_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
climate_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing our knowledge of climate change.

outcome_sumary: We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the impacts of water variability. This includes updating of systems to maximize benefits from contemporary technologies (e.g. cloud-based systems), as well as continued focus on nature-based solutions and risk transfer mechanisms. We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the risks associated with floods and droughts, with a focus on gender equality and inclusion.
milestone_evidence: Progress on novel approaches to water risk management (1) Managed Aquifer Recharge for sustaining groundwater supplies for smallholder coffee production in Vietnam; (2) through hydrological characterization of different rice environments in flood based farming systems in the Ayeyarwady Delta in Myanmar. (3) Flood and drought monitoring for mitigating drought and flood risk has been achieved in all four countries and is documented, including locations with high impact identified, (4) insurance trials completed, information sent to government and other agencies, capacity building and (5) solutions integrated into national programs.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender component in the impacts on livelihoods (among others). Gender equality is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: CapDev is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work.
climate_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing our knowledge of climate change.

outcome_sumary: We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the impacts of water variability. We have continued with the development and trialing of innovative approaches for managing and mitigating the risks associated with floods and droughts, with a focus on gender equality and inclusion.
milestone_evidence: This milestone was extended to enable recent (1) technological advances and new approaches (e.g. bundling) to be incorporated and to continue the work on Bundled Index Insurance implemented, in Bihar, India. The (2) satellite-based flood insurance was also tested as means for compensating Bangladeshi farmers for flooded crops. Partnering took place with (3) the South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation Disaster Management Centre of UN-SPIDER on emergency response. As a result of this work, there will be an extension to Afghanistan adoption of a Drought Early Warning System and the South Asia Drought Monitoring System platform customized in Google Earth Engine, which will roll-out 2020.

outcome_sumary: In 2019 VCR moved from tools development to implementation of water-energy-environment-food nexus tools in various river basins and countries of Asia and Africa. To ensure wider uptake of WLE tools, researchers presented results at professional, university and policy settings; trained next users and participated in regional and other networks.
milestone_evidence: Several analyses delivered including (1) Economic analyses (linked to environmental flows) to explore synergies and trade-offs between built and natural infrastructure in the Tana River Basin, Kenya; (2) Nexus analysis of three tributaries (Sekong, Sesan and Srepok) to the Mekong River; and (3) Applying hydrological models from the Koshi, Karnali and the Mahakali river basins contributed to Nepal Irrigation Master Plan.

outcome_sumary: Development of a variety of decision support tools, investment options, business cases and pilots proceeded to inform and influence application of sustainable intensification, soil management and application of agrobiodiversity in land restoration in 10 countries (Kenya, Benin, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Bangladesh, Uzbekistan, Jordan, Colombia, Peru and El Salvador). There was special attention paid to how a focus on gender and equity issues can positively impact restoration and soil health interventions.
milestone_evidence: Collected (1) cross-country comparative data on gender (Kenya and Burkina Faso), and (2) compiled practical strategies for enhancing gender equality in innovation platforms; and (3) considered how to integrate gender and social inclusion considerations in mathematical modeling focused on agriculture and natural resource management and (4) held dialogues on inclusion in restoration.
gender_justification: Principal score: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing gender equality

outcome_sumary: Practices for improving soil fertility and soil carbon were assessed in Ethiopia, Tanzania, Southern Africa and Sub-Saharan Africa. Soil carbon sequestration potential and micronutrients deficiencies mapped at the regional and continental level in Africa. Guidelines for soil carbon assessments adopted by United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD).
milestone_evidence: Capabilities in soil health strengthened through (1) recommendations on sustainable fertilizer use based on evidence of crop non-responsiveness to fertilizers; (2) strengthening crop nutritional quality through analyses of links between micronutrient deficiencies and soil quality management; (3) assessing tillage and residue management on runoff, soils, and yield in Ethiopia; (4) validation of a soil fertility decision guide in Tanzania; and (5) support to the adoption of a new data sharing policy in Ethiopia.

outcome_sumary: WLE’s decision analysis frameworks for planning and performance measurement of land restoration efforts were further developed and applied with local partners in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia (2), Kenya, and India. The Burkina Faso case evaluated alternative interventions for protecting a reservoir from siltation. The Ethiopia cases evaluated alternatives for forest landscape restoration and irrigation developments. In Kenya there was close partnership with county-level government and stakeholders to target and co-design land restoration investments. In India, an integrated framework was tested for monitoring, evaluating, and enhancing the effectiveness of initiatives designed to restore degraded land in commonly managed land.
milestone_evidence: M&E tools development continued with (1) co-design of stakeholder and cross-sectoral engagement processes in Kenya for better targeting of land restoration investments (2) co-design of an integrated framework for monitoring, evaluating, enhancing effectiveness of degraded land restoration in India; (3) exploration of mitigation benefits from expansion of trees on rangeland in Colombia and Sierra Leone (Mali replaced by other countries).

outcome_sumary:
Our interventions focus primarily on two human health risks - malaria
transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among
livestock holders. In 2019, plans to test alternate wetting and drying (AWD)
irrigation with AfricaRice in West Africa and with IRRI in East Africa advanced.
AWD in rice farming has potential to limit malaria transmission as well as greenhouse
gas emission. In addition, studies on livestock vaccination strategies for RVF
were initiated in Kenya and Uganda. There is also ongoing work to characterize
risks related to landscape-mediated effects of agriculture on vector-borne
disease in Africa and South Asia
milestone_evidence:
ILRI researchers finalized the risk maps in 2019 and have trained some
government officers on how to use these risk maps in contingency planning. More
policy engagement is planned for 2020. At this stage, it is too early to
suggest that the maps have been adopted in government planning.
gender_justification: no evidence of gendered-risks for infection
youth_justification: no evidence of youth-risks for infection
capdev_justification: Decision makers will have better clarity on spatial distribution of RVF risk for deployment of risk-based surveillance and control measures
climate_justification: This disease is climate sensitive. The risk map has been produced using climate variables among other predictors. Expected changes in RVF risk in the future (2050/2070) will also be generated based on the baseline map

outcome_sumary:
Our interventions focus primarily on two human health risks - malaria
transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among
livestock holders. In 2019, plans to test alternate wetting and drying (AWD)
irrigation with AfricaRice in West Africa and with IRRI in East Africa advanced.
AWD in rice farming has potential to limit malaria transmission as well as greenhouse
gas emission. In addition, studies on livestock vaccination strategies for RVF
were initiated in Kenya and Uganda. There is also ongoing work to characterize
risks related to landscape-mediated effects of agriculture on vector-borne
disease in Africa and South Asia
milestone_evidence: The synoptic review was completed and a manuscript was submitted to a peer-reviewed journal in 2019. It was rejected, so the authors are refining it to re-submit in 2020.
gender_justification: study focused on environmental and technical not social issues
youth_justification: study focused on environmental and technical not social issues
capdev_justification: broad overview study not yet with specific plans for implications for implementation
climate_justification: The review provides recommendations on irrigation practices that could be used to manage mosquito abundance while at the same time limiting GHG emissions

outcome_sumary:
Our interventions focus primarily on two human health risks - malaria
transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among
livestock holders. In 2019, plans to test alternate wetting and drying (AWD)
irrigation with AfricaRice in West Africa and with IRRI in East Africa advanced.
AWD in rice farming has potential to limit malaria transmission as well as greenhouse
gas emission. In addition, studies on livestock vaccination strategies for RVF
were initiated in Kenya and Uganda. There is also ongoing work to characterize
risks related to landscape-mediated effects of agriculture on vector-borne
disease in Africa and South Asia
milestone_evidence: AfricaRice is a partner with the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) on the alternate wet and dry (AWD) irrigation in rice trials in West Africa.For CapDev - The collaboration with AfricaRice to include health-related indicators reflects a shift in institutional priorities and a recognition of the value in incorporating aspects of human health in their research. Training has taken place, and will continue, to build institutional awareness and the ability to monitor health-indicators.For Gender - Gender is part of this work because pregnant women and <5y children suffer >85% of the burden of malaria in Africa. Hence this links to the “sustainable rice-growing lifestyles” work of Kazuki Saito, our collaborator in Africa Rice.
gender_justification: The indicators to be developed will include gender and equity aspects realising that rice farming practices are associated with gender
youth_justification: youth not specifically considered but only linked to gender
capdev_justification: Opportunities to train farmers on new irrigation strategies which reduce malaria risk as well as emission of GHGs
climate_justification: A component of the study investigates how alternative irrigation practices influences GHG emissions

outcome_sumary:
The milestones for this outcome demonstrate progress in
developing, validating, and evaluating a suite of strategies to mitigate cysticercosis
in East Africa and other zoonotic threats in different contexts in Africa and
South Asia. In 2019, we established a new partnership with the University of
Munich to support the development of a diagnostic kit for cysticercosis. ILRI
is also working on national action plans for cysticercosis in Kenya and Uganda,
as well as an action plan for brucellosis in Kenya. The latter has been
submitted for approval by the government.
milestone_evidence: Earlier attempts to develop a pen-side test (a diagnostic that can provide real-time information about the health status of an animal or herd) were not successful. The partnership with University of Munich will re-start efforts to develop and validate the test.
gender_justification: purely lab-based technical work. The technology being developed is assumed to be appropriate for men and women
youth_justification: purely lab-based technical work. Assumed to be useful for youth but not specifically designed with youth considerations.
capdev_justification: The test will improve the capacity of veterinary department to do surveillance on cysticercosis
climate_justification: Assumed test will be useful in all climate scenarios

outcome_sumary:
The milestones for this outcome demonstrate progress in
developing, validating, and evaluating a suite of strategies to mitigate cysticercosis
in East Africa and other zoonotic threats in different contexts in Africa and
South Asia. In 2019, we established a new partnership with the University of
Munich to support the development of a diagnostic kit for cysticercosis. ILRI
is also working on national action plans for cysticercosis in Kenya and Uganda,
as well as an action plan for brucellosis in Kenya. The latter has been
submitted for approval by the government.
milestone_evidence: A draft policy document has been submitted to the government for approval, which is expected to happen in 2020.
gender_justification: gender is a gap that remains to be built in
youth_justification: youth is a gap that remains to be built in
capdev_justification: The policy will improve brucellosis control strategies and allocation of resources based on estimates of burden
climate_justification: climate change is a gap that remains to be built in

milestone_evidence:
Technical
report has been finalized, but we are awaiting government approval before it can be disseminated. It is too early to claim that awareness has been raised as a result of this report.
gender_justification: contribution to a national task force that did not consider gender
youth_justification: contribution to a national task force that did not consider youth
capdev_justification: Better awareness on distribution of cysticercosis to guide interventions
climate_justification: contribution to a national task force that did not consider climate change

milestone_evidence: A meeting was held in ILRI Nairobi in December 2019 to share the final project outputs. The reports are available, though not disseminated publicly.
gender_justification: Results of the studies conducted identify risk factors of the target zoonotic diseases by gender and livelihood practices
youth_justification: Youth targeted in the dissemination of information through the use of mobile phones and social media
capdev_justification: Postgraduate training around value chain mapping and awareness of zoonotic disease management was a key component of the outputs

outcome_sumary:
Partnerships for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) research and
policy interventions involving some CGIAR institutions (ILRI, IFPRI, IMWI, WorldFish),
some universities (LSHTM, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences) and a
few countries (Kenya, Uganda, Vietnam and Bangladesh) were established in 2019.
These partnerships work under the aegis of the CGIAR AMR Hub that was launched
in February 2019.
milestone_evidence: The CGIAR Antimicrobial Resistance Hub (AMR) was launched in a high-profile event at ILRI in February 2019. The Hub is led by Arshnee Moodley. The AMR Hub website was launched and contains a growing body of resources on agriculture-associated AMR.
gender_justification: establishment of platform - gender will be brought into subsequent research portfolio
youth_justification: establishment of platform - youth will be brought into subsequent research portfolio
capdev_justification: The website is a repository for materials that can be used by national and international partners for AMR research
climate_justification: establishment of platform - clmate change will be brought into subsequent research portfolio

outcome_sumary:
Partnerships for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) research and
policy interventions involving some CGIAR institutions (ILRI, IFPRI, IMWI, WorldFish),
some universities (LSHTM, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences) and a
few countries (Kenya, Uganda, Vietnam and Bangladesh) were established in 2019.
These partnerships work under the aegis of the CGIAR AMR Hub that was launched
in February 2019.
milestone_evidence: Researchers from this flagship drafted and provided major inputs into CGIAR's Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) Strategy. The Strategy describes how a OneHealth framework can be used to design and test AMR interventions.
gender_justification: The strategy identified gender and equity issues that should be addressed by AMR work
youth_justification: youth to be included in subsequent stages
capdev_justification: Guides one health researchers on how to establish multidisciplinary team on AMR work
climate_justification: climate to be included in subsequent stages

youth_justification: early technical risk analysis without social dimension

outcome_sumary:
Milestones for this outcome demonstrate how this flagship is convening
actors representing agriculture and public health to raise awareness of areas
of collaboration and eventually, design and implement joint projects. Since
2018, this flagship has convened several multisectoral meetings bringing
together agriculture and public health actors. Some have been regional in
nature while others have been international. The annual Agriculture, Nutrition,
and Health Academy (ANH Academy), which is co-led by A4NH and the London School
of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) also serves as a platform for this
flagship to facilitate these collaborations.
milestone_evidence: This is a sample of events held in 2019: (1) Agriculture Nutrition and Health Academy Week 2019 in Hyderabad; (2) London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine week; (3) workshop in Vietnam.
gender_justification: Partnership developed by LSHTM in the meetings include development of frameworks of gender and equity studies in one health
youth_justification: youth part of broader equity considerations
capdev_justification: Graduate fellows from various institutions trained on one health research during A4NH academy week
climate_justification: some considerations of climate change, but not high-priority topic

outcome_sumary:
Ex-ante/spatial assessments (incl foresight and
 targeting) assess how major drivers (like climate change, biotic stresses,
 and rural transformation) will alter MAIZE in the developing world.
 Highlights of foresight/targeting studies to inform policy:
 - Three strategic studies focused on Africa: one providing a spatial framework
 for ex-ante impact assessment of agricultural technologies (1); another assessing
 future changes and uncertainty in decision-relevant measures of East African
 climate (2) and the third assessing maize crop nutrient input requirements
 for food security (3).
 - comprehensive book reviewed the transformation of rural Africa (4) with a
 complementary paper reviewing implications for sustainable agricultural intensification
 (5).
 - Three other studies analyzed specific innovations: potential of
 site-specific extension services and high-input agriculture in Nigeria (6);
 an ex-ante assessment for scaling conservation agriculture in Zambia (7) and
 the potential of biofortified maize for child nutrition in southern Ethiopia
 (8).
 - Two papers focused on stresses: one assessing the threats of Tar Spot
 Complex disease of maize in the USA and its global consequences (9) and the
 other assessing weather shocks and spatial market efficiency in Mozambique
 (10).
 - comprehensive manual provides a guide to scaling soil and water
 conservation in the Western Highlands of Guatemala (11).
 

.

outcome_sumary:
Enhance adoption/impacts:
 - MAIZE Impact assessment strategy released (1) and potential implications for technological change rethought (2).- Review impact pathways for improved staple-crop
 germplasm to poverty reduction (3) and intensification through conservation agriculture
 (4).
 - Assess adoption and impacts of drought-tolerant maize in
 Zambia (5), Malawi (6), Zimbabwe (7), Uganda (8,9)
 - Revisited maize landrace use in Mexico (10), adoption of
 short-duration varieties in Nigeria (11)
 - Assessed economic impacts of maize stem borer in Pakistan (12),
 minimum tillage in Kenya (13) climate smart agriculture in Africa (14), soil Zinc on child-nutrition in Ethiopia (15).
 - Assessed impacts of services on adoption in Africa:
 credit and extension (16) and information exchange (17).Gender/social-inclusiveness:
 - Youth in Africa: Assessing heterogeneity of rural
 youth opportunities (18); access to land, migration and employment
 opportunities (19)
 - Gender differentiated adoption of improved maize in
 Ethiopia (20), disentangling gendered information and role model
 effects in Uganda (21)
 -Two book chapters: Integrating gender into farm typologies in
 Guatemala (22); agrobiodiversity use affected by socioecologic and
 economic diversity (23) 
 - Resource material on gender in Africa’s maize seed
 systems: Women seed business (24), gender-responsive approaches
 for agro-dealers (25), breeders (26), seed companies (27) and promotion (28).
