milestone_evidence: Varietal profile. Evidence is available for biofortified pearl millet, and lentil and links are reported in AR, and in the evidence links section in this masterlist.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary:
The
 simultaneous improvement of both production and market traits through
 partnership with NARS under Flagship 4 resulted in commercialization of 26
 GLDC crop cultivars of chickpea (6), lentil (5), groundnut (8), pigeon pea
 (2), sorghum (1), pearl millet (3), and finger millet (1) in Africa and
 Asia.
 Rapid
 generation advancement (RGA) that enhances rate of genetic gain is used to
 develop and commercialize high oleic varieties, and protocols were
 standardized and deployed in lentil and chickpea. New genetic material of
 GLDC crops was shared with NARS partners in Africa and Asia and
 multi-location testing is established jointly with NARS to identify new
 cultivars for the target-agroecologies.
 TPE
 Characterization in Asia and WCA is completed for Groundnut, Sorghum and
 Chickpea and this activity is prioritized under CoA 4.1 and has received
 co-investment from AVISA and other bilateral projects.
 The
 first high oleic groundnut varieties that confer consumer hearth benefits are
 commercialized in India. Bio-fortified lentil and pearl millet cultivars
 commercialized are important to reduce the burden of micro-nutrient
 malnutrition.
 The
 GLDC crop product profiles have been developed and uploaded on the EiB
 platform. NARS were also trained on development of PPs at the second training
 course organized by FP4.
milestone_evidence: Towards the end of the Extension Phase of CRP-GL and DC, the varieties at various stages of testing in national trails and/or MLTs are released for commercial cultivation in CRP-GLDC. The variety profile meets the Product Lines of CRP-GL and DC.
gender_justification: We have some examples (a) easy snap finger millet variety and (b) high protein soybean variety that is enabling women and youth enterpreneurship.
capdev_justification: Training of researchers and breeders in partner NARS for breeding approaches and methods, nursery management that enabled them to release varieties
climate_justification: The new varieties have key traits for climate change adaptation such as, adaptation to water deficit stress and heat tolerance. Some have enhanced level of resistance to biotic stresses that are expected to be more severe in climate change scenarios.

outcome_sumary:
The
 GLDC crop Product Profiles are developed and uploaded on EiB platform. NARS were also trained on development of
 PPs at the second training course organized by Flagship 4.
milestone_evidence: The EiB (Excellence in Breeding) platform has a portol to upload the Product Profiles and this exercise was done. In addition the information on the portal is shared to Jake in a excel sheet that can be provided as evidence.
gender_justification: The new exercise of designing ‘Product Profiles’ explicitly captures the gender components. The designing is based on value chain study in the target ecology.
capdev_justification: The NARS are trained to design the Product Profiles and also provide feedback to design Product Profiles. Training was conducted in collaboration with the EiB at the CNG meetings as well as the International Training Course organized in 2018 (at New Delhi, India) and 2019 (at Arusha, Tanzania).
climate_justification: Climate change is the main objective and is fundamental in the design and expected results in the development of crop product profiles.

outcome_sumary:
Advanced
 the work related to Botrytis grey mold 
 in chickpea, blast/heat tolerance in pearl millet and drought
 tolerance in cowpea by using wild germplasm
milestone_evidence: Publications, reports, technical bulletins. The papers cited talks about successful wide crosses.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason in breeding technology development/refinement. In pacticular, the young researchers/students trained in making these crosses.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary:
Molecular
 breeding products (2 in groundnut, 3 in chickpea) released in India and
 Ethiopia Markers deployed in breeding program in groundnut, sorghum and
 cowpea resulting in more than 700K marker data points generated in 2019. QC
 panels developed and initially validated in groundnut and pearl millet.
 Germplasm reference sets, other germplasm sets, mapping populations assembled
 and traits prioritized for discovery research in 4 legumes (groundnut,
 chickpea, pigeonpea, cowpea) and 3 cereals (sorghum, pearl millet, finger
 millet)
milestone_evidence: The papers cited describe the traits characterized at genotypic and phenotypic levels to develop markers.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason in precision phenotyping. In particular, Students and young researchers trained in these projects as part of their capacity building.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary:
Some
 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding
 program with disease resistance and promising levels of iron in red, black
 and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program 200 lines from a
 population developed for drought and BCMV resistance (p52) were evaluated in
 a drought and irrigated trial. 38 lines from a population developed for heat
 tolerance (p88) were evaluated in drought and irrigated conditions. Data
 needs to be analyzed to code new lines (~70), for multilocational
 testing.
milestone_evidence: EiB site. The profiles are registered with the Excellence in Breeding platform, but they have apparently chosen not to make them public.
gender_justification: A majority of bean farmers in Africa are women, and thus the target characteristics of improved bean cultivars are of immediate interest. Of specific gender related traits of a profile, cooking time emerges consistently with implications for time spent gathering firewood. High iron beans have special significance for women in their role as caregivers and for their own health. Surveys will refine product profiles and may reveal more gender related breeding objectives.
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Product profiles address a wide range of objectives. Regarding climate change, product profiles represent a commitment to develop drought tolerant varieties in several grain types. Similar to gender, the project profile is a commitment to work toward climate resilient bean varieties. Here perhaps the intention is more direct than in the case of gender.  Specifically the creation of drought tolerant beans is explicit in several product profiles.

outcome_sumary: In a collaboration with the Boyce Thomson Institute, databases for breeding management and analysis have been set up for sweetpotato, cassava, banana and yam. Over the past year, CGIAR Centers and NARS partners have entered hundreds of trials into the databases, using them to carry out all steps of their breeding cycle and collecting trait data to inform the breeding programs. Sweetpotato varieties were released in Burkina Faso, Kenya, Ghana, Tajikistan and Bangladesh, potato varieties in Rwanda, Bangladesh and Tajikistan, yam varieties in Nigeria, and cassava varieties were proposed for release in Nigeria, Malawi, Zambia and Colombia.
milestone_evidence: Quantitative trait loci (QTLs) for yield were identified in sweetpotato, and QTLs for starch and β-carotene helped explain the negative correlation between them. GWAS identified markers to bunch weight in banana. Introgressed Manihot glaziovii genome segments accounted for partial heritability for yield, dry matter, Cassava Mosaic Disease and Cassava Brown Streak Disease resistance in cassava.
gender_justification: Genomic approaches open possibilities to develop markers for gendered end-user preference traits related to product quality and agronomic traits
capdev_justification: Research is carried out with national partners, and graduate students, increasing the capacity for genomic approaches.
climate_justification: Genomic approaches open possibilities to develop markers for abiotic stress-tolerance traits

outcome_sumary: Reference genomes of Musa and Yam published, and dense linkage map of hexaploid sweetpotato developed, providing the basis for follow-up research on trait discovery. Application of genome-wide association study led to the identification of markers linked to bunch weight in banana, critical for early selection for fruit filling. Advances in gene editing is going beyond proof of concept and will accelerate development of new products. B genome of banana edited to inactivate endogenous viral sequence, making such material safe to use in breeding. Through advances in high throughput phenotyping are tackling traits related to abiotic stress tolerance and product quality.
milestone_evidence: Phenotyping under controlled environmental conditions was used to screen banana accessions to responses to stress, simulating the climate of the East-African highlands. Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) equations were developed for nutritional compounds in yam and for carotenoids in cassava. Canopy chlorophyll fluorescence was applied to detect stress in sweetpotato.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: The protocols are developed in collaboration with national partners, thus increasing the capacity for high throughput phenotyping
climate_justification: Breeding material is screened to identify tolerance to abiotic stresses. This will ensure enhanced resilience to climatic shocks. Remote sensing is playing an important role in this research area.

outcome_sumary: An in-depth assessment of on farm diversity in hotspots areas of RTB crops is ongoing. Native varieties were collected in hotspot areas including potato and cassava in Peru, banana and yam in PNG, and yam and cassava in Benin. Banana collecting missions were undertaken in PNG, Cooks, Rarotonga and Samoa islands. Based on earlier collecting missions, catalogues of banana from Vietnam, and China and Laos were produced. The potato farmer’s association AGUAPAN in Peru is fostering the implementation of a hotspot-based, in-situ network for potato landraces. Payments for agrobiodiversity conservation services in collaboration with MINAM is under implementation in Peru.
milestone_evidence: The genetic diversity of wild banana collections was quantified, collecting missions carried out in Oceania, and landraces screened for Fusarium resistance. Peru farmer association implementing in-situ network for potato landraces. Together with Ministry of Environment of Peru and Regional Governments, GEF Agrobiodiversity project is implementing Payments for Agrobiodiversity Conservation Services.An harmonized framework together with an online platform for monitoring and sharing knowledge about genetic diversity of RTB crops and their wild relatives is under development.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Collecting missions with partners and training on handling and transfer of material. Capacitation of local farmer associations on getting organized for payments for agrobiodiversity conservation. AGUAPAN is helping its members access funds through benefit-sharing where some of the profits derived from using the landraces are shared with the farmers who preserve them.
climate_justification: In-situ conservation enhances the maintenance of well-adapted genetic material, that shifts over time with changing climates.  Collections of material from hotspots of diversity assures conserving a wider range of genetic diversity that may provide novel resilience alleles to breeding programs to abiotic stress tolerance.

outcome_sumary: Drought tolerance was evaluated in accessions of sweetpotato crop wild relatives (CWR) in order to identify new sources for breeding. A pre-breeding core collection of potato CWR-derived breeding lines and true-seed families with drought tolerance or resistance to diseases that will increase with climate change was generated. Cassava landraces were identified with whitefly tolerance using parameters such as number of nymphs and percentage of affected area. Drone-based phenotyping including thermographic screening for heat stress in sweetpotato, water stress in potato and measurement of plant growth in cassava are setting the stage for developing populations with enhanced resilience to climatic shocks.
milestone_evidence: A climate-controlled growth container, designed to simulate the climate of the East-African highlands, was used to screen banana accessions responses to stress. The protocol can be used for parent selection. Dataset for evaluation of abiotic stress tolerance using multispectral aerial images of 1585 potato genotypes under normal and deficit irrigation.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Platforms developed specifically to screen populations for tolerance to abiotic stresses of drought and heat.

outcome_sumary: Collaboration among center and partner breeding programs led to the implementation of product profiles to define breeding targets across the programs. The programs are digitizing their data collection, using standardized databases (BreeDBase). The breeding community of practice has come together to define ontologies for new traits related to product quality and explore how to best implement the tricot method for variety evaluation. Interactions with the Gender in Breeding Initiative is resulting in impacts on gender being considered when prioritizing traits for breeding. Collaboration with the Breeding Application Programming Interface (BrAPI) community is facilitating interoperability among breeding applications.
milestone_evidence: Through the Breeding Community of Practice, courses were given in statistics, data management and ontologies. RTB Center and five partner breeding programs are implementing product profiles to define breeding targets, while considering gender impacts. The BrAPI community is facilitating interoperability among breeding applications, as center and partner programs go digital
gender_justification: Incorporation of GBI tools into the process of product profile development is ensuring gender issues are considered in the ranking and prioritization of breeding target traits.
capdev_justification: The training events were 100% about capacity building in specific areas of breeding research.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: From 2010 to 2019, a multi-partner coalition led by CIP contributed to the release of 150 improved sweetpotato varieties, 100 of them orange-fleshed, with high levels of vitamin A, across 17 countries of SSA. In total vines of improved varieties were distributed to more than 29 million individuals. Early generation clean seed using rapid multiplication technologies is being produced by commercial entities for cassava in Nigeria and Tanzania, yam in Nigeria and Ghana, and potato in Rwanda and Kenya, thus making available seed of improved varieties to commercial seed growers.
milestone_evidence: Development of seed business models ongoing for all RTB crops. Rapid multiplication techniques, certification schemes and decentralized entrepreneurs are supported- for example: in Kenya for potato; in Uganda and Tanzania, for banana; in Nigeria and Tanzania for cassava; in Nigeria and Ghana for yam; in 11 African countries for sweetpotato.
gender_justification: The roles of men and women in banana and sweetpotato seed systems in Uganda were studied, and how these affect the functionality of the two seed systems while exploring differences in men and women regarding seed availability, access and quality. Women are engaging and investing in nurseries to produce planting material, and become licensed to produce certified seed potato.
youth_justification: Youth are engaging and investing in nurseries to produce cuttings, and become licensed to produce certified seed potato.
capdev_justification: Seed production requires significant capdev-so there is ongoing training of certified seed producers and decentralized vine multipliers on seed production practices and business development.
climate_justification: Technologies such as Triple S for sweetpotato allow the conservation of planting material over longer dry seasons.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and Fusarium and Sigatoka resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo plot trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields across multiple locations and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha as a result of quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Sustainable intensification technologies such as partial root-zone drying (PRD) were demonstrated in 7 districts in Assam, India.High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and Fusarium and Sigatoka resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo plot trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields across multiple locations and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha as a result of quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Sustainable intensification technologies such as partial root-zone drying (PRD) were demonstrated in 7 districts in Assam, India.
milestone_evidence: Increased availability of improved varieties of potato, cassava and orange-fleshed sweetpotato, with strengthened seed multiplication and supply systems, and improved crop management practices in Malawi. New potato varieties released in Rwanda after 30 years, with RAB producing quality early generation seed. National plan for improving seed potato in Georgia submitted.
gender_justification: 51% of farmers applying technologies were women in Kenya GAP trainings. RTC-Malawi targetted women for training on nutrition.
capdev_justification: Four module training course on potato learning farms covering a cropping season and training on agronomic practices was integral part of technology dissemination package
climate_justification: Technology package allows reliable production in inconsistent climates and supports diversification of potato to non-traditional agro-ecologies.  Potato varieties released in Rwanda and promoted in Malawi were heat and drought tolerant.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and Fusarium and Sigatoka resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo plot trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields across multiple locations and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha as a result of quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Sustainable intensification technologies such as partial root-zone drying (PRD) were demonstrated in 7 districts in Assam, India.High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and Fusarium and Sigatoka resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo plot trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields across multiple locations and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha as a result of quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Sustainable intensification technologies such as partial root-zone drying (PRD) were demonstrated in 7 districts in Assam, India.
milestone_evidence: Approaches and tools to better understand causes and dynamics of seed degeneration have been developed and help in defining integrated seed systems strategies. Case studies have been published for sweetpotato in Uganda and for banana in Peru, Uganda, Ghana, Ivory Coast and in the Congo Basin.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Approaches and tools are currently used in projects and capacities of national partners are strenghtened to adapt and use these tools.
climate_justification: The seedHealth R package can be used to estimate the effect of environmental changes caused by CC on the degeneration rate of RTB crops.

outcome_sumary: Released varieties of OFSP are increasing in production, as well as proVit A rich plantains. Yellow cassava varieties have been released in Nigeria and DRC and promising varieties with high beta-carotene content have been recommended to the national program of Colombia for final evaluation before release. Tetraploid lines with elevated levels of iron and zinc have been received in SSA for testing in Ethiopia and Rwanda. The material is also maintained in Kenya at the SSA gene bank. Additionally, they were shipped to Malawi, Zimbabwe and Uganda. Biofortified lines have also been shipped to Nepal and Bangladesh for testing.
milestone_evidence: As of September 2019, orange fleshed sweetpotato varieties have been released in 14 countries.In particular, in 2019 six orange and two yellow sweetpotato varieties were released in Kenya and Ghana, and two orange varieties in Tajikistan. 189 banana genotypes were screened for provitamin A content, with some that can be promoted for biofortification. Zinc and iron-biofortified potatoes are being tested in Rwanda, Ethiopia, Malawi, Kenya and Bangladesh.
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: OFSP varieties released in Mozambique are drought tolerant, and are now being tested in other countries.

outcome_sumary: Pre-breeding potato clones with resistance to Ralstonia solanacearum, late blight and drought tolerance are being developed using crop wild relatives. Sweetpotato crop wild relatives were screened for SPVD virus resistance as well as for drought tolerance. Banana landraces were screened for Fusarium 1 resistance. Collecting missions took place in Cameroon for yam and for banana at several locations in Oceania, thus expanding the potential source germplasm for trait discovery and introgression. Therefore, the collection of crop wild relatives and landraces is being expanded, and screens for important traits are taking place.
milestone_evidence: Genetic diversity of wild banana collections was quantified, and landraces screened for resistance to Fusarium. Banana cultivars and their uses in Uganda and Tanzania were described. A potato farmer-led association in Peru is characterizing landraces they conserve. Potato wild relatives are being used to develop disease and drought tolerant varieties.
gender_justification: An overview of different banana products, cultivars used to make those products and the preferred characteristics as reported by men and women farmers in different regions of Uganda and Tanzania was carried out.  Crop wild relatives derived potatoes are being evaluated by  participatory approaches and includes awareness activities to increase the likelihood of adoption of the new varieties, with particular emphasis on gender equality in decision-making.
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Combining abiotic and biotic stress in advanced clones to provide farmer s with resilient varieties

outcome_sumary: Women are involved in participatory variety selection for banana in East Africa. In Nigeria, promising cassava Nextgen clones are being evaluated by 320 farmers that were selected using a gender response and socially inclusive purposive selection. In Kenya, supporting the development of farmer producer organizations (FPO), where women represent 30% of FPO committees. Furthermore, 70% of beneficiaries receiving GAP training and then applying productivity enhancing technologies are women. Excellent progress was made on analyzing interventions regarding gender-responsiveness and developing gender-responsive interventions for India. Participatory varietal selection was implemented in Bangladesh and India with gender‐responsive approaches to facilitate women’s active participation
milestone_evidence: Overview of banana cultivars used to make different products and their preferred characteristics by farmers in Uganda and Tanzania was carried out, and management of planting material was studied in Uganda. A gender analysis of the potato value chain was conducted in districts in Assam and gender responsive participatory varietal selection (PVS) applied.
gender_justification: Supporting women representation in FPOs in Kenya.  Women are specifically targeted when forming framer groups for training and largely as a result of being more available and more enthusiastic to participate.  Banana variety preferences and the different products made from them were compared between men and women farmers.
capdev_justification: Training addresses resilience through climate smart varieties and practices to ensure good productivity when seasonal conditions not entirely suitable for potato
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: The Seed Tracker app collects and organizes seed production information, for institutions to monitor seed quality and certify producers and is being used for cassava seed certification by the national agencies in Nigeria and Tanzania. The Seed Certification Authority of Malawi has started using and enforcing certification standards for cassava seeds. Through its Seed Act 2019, Nigeria is decentralizing seed certification by authorizing private entities to certify seed. The Act also defines quality assurance and certification of vegetatively propagated crops. A Plan for Improving Seed Potato in Georgia was formulated for authorities to address constraints related to quality seed production.
milestone_evidence: The Seed Tracker app is being used for cassava seed certification by the national agencies in Nigeria and Tanzania. Malawi started using certification standards for cassava seeds. A new Seed Act was enacted in Nigeria authorizing private entities to certify seed. Plan for improving seed potato in Georgia was formulated.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: The National Agricultural Seeds Council (NASC) of Nigeria received training in e-Certification of cassava seed, and has established its own NASC Seed Tracker unit.  Likewise for molecular virus indexing with a molecular lab established and screening samples from breeder seed production plots. Seed tracker app implemented in Tanzania after training of local TOSCI staff.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: (RTC-ACTION), IITA and partners organized capacity building through groups training of Agricultural Extension Officers as training of Trainers (ToT). Seventy (70) Agriculture Extension and Development Officers (AEDOs) were trained as ToT in the seven targeted Districts and each ToT trained 200 farmers in their respective areas with attendance of 13,320 farmersPO2.4: Supported 2 MSc and 4 PhD in 2019
milestone_evidence: 18 male MScs, 8 female MScs, 27 MScs (gender not mentioned)BA2.2: 15 PhD ongoing (4 female and 11 male), 3 PhD finished (2 male, 1 female) and 5 MSc ongoing (2 female and 3 male) and 4 MSc finished (4 female)From BA2.2: 1 male and 1 female PhD received and both person integrated back into the institute.From CA2.3: The project is supporting two students (1 male PhD and 1 female MSc) in collaboration with the University of Malawi University, Chancellor College and University of Agriculture and Natural Resources (LUANAR) respectively
gender_justification: Long term training programs have a good representation of women candidates.
youth_justification: Across all the crop programs, young graduate students are participating in the research projects for MSc and PhD
capdev_justification: Outcome and related milestones are about training and capacity development
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: The use of information and communication technologies is increasing. Collaboration with skilled social enterprises and non-governmental organizations is expanding the reach of the initiatives promoting integrated crop management. Tools piloted for cassava agronomy, pest and disease diagnosis and management in potato, cassava and banana have been developed and are at different levels of validation and dissemination.
milestone_evidence: The Akilimo decision support system platform for cassava agronomy was released on Google’s PlayStore as a freely downloadable smartphone app. It is already being used by cassava farmers in Tanzania and Nigeria and providing location-specific fertilizer recommendations.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Capacity development activities and new phone-based knowledge sharing and decision support tools are developed and used to increase the number of beneficiaries reached
climate_justification: Climate data and climate modeling are used to provide the best advice possible to farmers and extensionists using the decision support tools

outcome_sumary: The use of information and communication technologies is increasing. Collaboration with skilled social enterprises and non-governmental organizations is expanding the reach of the initiatives promoting integrated crop management. Tools piloted for cassava agronomy, pest and disease diagnosis and management in potato, cassava and banana have been developed and are at different levels of validation and dissemination.
milestone_evidence: Virome data used to predict virus strains evolution; Foc TR4 spread assessed in South Asia and southern Africa; areas of Thailand affected by the CMD pandemic identified; surveys in Central Africa have identified high densities of African root and tuber scale (Cameroon and Gabon); enhanced modeling tools for banana bacterial wilt; survey for potato cyst nematode (PCN) in Uganda.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Model developed for mapping Banana Xanthomonas Wilt spread risks in Africa integrates environmental and experts-generated variables

outcome_sumary: Scientific and technical support provided to National Plant Protection Organizations in target countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America is helping to build capacities to predict pest and disease outbreaks under climate change scenarios. In 2019, to contain the spread of Potato Purple Top in the Andean Region awareness creation and management strategies have been implemented in Ecuador, Peru
milestone_evidence: Pest and disease risk models developed take temperature and precipitation into consideration and can therefore be used to determine potential impacts of climate change.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Future climate scenarios are used to determine potential evolution of pest and disease populations and related risks

outcome_sumary: Based on 2019 publications, number of households benefitting from adoption of management practices to control Banana Xanthomonas Wilt in Uganda has been estimated at 60,000. Positive impact expected in other countries where similar initiatives have been implemented (Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda). Significative effects of integrated pest management approaches for potato light blight on production and income have been documented in Peru. More than 40,000 farmers benefitted from Farmer Field Schools interventions. Similar results are expected in other countries (Bolivia, Ethiopia and Uganda). More than 10,000 user reports generated through Nuru to diagnose cassava diseases in Africa which will promote improved disease management.
milestone_evidence: Integrated pest management strategies: decision support systems for potato late blight; phone-based apps for detection of RTB pests and diseases; single diseased stem removal (SDSR) for the control of banana Xanthomonas wilt; enhanced BBTD and FocTR4 management practices; thermal chamber technology for production of disease-free cassava planting material.
gender_justification: Gender roles characterized in relation to responses to pests and diseases of RTB crops and the application of IPM and ICM measures (See Outcome 3.4)
youth_justification: Information and Communication Technologies are increasingly used to disseminate knowlegde and decision support tools. Thermal chamber technology in Colombia has been specifically targeted toward youth entrepreneurs.
capdev_justification: Capacity development activities and new phone-based knowledge sharing and decision support tools are developed and used to increase the number of beneficiaries reached
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: In Rwanda and Burundi gender roles have been characterized in relation to the production of four crops (banana, cassava, potato, and sweetpotato). Understanding the division of labor and decision-making in crop management may lead to designing better interventions targeted at improving efficiency in smallholder agriculture.
milestone_evidence: A study was published describing gender roles in managing banana Xanthomonas wilt in Burundi. Two working papers were drafted describing men’s and women’s knowledge, practices and attitudes to IPM in Laos and Cambodia
gender_justification: All the studies reported here have their main focus on gender related aspects.
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: National plant protection organizations (NPPOs) in 15 countries had their systems enhanced for detecting, monitoring and responding to major pest/disease threats. For the CMD pandemic in SE Asia, this included NPPOs in Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and Vietnam. For BXW in East/Central Africa this included: Burundi, DR Congo, Rwanda and Uganda. For Foc TR4 this included Mozambique and Tanzania in south-eastern Africa and India in South Asia. For BBTV this included: Benin, Cameroon, Nigeria and Togo.
milestone_evidence: Countries where relevant activities were implemented: Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and Vietnam - Cassava Mosaic Disease. Burundi, DR Congo, Rwanda and Uganda - Banana Xanthomonas Wilt. Mozambique, Tanzania and India - FocTR4. Benin, Cameroon, Nigeria and Togo - Banana Bunchy Top Virus. Ecuador and Peru - Potato Purple Top.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Multistakeholder platforms, alliances and networks are promoted to facilitate shared learnings and co-development of national and regional surveillance and management strategies.
climate_justification: Scientific and technical advices provided to National plant protection organizations include projections and predictions developed using future climate scenarios.

outcome_sumary: RTB-based products, i.e. orange fleshed sweetpotato puree and baked products, high quality cassava flour, high quality cassava peels for animal feed, are already promoted in African markets in Kenya, Nigeria, Uganda and Malawi. Research aiming at reducing inefficiencies and hazards related with processing of traditional products (e.g. gari, fufu) is ongoing in Sub-Saharan Africa. Development of gender equitable value chains is supported in Kenya, Malawi, Tanzania and Uganda for sweetpotato and, in the Andean region, results obtained by promoting inclusive value chains have been assessed. With NARS and private companies, new quality food and feed products are under development.
milestone_evidence: Sweetpotato processing into puree and its use for baked products is being promoted in Kenya, Uganda and Malawi with private companies and development organizations. Quality evaluation of food products (e.g. snacks, cookies) produced from RTB crops has been pursued in collaboration with NARS, three new journal articles have been published.
gender_justification: Women are strongly involved in processing and commercialization of RTB products, in particular food products. Gender studies have been realized in Nigeria, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique and Tanzania.
capdev_justification: Co-development of processes and protocols with NARS and private sector as well as capacity development activities are integral part of the implementation startegy
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Joint research, delivery and advocacy work with A4NH is supporting the mainstreaming of biofortification (OFSP, yellow cassava) in national (more than 15 countries) and regional agriculture, nutrition and health policies and programs in Africa. The Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative led by CIP and with HarvestPlus as key partner has already reached 6M households. Research on Vit-A rich bananas and Fe & Zn dense potatoes is also promising. Bioavailability studies and testing of improved varieties are ongoing.
milestone_evidence: Through the Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative, the FoodSTART+ project and two projects on Fe and Zn biofortitfied potatoes, more than 15 countries have seen the implementation of relevant agriculture for nutrition and health initiatives.
gender_justification: Improving maternal, in particular for young mothers, and infant nutrition receive a specific attention and is among the main objectives of most of the agriculture and nutrition integrated interventions.
youth_justification: Improving maternal, in particular for young mothers, and infant nutrition receive a specific attention and is among the main objectives of most of the agriculture and nutrition integrated interventions.
capdev_justification: Integrated agriculture for nutrition and health interventions put a lot of emphasis on capacity development at different levels: frontline workers (who administer downstream training), caregivers of children under 5 years, staff in regional governments and development organizations, decision-makers.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Linked with Outcome 4.4Through the Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative, the FoodSTART+ project and two projects on Fe and Zn biofortitfied potatoes, more than 15 countries have seen the implementation of relevant agriculture for nutrition and health initiatives.
milestone_evidence: Through the Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative, the FoodSTART+ project and two projects on Fe and Zn biofortitfied potatoes, more than 15 countries have seen the implementation of relevant agriculture for nutrition and health initiatives.
gender_justification: Improving maternal, in particular for young mothers, and infant nutrition receive a specific attention and is among the main objectives of most of the agriculture and nutrition integrated interventions.
youth_justification: Improving maternal, in particular for young mothers, and infant nutrition receive a specific attention and is among the main objectives of most of the agriculture and nutrition integrated interventions.
capdev_justification: Integrated agriculture for nutrition and health interventions put a lot of emphasis on capacity development at different levels: frontline workers (who administer downstream training), caregivers of children under 5 years, staff in regional governments and development organizations, decision-makers.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Technologies like high quality cassava flour (HQCF), high quality cassava peels (HQCP) and small-scale efficient flash drying are at different stages of adaption and adoption. HQCF has been promoted in Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Nigeria and is one of the technologies promoted by the African Development Bank. Two RTB scaling projects support the establishment of scaling mechanisms for the other technologies in Colombia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: Transformation of cassava peels into animal feed is being scaled out in Nigeria. Energy-efficient technologies for cassava flash drying are being disseminated in Colombia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana and Nigeria.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Training activities, technical backstopping and field visits have been relaized in all the 4 countries
climate_justification: Improved technologies contribute to more efficient use of inputs through improved energy efficiency, economies of scale, and utilization of by-products. This contributes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating climate change if compared with a business-as-usual scenario.

outcome_sumary: Nigeria and Uganda are the two countries where activities are ongoing. Transformation of cassava peels, sweetpotato vines and damaged or poor-quality roots into animal feed has been demonstrated as viable options to add value to waste and sub-products. In Bangladesh and Nigeria, CRPs RTB and FISH are exploring strengthen collaboration for better integration of crop-fish agri-food systems.
milestone_evidence: Sweetpotato silage piloted for pig feed production in Uganda and under testing for dairy cattle. High quality cassava peels being scaled in Nigeria. Cassava waxing and potato storage practices tested in Uganda. Exploratory work on better integration of roots, tubers and bananas with fish agri-food systems in Bangladesh and Nigeria.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: The interventions have capacity development components to facilitate the uptake of new technologies and practices by farmers, processors, manufacturers and extension services.
climate_justification: Reducing post-harvest losses also reduces the environmental footprint of the cropping system and hence contributes to mitigating climate change

outcome_sumary: This is linked with Outcomes 4.1 and 4.3.RTB initiatives promoting gender equity through gender-sensitive value chains and gender-sensitive assessment of food products and processing practices have been documented in 10 countries.
milestone_evidence: In Bangladesh, Bolivia, Ecuador, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Peru, Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda gender-sensitive value chain approaches to promote commercialization of RTB crops and products have been implemented and documented. In Nigeria, exposure to air pollutants and heat stress among resource-poor women entrepreneurs in small-scale cassava processing has been assessed.
gender_justification: As showed in all the evidences provided, gender dimension is key in all the studies and activities realized.
youth_justification: Youth are specifically targeted through participatory approaches to promote more inclusive  value chains
capdev_justification: Development of inclusive value chains is promoted through participatory approaches that put strong emphasis on capacity development of stakeholders.
climate_justification: Exposure to smoke during gari processing, as identified in the article mentioned, is a main issue for resource-poor women entrepreneurs. Addressing this issue will improve both the health of these women and environmental footprint of gari processing

outcome_sumary: Large scale multi-stakeholder initiatives like SPHI, TAAT compacts, and projects like FoodSTART+ and RTB scaling projects are promoting novel models to develop and bring innovations at scale. Co-design and development of innovation and scaling processes are contributing in building capacities at the individual and organizational level.
milestone_evidence: Partnerships for scaling established in more than 10 countries through RTB scaling projects. Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative and the two compacts for cassava and sweetpotato in the Technologies for African Agricultural Transformation (TAAT) programme are also examples of leading role played by CG Centers in broad institutional arrangements.
gender_justification: Gender-sensitive approaches are developed and used in the framework of Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative
youth_justification: Youth agripreneurship is one of the pillars of Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative and Technologies for African Agricultural Transformation (TAAT) programme intervention strategies
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an integral component of scaling strategy of RTB projects as well as broader initiatives and programs mentioned in the milestone explanation.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Partnerships have been developed between RTB and scaling partners (CIALCA, ict4BXW, FoodStart, Euroclima in LAC, RUNRES) that have the capacity to increase income by successfully scaling RTB innovations through policy dialogue, capcity building and digital support.
milestone_evidence: 5 initiatives including RTB-Based farming system intensification and diversification for income generation have been designed and implemented in collaboration with partners (CIALCA, ict4BXW, FoodStart, Euroclima in LAC, RUNRES).
gender_justification: 'Gender responsive approaches, capacity building and gender training are included in the different interventions. Gender analysis is part of the research design in many innovations.'
youth_justification: Interventions by CIALCA and Farmer Business Schools specially target young people.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an integral part of all interventions to disseminate technology.  It is regarded as a key pillar in the desing of the initiatives.
climate_justification: Optimization options and modelling take into account climate change patterns.

outcome_sumary: Innovations and approaches to increase whole farm productivity are being scaled through partners in collaboration with key stake holders in Nigeria, Tanzania, Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo
milestone_evidence: Entry points and scaling opportunities identified and implemented in collaboration with key stakeholders in Nigeria, Tanzania, Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo. Initiatives include: Scaling Fund projects (Triple S+, BXW); One Acre Fund collaboration in Rwanda (impact potential of 300,000 farmers); Site-specific cassava fertilizer recommendations in Great Lakes Region of Africa
gender_justification: 'Gender responsive approaches, capacity building and gender training are included in the different interventions. Gender analysis is part of the research design in many innovations.'
youth_justification: Interventions by CIALCA particularly target young people.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an integral part of all interventions to disseminate technology.  It is regarded as a key pillar in the desing of the initiatives.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Nutrition related initiatives are being implemented and supported by evidence to increase diet quality indices in eight countries.
milestone_evidence: Partnerships have been established to implement nutrition-related initiatives in 8 countries including: CIALCA and ICT4BXW in Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo; FoodStart+ in Vietnam, Philippines, India and Indonesia; Anemia Zero project in Peru; Bioversity-CIAT Alliance and the American Refugee Committee (ARC) partnership exploring nutrition options in refugee camps in Rwanda.
gender_justification: Not required
youth_justification: Interventions by CIALCA particularly target young people.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is an integral part of all interventions to disseminate technology.  It is regarded as a key pillar in the desing of the initiatives.
climate_justification: Optimization options and modelling take into account climate change patterns.

outcome_sumary: In collaboration with large projects gender is being incorporated in research and development practice to equitably scale innovations for RTB crops with men, women and young people, and enhance access and control over assets and resources.
milestone_evidence: Three large initiatives (CIALCA, FoodSTART and SUSTAIN) have developed tools to mainstream gender across their research and development portfolio in Africa and Asia to equitably scale innovations for RTB crops with men, women and young people, and enhance access and control over assets and resources.
gender_justification: Gender is the main topic of tools and methods developed for different projects and interventions
youth_justification: Youth is targeted both as a component of intersectionality in gender research, and also as a key factor in agribusiness development.
capdev_justification: Most of the tools and methods developed are shared with researchers and partners through capacity development activities
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: There is an increasing awareness that RTB needs to engage with public/ private policy development to achieve impact at scale. Evidence sharing and the creation of spaces for interaction with policy makers is enhancing the inclusio of RTB crops/techologies in policies and programs executed by government agencies, NGOs and/or private sector partners. An exampe of this are the agreements signed with RAB and IFDC.
milestone_evidence: Evidence on food resilience, value chains and livelihood strategies through RTB crops and technologies were shared with policy makers, public and private sector actors in 4 countries in Asia. Evidence of RTB value chains on gender relations and wellbeing was built and shared with decision makers in 6 African countries.
gender_justification: Some of the spaces created for dialogue with policy makers have specific gender related objectives (Effects of commercialization of sweetpotato on gender relations and wellbeing)
capdev_justification: Many of the spaces for interaction hold capacity development objectives and activities to create awareness and influence policy change
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Strong emphasis was placed on capacity development of MSc and PhD students and staff of research and development partner organizations. In parallel, capcity developmetn curricula was developed and facilitated internally to staff and to teams from partner organizations to support strategic topics such as gender and SDI.
milestone_evidence: 2 PhDs defended- 6 PhD candidates ongoing in the field of Innovation and Scaling- 8 PhDs ongoing on sustainable intensification and diversification- 8 MSc students supported- FoodSTART+: technical expertise in Asia with IFAD (220,000 people)- ICT4BXW trained extension providers and end-users on the use of ICT tools for scaling SDSR in Rwanda- CIALCA organized a Gender and Nutrition in AR4D training for partners and students
gender_justification: Gender is one of the areas of capacity development to internal staff and to partner organizations
youth_justification: Youth is a target group for capacity building and one of the topics as part of gender and intersectionality.
capdev_justification: Capacity is the main focus of all activities
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Different models including scaling readiness have been developed and tested with partners in more than 15 countries. An analysis and comparison of different models is underway, and addition modules are beind developed for more responsible scaling and gender-responsive scaling.
milestone_evidence: The Science of Scaling Special Issue will contain a number of reflexive journal articles that provide ex-post analysis of the innovation histories of e.g. OFSP. However, this will be published in 2020
gender_justification: New models for gender responsive scaling are being developed
youth_justification: Youth is being included as a component of intersectionality analysis for scaling
capdev_justification: Capacity development to partners is a continues process to ensuere approrpiate testinga and validation of methods.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Partnerships with NARS have been established to develop capacity for dealing with climate risks and extremes, including for RTB crops. In parallel, new tools, methods and evidence have been produced to detect, adress and forecast stress.
milestone_evidence: Initiatives supported by RTB in India, China, Myanmar, Philipines, Vietnam and Indonesia included an analysis of expected effects of selected innovations on households' capacity to deal with climate risks and extremes.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Climate change adaptation is the central topic of analysis through varieties and climate patterns.

outcome_sumary: Best practices for climate-smart and soil management in cassava and banana systems have been developed and documented. Partnerships have been established to scale SDI approaches on soil, water and nutrient cycles for nutritional sensitive agriculture.
milestone_evidence: 7 studies have assessed and documented effects of SDI approaches on soil, water and nutrient cycles for nutritional-sensitive agriculture. Other initiatives like the Circular Economy Project focus on closing nutrient loops and waste streams in Rwanda and Ethiopia.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Optimization options and modelling take into account climate change patterns.

outcome_sumary: Spawning and production first selected generation of silver carp was completed. Catla carp were not productive in 2019 and could not be bred. Breeding is now scheduled for breeding in 2020.Experiments on key resilience traits in GIFT were completed and genomic data obtained, both key steps in the production of novel improved strains for these farmed fish of global importance. Good progress was made in development if integrated assessment tools for tilapia fish farming, that were used to assess performance of improved tilapia strains.Key data on performance and yield gaps in tilapia farming were analysed and findings studies published.
milestone_evidence: Silver carp first generation has been produced. Catla were not productive and are now scheduled for breeding in 2020.Samples collected for genomic analysis and data to be analysed in 2020 for genomic-based selection of GIFT in Malaysia.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Spawning and production first selected generation of silver carp was completed. Catla carp were not productive in 2019 and could not be bred. Breeding is now scheduled for breeding in 2020.Experiments on key resilience traits in GIFT were completed and genomic data obtained, both key steps in the production of novel improved strains for these farmed fish of global importance. Good progress was made in development if integrated assessment tools for tilapia fish farming, that were used to assess performance of improved tilapia strains.Key data on performance and yield gaps in tilapia farming were analysed and findings studies published.
milestone_evidence: The assessment of the impact of dissemination of genetically improved Abbassa Nile tilapia strains was conducted. Results were published in a peer review paper. In addition, a systematic literature review of the major factors causing yield gap by affecting growth, feed conversion ratio and survival in Nile tilapia was also conducted. This has been key to inform the theory of chage behind the GIFT impacts studies.A study, dataset availabe, was conducted in Bangladesh to assess GIFT diffusion at ahatchery level and to evaluate breeding performance at farm level. This has included socio-economic analysis of farms and management implications. A baseline assessment for analysing tilapia adoption was also conducted in Myanmar.
gender_justification: Gender is one of the key dimensions explored while assessing adoption and performance of GIFT
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Several promising lines of cooperation with private sector partners in fish disease diagnostics and feed ingredients were successfully pursued with co-investment during 2019. These include the partner Wilderlab for fish disease diagnostics tools through the Inspire Big Data collaboration on “Lab in a backpack”; and feed companies engaged in fish feeds research and scaling related to the nutritious pond concept (NPC) and novel ingredients, including Skretting, several national feed companies in Bangladesh and DeHeus (the latter funding of two PhD students from Bangladesh).
milestone_evidence: Bangladesh National Health Strategy, that provides a One Health framework for managing disease risks in aquatic animals and public and private sector cooperation and investment, has been produced. This strategy provides a framework for public and private investments in Bangladesh aquatic animal health.An MoU with Single Spark has been signed to support the start-up of new entrepreneurs in Bangladesh.An MoU with De Heus, for co-investment in feed development in Bangladesh, was also concluded.A new MOU for R&D cooperation with Skretting was also signed and different activities, co-funded within this partnership, has started in Egypt.A partnership with Wilderlab was also established for developing a rapid genomic detection tool for aquaculture pathogens under Big Data Innovation grant.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Building capacity of research and development partners is key for scaling up FISH research about fish feed and fish health
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Better management practice (BMPs) guidelines for improving tilapia farming management have been published at global level, and progressively adapted to national circumstances through national BMP guidelines and bilaterally funded projects, to guide sustainable tilapia farming practices in training and extension programs.The partnership platform established by the Aquaculture compact of the Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project provides an important conduit for scaling of improved fish farming practices in focal (DR Congo, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria and Zambia) and satellite (Burundi, Cameroon, Cote D’Ivoire, Republic of Benin and Tanzania) countries. A partnership with the Southern Africa Development Cooperation supports further extension of best practices in aquatic genetic resources management to member countries in that region of Africa. A partnership platform became operational in Cambodia in early 2020
milestone_evidence: The first Tilapia BMP workshop was held in WorldFish Abbassa, Egypt in Jan 2019. The workshop convened key people involved in breeding, dissemination and farming of tilapia and agreed on an approach to coordinate and facilitate the process of developing tilapia BMP products at global and country levels.Based on this global workshop and approach, 2 national BMPs have been developed in Zambia and Timor-Leste, while other countries such as Bangladesh and Myanmar and Egypt have been involved in multi-stakeholder consultations and have drafted national guidelines.FISH CRP had supported the development of the SADC Regional Tilapia Genetic Improvement programe that guided to develop three national nucleus breeding programmes for tilapia in the region.
gender_justification: The application of better management practices keep in account gender differences to improve adoption for both men and women farmers
capdev_justification: The scope of the better management practices is to build the capacity of the stakeholders, including farmers, to enhance efficiency and  sustainability of aquaculture
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: Better management practice (BMPs) guidelines for improving tilapia farming management have been published at global level, and progressively adapted to national circumstances through national BMP guidelines and bilaterally funded projects, to guide sustainable tilapia farming practices in training and extension programs.The partnership platform established by the Aquaculture compact of the Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project provides an important conduit for scaling of improved fish farming practices in focal (DR Congo, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria and Zambia) and satellite (Burundi, Cameroon, Cote D’Ivoire, Republic of Benin and Tanzania) countries. A partnership with the Southern Africa Development Cooperation supports further extension of best practices in aquatic genetic resources management to member countries in that region of Africa. A partnership platform became operational in Cambodia in early 2020
milestone_evidence: Thanks to the initiatives promoted by the Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project, various aquaculture research and development approaches have been developed and implemented in 10 African countries.
gender_justification: Platforms and R&D agenda promoted by the FISH CRP focus on solutions that are inclusive and gender sensitive.
youth_justification: Platforms and R&D agenda promoted by the FISH CRP focus on solutions that are inclusive and create opportunities for the youth.
capdev_justification: Solutions proposed are co-developed with and released to partners and stakeholdes
climate_justification: Platforms and R&D agenda promoted by the FISH CRP focus on solutions that are environmentally friendly and climate-smart.

outcome_sumary: The partnership platforms established by the Aquaculture compact of the Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project and by Aquaculture Technical, Vocational and Entrepreneurship Training for Improved Private Sector and Smallholder Skills (AQ TEVET) project are key steps toward enhancing the linkages between the private sector and smallholder fish farmers in Africa.A partnership platform became operational in Cambodia in early 2020Multiple partnerships are being pursued across focal and scaling countries for scaling of FISH aquaculture technologies, showing overall positive progress in scaling. Notable examples are: Bangladesh through private sector and market systems oriented projects involving health, feed and aquaculture management; Cambodia through a cooperation with the American SoyBean Association; Timor Leste with private hatchery investors; and African Development Bank investments in Zambia and Malawi.
milestone_evidence: Approaches to enhance the linkages between the private sector and smallholder commercial fish farmers have been adopted in Northern Zambia via input supply stores. Infographic from the AQ TVET project in Zambia explains the approach.The Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project web site provides an outline of the countries involved and partnership approach.A policy case describes a commitment of the Southern African Development Community for scaling fish genetic improvement investments in the SADC region.
gender_justification: Business model proposed are inclusive and developed to support women’s empowerment.
youth_justification: Business models developed by the Fish CRP focus on creating opportunities for the youth
capdev_justification: Solutions proposed are co-developed with and released to partners and stakeholdes
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: The partnership platforms established by the Aquaculture compact of the Technologies for African Agriculture Transformation (TAAT) project and by Aquaculture Technical, Vocational and Entrepreneurship Training for Improved Private Sector and Smallholder Skills (AQ TEVET) project are key steps toward enhancing the linkages between the private sector and smallholder fish farmers in Africa.A partnership platform became operational in Cambodia in early 2020Multiple partnerships are being pursued across focal and scaling countries for scaling of FISH aquaculture technologies, showing overall positive progress in scaling. Notable examples are: Bangladesh through private sector and market systems oriented projects involving health, feed and aquaculture management; Cambodia through a cooperation with the American SoyBean Association; Timor Leste with private hatchery investors; and African Development Bank investments in Zambia and Malawi.
milestone_evidence: Bangladesh project provides co-investment with private sector into scaling of technologies and business models.A cooperation with the American Soybean Association in Cambodia is scaling feeding technologies to fish farmersPrivate sector investment in GIFT fish hatchery in Timor Leste. Public sector investment in GIFT genetic program in Odisha, India.African Development Bank invests in Zambia to adopt genetic technologies for development of an improved strain of Oreochromis andersonii.African Development Bank invests in a Sustainable Fisheries, Aquaculture and Watershed Management project in Malawi that includes investment in aquaculture and genetic technologies from WorldFish research.WorldFish and U.S. Soybean Export Council (USSEC) promote the use of In Pond Raceway System (IPRS) technology in Egypt.
gender_justification: Integrated aquaculture technologies and business models proposed are gender sensitive.
capdev_justification: Solutions proposed are co-developed with and released to partners and stakeholdes
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary: A series of regional and global syntheses were complete during the year, at global and national scales, with further influential deliverables along this pathway to be produced in 2020 and beyond. These syntheses include papers published on nutritional values of coastal fisheries and small-scale fisheries governance and associated country level initiatives in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar and Timor Leste.“Hidden Harvest” data sets from four countries, as part of the FISH-FAO cooperation on small-scale fisheries in food systems progress well. A regional paper on fish in food systems of Asia was completed and submitted for publication.
milestone_evidence: Key papers published on nutritional values of coastal fisheries and small-scale fisheries governanceTimor-Leste reports on fisheries and aquaculture assessment; journal article on trade flows of fish; and a journal article on collaborative governance fit for fisheries and food security in Timor-Leste. Country level initiatives in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar and Timor Leste have informed regional/global analyses and/or enabled FISH to put into practice synthesis findings.Bangladesh and Myanmar publications on cross-border stocks and fisheries for Hilsa in Bangladesh and Myanmar.Methodological innovation (reported 2018) employed in data collection completed with datasets lodged on MEL for Eqypt, Bangladesh, Malawi and Zambia as part of Illuminating Hidden Harvest Initiative.
gender_justification: Gender is an important component in the Illuminating Hidden Harvest initiative
capdev_justification: Decision making processes are highly participatory and enhance capacity of stakeholders that are involved
climate_justification: Climate-smart solution are promoted and investigated to enhance sustainability of fishery communities

outcome_sumary: Livelihood improvements, alternative livelihoods and livelihood buffers have been tested through action research – best practice guides and diagnostic tools have been developed and disseminated through established networks (e.g., regional agencies) and new investments. Technologies include fish drying tents, fish aggregating devices, solar powered freezers, savings schemes. Whilst more lessons will emerge as contexts and opportunities change this is complete as per milestone.
milestone_evidence: Peer review articles on women’s participation in fisheries value chains in Malawi (Nagoli et al. 2019; Pasani et al. 2019), and guiding gender-sensitive and inclusive livelihood improvement initiatives. For Pacific region, learning on livelihoods being integrated into manual for broad dissemination through SPC and regional networks in 2020.Exposure stories published on line as part of dissemination “Ingredients of success” and “Women’s use of solar power freezers”Early 2020 publication of diagnosis tool for livelihoods as an innovation – taken up by EU investment. 2020 evaluation of uptake.Fisheries technology assessed as high return on investment intervention (Tilley et al. 2019) and manual of best practice developed and adapted by regional agency in the PacificHigh level keynote presentation on livelihood learning to 1000 fisheries stakeholders at United Nations Science to Policy Nexus meeting
gender_justification: The research work has a significant focus on women

outcome_sumary: Three multi-stakeholder platforms have been identified and established – these are being institutionalised through 2020.Progress was made during 2019 in adoption of emerging governance and production models in multi-functional landscapes in Cambodia and Myanmar, Fish rice innovations scaling in Cambodia and land use reform enabled in Myanmar will allow further scaling of rice-fish innovations. Guidelines to support adoption and application of governance and fish production models across a wider range of water infrastructure and management contexts were drafted during 2019 and their promotion through fisheries and water governance and management stakeholders and networks will commence during 2020 with formal release of guide.. "

climate_justification: Platforms and R&D agenda promoted by the FISH CRP focus on solutions that are environmentally friendly and climate-smart.

outcome_sumary: The large seeded Mesoamerican bean lines’ drought-tolerance was tested against drought checks for two years. They also present excellent combining ability. The parentage of these lines does not reveal the source of their traits, with the exception of one parental line with superior low fertility tolerance. These lines illustrate the importance of maintaining a large number of crosses in a breeding program, to identify serendipitous combinations.Some 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding program with disease resistance and promising levels of Fe in red, black and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program, 200 lines from a population developed for drought and BCMV resistance were evaluated in a drought and irrigated trial. Thirty-eight lines from a population developed for heat tolerance were evaluated in drought and irrigated conditions. Data needs to be analyzed to code new lines (~70) for multi-location testing. Resistance to BLCrV was identified in Mesoamerican lines; so a population was developed to backcross this trait into Andean germplasm. The population was advanced under disease pressure, evaluated in two seasons, and is now entering yield trials.More than 70 families have been developed for heat tolerance. Several were evaluated under heat in the Caribia Research Station of AgroSavia, the Colombian national program. Other populations presented modest resistance to leafhoppers. Entomological studies demonstrate resistance or tolerance to leaf miners and white flies. Initial data on Fe concentration in some lines exhibit as much as 20 ppm above the baseline. These early results highlight the great value of tapping the tertiary gene pool.11,885 tons produced in 7 countries. Increased utilization of quality seed of improved varieties. Reduced time between the release and use. Increased number of seed producers engaged and increased seed business volume. Increased linkages between seed and grain production.An initial evaluation of wild P. acutifolius under a GCDT project revealed 2 accessions (G40287 and G40056) that could withstand night temperatures of 28oC and still produce seed. Families developed from these accessions were evaluated in the greenhouse under 25oC nights, with some 30 families presenting good pod formation. Further evaluation will support the search for QTL for heat tolerance. These lines complement other interspecific lines developed in previous years, of which the line SEF 16 emerged as the best in field trials on the north coast of Colombia.Greenhouse screening using breeding lines for ALS using aggressive strains identified MAB349 and MAB359 as promising resistant genotypes. Other genotypes such as NUA184, SMN184 and NXB080 showed acceptable levels of resistance.This was adopted as a PhD research topic, and thus was not pursued within the program.An R programme facilitates data processing from MSPQ tool for heat-related photosynthate transport, performing basic statistics, reflecting behavior under heat and identifying the best 10% genotypes. MPSQ seeks multidimensional evaluation of data to understand tolerance. Artificial intelligence to evaluate seed filling in scanning bleached bean pods is in final evaluation. We also verified that tolerant genotypes under heat elongate pods rapidly and consistently during pod elongation and later in seed-filling stage. An approach to evaluate abortion with and without heat shock is being developed in growth chambers.ABC research teams in Tanzania have shown that the use of micronutrients based fertilizers increase agricultural productivity by at least 25% across crops and geographies. Beyond phosphorus, research is needed on bean response to molybdenum, zinc, boron, manganese and copper.No new markers for BGMV have been tried this year. The MAGIC population needs to be evaluated for this trait in LAC, or the BASE needs to be re-evaluated in replicated trials.
milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. The system has been tested as part of an undergraduate thesis. While functional, it is quite expensive and may not be practical.
other_reason: While partially met for bush beans, climbing beans represent a greater challenge as they are inherently later to flower and mature.
